column2: The absence of public statements from Protestant leadership concerning the current conflict in Ulster became even more evident when Dr. Carl McIntire came north from Collingswood, N. J., to try to force a confrontation of the Rev. Ian Paisley of Ulster and our Mayor.

All honor to Miss Alice Tully. Praise, too, to the hall that bears her name. As a place to hear chamber music, the new room at Lincoln Center is proving to be just what the acoustical doctor ordered. And, of last night's concert by seven master musicians brought together by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, it may properly be said that theater and artists deserved each other.

ATHENS -- In the privacy of their homes, in the shadows of hotel bars and in bustling downtown cafes, opponents of the Greek military regime gather to exchange anxieties, rumors and thoughts for the future.

GENEVA, Sept. 14 (Reuters) -- The 54-nation United Nations Trade and Development Board has called on the World Bank to consider working out arrangements for supplementary financing, a project to help out poorer countries whose development is disrupted by unforeseen drops in export earnings.

The 535th press release issued this year by Mayor Lindsay announced in seven long paragraphs last week that for the first time the city was constructing a succah -- a reproduction of the shelter Jews built on the desert in their flight from Egypt more than 2,000 years ago -- to commemorate the Succoth holiday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 14 -- Dr. Aubrey L. Whittemore Jr. won his third straight Luders-16 Class race with Naiad on Long Island Sound off the Riverside Yacht Club today. The regatta was the 38th and final of the championship series for Yacht Racing Association fleets based east of Rye.
Three chartered flights carrying 200 Czechoslovak refugees arrived here last week. Many of the newcomers said they feared that the Prague Government would soon stop granting exit permits.

KLAGENFURT, Austria, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Oarsmen from the United States captured two of the seven titles in the European rowing championships on Woerther Lake today, a feat unmatched by any of the other 27 nations.
More than 2,600 tons of refuse were removed from the city's streets yesterday as sanitationmen worked overtime -- at a cost of $100,000 -- for the second consecutive Sunday.

The White House is investigating allegations that Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, and his former law associate were paid more than twice as much as other landowners for property condemned last year by the state for highway construction in South Carolina, Life magazine reported yesterday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- Anatoly Y. Levitin, a religious dissenter whose writings have been published in the West under the pseudonym Krasnov, is reported to have been arrested three days ago for anti-Soviet activity.

THE apartment could have been at an expensive address; the taste of the inhabitants, modern and sophisticated. But this particular apartment is in a recently completed New York City Housing Authority project for low-income families, and the decorators were staff members of the authority -- Elizabeth Archer and Louise Spindel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Of the various barriers that the Federal Government might raise against the merger, the required approval by the Federal Communications Commission of the transfer of ownership of the Dallas radio and television stations was believed by observers in Washington as the likeliest to cause significant delay, or even disapproval.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 14 -- The Israeli Government has decided not to cooperate with a United Nations committee investigating the status of Arabs in areas occupied by Israel in the 1967 war.

A slowdown in the increase in relief rolls here -- even more than in city budget plans last spring -- is currently counted on to supply the $3-million for extra police overtime in the next four months.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 -- An eight-year exile did not rid Robert F. Williams, the black revolutionary, of the conviction that armed self defense is at times the Negro's best politics, but Mr. Williams said yesterday it had convinced him that America today represented "the best chance ever" for "social changes and racial justice."
A wide-ranging study of the obstacles raised by economic nationalism to international business and trade was released during the weekend by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Albert Clipper possesses a bright, clarion tenor of impressive weight and cutting power. This is a voice of obvious heroic dimensions -- perhaps even too much for the intimacy of Carnegie Recital Hall where he sang yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Santa Barbara oil slick and low bids on newly discovered Alaska oil lands are expected to cut $300-million from the Government's revenues for oil leasing this year, an Interior Department official says.

The September meeting of the 300-man delegate body of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, held at the Police Recreation Center in Tannersville, N. Y. last week, has become a tradition: some union work, but mostly three days of fun and games.
BUFFALO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A paraplegic, crippled during a 1967 robbery attempt, fell from his wheel chair today and was arrested as he tried to flee from a variety store robbery, the police said.

SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Sept. 14 (UPI) -- Dog-tired Bill Toomey, with a sore back and limping from a bruised left heel, made a valiant bid for the world record in the decathlon today, but fell short by 182 points.

VIENNA, Sept. 14 -- The Central Committee of the Czechoslovak Communist party is expected to begin a secret session on Thurslay to decide the political fate of its former First Secretary, Alexander Dubcek, and other leaders of the 1968 democratizing experiment.

THE recent Students' Team Tournament in Dresden, East Germany, in which 26 four-man teams from every part of the globe participated, was partitioned into five preliminary sections. The two highest-scoring teams in each section qualified for the finals.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino has hired a new advertising agency, which has come up with his campaign slogan: "A Better Life for Everyone."
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- Vassar College will begin tomorrow a drive to raise $50-million by 1972 -- the biggest campaign goal in the college's history.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- There was still no official word here today of any decisions made by President Nixon and his principal advisers on Vietnam at their meeting at Camp David yesterday.

APIA, Western Samoa -- Gray-haired chiefs in lava-lava, the traditional wraparound skirt worn by island men, and youths in blue jeans personify a growing generation gap in the dreamy isles of Western Samoa, the first Polynesian state to become independent in this century.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A major research program at the National Cancer Institute has been forced to order 380 valuable monkeys killed because of a shortage of funds.
College football's centennial year had a partial opening Saturday and the University of California, Los Angeles, and three quarterbacks quickly hit the spotlight.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 14 (Reuters) -- Troops took over petroleum installations and the distribution of oil in key centers of this island nation today following a Government proclamation of a state of emergency last night to deal with a wave of strikes.

Wearing a frock coat and clutching a well-thumbed Bible, the Rev. Carl McIntire, the radio preacher, read his "Christian Manifesto" on the steps of Riverside Church yesterday, demanding $3-billion in "reparations" to fundamentalists.
WHAT can we expect of the future of art? These two collections of essays inadvertently collide head-on in offering opposing answers.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 14 (UPI) -- A pinch double by Bob Taylor and a single by Jerry Adair scored the tying and winning runs in the ninth inning today, as the Kansas City Royals edged the Minnesota Twins, 4-3.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A group of Negro elected officials from throughout the nation, ending three days of meetings with high government officials, asserted today that the Nixon Administration had failed either to understand or to act effectively on the problems of black people in America.

DALLAS, Sept. 14 -- Roger Staubach presented the specter of the scrambling quarterback in the Cotton Bowl tonight to the shock and concern of his coach, Tom Landry, and the temporary delight of a crowd of 58,975.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A Federal judge here ruled today that the officers of the United Mine Workers of America had been using the union's bimonthly newspaper "as a propaganda organ" to promote their re-election.

NETCONG, N. J., Sept. 15 -Sections of the Congressional Record quoting prayers recited by chaplains in the United States Senate and House of Representatives will be read to students in the Netcong public schools starting tomorrow.

MENTON, France, Sept. 15 -Arthur Miller, who is retiring as president, made an appeal for youth today as he opened the 36th international congress of the PEN Club in Menton's neo-Renaissance Palais del Oro.

A Czechoslovak professor of neurology, here on a brief professional visit, was attacked and robbed at 125th Street and Madison Avenue late Sunday night, as he was returning to his hotel from a weekend visit with some friends.
CASS LAKE, Minn. -- Rain drummed on the roof of our cottage at Birch Villa the opening day of the International Muskie Tournament, partially flattening the waves on Cass Lake.

HUBERT DE GIVENCHY has always stood head and shoulders above the other Paris dressmakers, and even now as the haute couture scrambles to keep its place in the sun, the 6-foot-6inch designer is still unique.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 15 -The developers of the highyield cereals that are increasing food production dramatically in hungry countries reported today a major victory for their seeds over drought and disease.

Group III, a social club that has sponsored ski trips and other amusements for its subscribers, will turn its attention to fund-raising Oct. 11 with a dinner-dance to benefit the Harlem Hospital School of Nursing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Senator Gordon Allott of Colorado removed himself from the race for Republican leadership in the Senate today, leaving three declared candidates to succeed the late Everett McKinley Dirksen.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- Teachers here voted today to authorize a strike that could close down classes for 674,367 students in the city's public schools.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- Steve Carlton of the St. Louis Cardinals set a major league record tonight by striking out 19 New York Mets. But the Mets still won the game, 4-3, on a pair of two-run home runs by Ron Swoboda and extended their lead to 4 1/2 games with 15 to play.

The United States Court of Appeals refused yesterday to reduce the bail for 13 persons identified by the police as Black Panthers who are being held on charges of plotting to blow up department stores, subways and other civic targets.

SIGNATURE scarves were only the beginning. Having tasted the drawing power of designer names on things other than the clothes with which they made their reputation, the designers are now gleefully searching for new worlds to conquer.

Paul-Marc Henry, a French diplomat on loan to the United Nations, who was evicted from a train Sunday because his two miniature poodles were not muzzled, demanded an apology yesterday from the mayor of New Rochelle and the New Haven Railroad.

The boards of directors of the Williams Brothers Company and the Edgcomb Steel Company have signed a definitive affiliation agreement and plan of reorganization for the merger of Edgcomb into a newly formed subsidiary of Williams.
The $28,350 Stymie Handicap was coming up yesterday at Belmont Park and Frank Bonnetti of Brooklyn was looking to get even.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -Pennsylvania put an end to its streak of eight nonwinning years last season. The Quakers were the surprise of Ivy League football finishing third and posting a 7-2 won-lost record over all. Opponents take Penn seriously enough this year to give the Quakers an outside chance at the 1969 league title.
ATHENS, Sept. 15 (AP) -Jurgen May, a former East German distance runner who defected, was removed from the West German team tonight on the eve of the European track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Legislation designed to help thousands of college students obtain tuition loans cleared the House of Representatives today. Approved by a vote of 322 to 60, the bill would permit the Federal Government to make incentive payments to private lending institutions that grant loans to students.

VALENTINO, the Italian couturier, confirmed here yesterday that Beck Industries, a burgeoning fashion complex, has purchased his Rome haute couture house as well as rights to his name to introduce a line of perfumes and cosmetics.

IN the uproar last spring over the cancellation of the Smothers Brothers there was talk that this season would bring pussyfooting to accommodate Washington. Perhaps so, but it wasn't detectable last night in the fall return from 8 to 9 o'clock of Dan Rowan and Dick Martin on "Laugh-In" over the National Broadcasting Company network.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Englewood's acting city treasurer has resigned following charges she received welfare at the same time she was on the city's payroll.
State Senator Roy M. Goodman charged the Federal Government yesterday with "the worst kind of slumlord practices" in three tenements on East 32d Street near Third Avenue.
Joe Namath's availability for the New York Jets' game in Denver on Sunday will be determined later this week.
Capital spending next year will increase by 5, 7 or 9 per cent, depending on who your favorite economic pundit may be.
BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -Tommy Heinsohn, who helped the Boston Celtics win eight championships in nine years as a player, returned to the National Basketball Association team today as coach.

However much we may lament the kidnapping of the U.S. Ambassador in Brazil, we need to keep in mind that it was a symbolic political act in a revolutionary struggle in that part of the world. As such an act, there are several things about it which merit attention:

The International Leisure Corporation yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a secondary offering of 800,000 common shares to be sold primarily by the Tracy Investment Company, a holding company controlled by Kirk Kerkorian.

ANCHORAGE, Sept. 13 -Evidence is slowly mounting that a polar bear, instead of being a "citizen" of the whole vast frozen Arctic -- a beast without a country -- may indeed owe allegiance to a specific area of the polar basin.

A few days before Election Day in 1954, voters in Connecticut suddenly began hearing ugly ethnic slurs about the Democratic candidate for Governor, a Jew. Some thought that the whispering campaign would work, proving that the time had indeed not yet come for New England's first Jewish Governor.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 15 -- Yale University's president today held up the example of two alumni -- New York City's Mayor, John V. Lindsay, and the Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr. -- to the incoming freshman class, praising the two as men "wholly unashamed of their high purpose."

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 15 -- The New York Giants tumbled out of their meeting, dressed in sweatsuits and sneakers. Jim Katcavage followed them in slacks and a sport shirt. His season was over, but his coaching career was just beginning.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 15 -- Fears of fresh violence increased here tonight after the Central Defense Committee said that the street barricades in the Roman Catholic area of the city would be maintained unless its demands were met.

I read with satisfaction of the new benefits for the City University faculty. Until eight years ago I was one of its members. I believe that I speak for many emeriti, who had to leave before the benefits became good, if I ask that the pension benefits be increased for them, too.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Secretary of State William P. Rogers extended for another six months today the formal but largely ineffective curbs on travel by United States citizens to Communist China, North Korea, North Vietnam and Cuba.
A city official yesterday defended the use of English grammar questions in a Civil Service examination for promotion to police captain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -A study group of distinguished lawyers and economists reported to President Nixon today that the Federal Trade Commission wastes much of its time and money on "trivial matters"; that its staff is characterized by "incompetence," especially at the top; that it does less work now with more people than it did 10 years ago, and that it should be changed or abolished.
BONN, Sept. 15 -- The Soviet Government has offered to negotiate a pact with this country to renounce the use of force, it was disclosed tonight.

Svetlana Alliluyeva believes that -- contrary to widespread speculation -- her father, Josef Stalin, was completely sane when he carried out the purges of the nineteen-thirties, which cost hundreds of thousands of Russian lives.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 -- Seven hundred delegates to the International Industrial Conference here and 450 young demonstrators disagreed today about the best road to peace.

SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, Tuesday, Sept. 16 -- Comdr. Albert S. McLemore, captain of the destroyer Frank E. Evans, was found guilty today and sentenced to a reprimand on charges of negligence and dereliction of duty in the collision of his vessel with the Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne.

Five major oil companies here joined the three original oil companies in the task of building a massive 800-mile pipeline to transport oil from Prudhoe Bay on Alaska's North Slope to a warm-water port at the Gulf of Alaska.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported today.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 15 -- France told her five partners in the European Common Market today that she would not discuss Britain's application for membership before the market's agricultural policy had been given its final shape.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Clement F. Haynsworth Jr., President Nixon's nominee to the Supreme Court, will face a searching public inquiry on his judicial ethics when the Senate Judiciary Committee begins its conference hearings tomorrow morning.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Three decades after the Battle of Britain, a campaign has started to promote the man now credited with having won it -- 87-year-old Lord Dowding.

DENVER, Sept. 15 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit refused today to halt a public school integration plan that was put into effect for the opening of Denver schools Sept. 2. The court said that such action would be "disruptive."

Judge Harold R. Tyler of the Federal District Court yesterday ordered the reinstatement of 15 Sanitation Department employes who had been suspended a year ago after refusing to answer questions in a city investagation of charges that sanitation men had taken fees from five private sanitation companies to permit the companies to use city dumps.
Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said yesterday that a post-election summit meeting between the United States and the Soviet Union last December was blocked by then President-elect Nixon.

MANNINGTON, W. Va. Sept. 15 (UPI) -- Work crews searching 500 feet underground for the remains of 78 men inside consol No. 9 mine suffered their first setback today when they encountered a rockfall and waist-high water.
HONG KONG, Sept. 15 -- Communist China appears to have halted the redeployment, begun last May, of ambassadors withdrawn two years ago from countries having diplomatic relations with Peking.

Those taxicab drivers who picketed four midtown hotels to protest the new bus service to the city's airports were aiming at the wrong target. The only reason the bus service has come into existence is that taxi service is so often so wretchedly inadequate.

Biafra's leaders have again shown the world they are ready to accept mass starvation of their people rather than sacrifice the minimum of "face" to permit a full-scale resumption of relief flights. They have rejected an agreement worked out with Nigeria by the International Committee of the Red Cross to allow unhindered daytime flights of food and medicine into the secessionist enclave for a trial period of three weeks.

Home movies of dead rats, refuse and garbage cans floating on four feet of water that was rushing down the center of residential streets in South Ozone Park, Queens, were shown yesterday at City Hall.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it had approved an agreement by which Pan American World Airways will lend New York Airways up to $400,000.

SCHWEINFURF, West Germany, Sept. 7 -- For nearly three years they worked together famously -- Finance Minister Franz Josef Strauss, the conservative from Bavaria, and Economics Minister Karl Schiller the progressive professor from Hamburg.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 16 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said last night that a decision had been made to withdraw an additional 40,500 American troops from South Vietnam by the end of November.

Methadone, a substance whose advocates say can help a heroin addict return to normal life, is about to become a major matter of controversy -political and governmental -between the Lindsay administration and the Democrats.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Following is the summary of the report of the American Bar Association commission on the Federal Trade Commission and two excerpts from the main body of the report:
A one-act comedy whose cast of four men and five women will appear in the nude for most of the performance will open on Broadway Nov. 22.
Commercial broadcasters have begun making decisive efforts to become attuned to the communities they are licensed to serve.

Your Sept. 6 editorial "Strange Precedent" on the vote of the Protestant Episcopal Church which, under pressure from militant black churchmen, recently allocated $200,000 to the National Committee of Black Churchmen is greatly appreciated by me personally.
Four steamship industry executives agreed yesterday that conventional cargo transport had become obsolete.

Robert C. Wilson, formerly a vice president of the General Electric Company, has been elected a corporate vice president of the North American Rockwell Corporation and named president of its commercial products group.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Draft lawyers across the country are pressing the Selective Service System to live up to the notion that local boards are truly "local" in composition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, will call tomorrow for two efforts aimed at establishing a national health policy. His action comes after the Department of Health, Education and Welfare acknowledged that the Government now had no such policy.
The stock market overcame its customary "blue Monday" jinx yesterday and posted a broad advance on expectations of another major withdrawal of United States troops from Vietnam.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 15 -- Amid the pewter and the brass and the ghosts of the past, the South's Governors have gathered here for their annual meeting -- and, in these quaint surroundings so faithfully dedicated to yesterday, their session is appropriately dominated by the spirit of one no longer with them.
PARIS, Sept. 15 -- The Group of 10 financial powers agreed today to give France part, but not immediately all, of the special credits she sought from the International Monetary Fund.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Nixon Administration announced plans today to shift administration of the food stamp program from the Agriculture Department to the Welfare Department.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Financial institutions of various kinds strongly opposed today the provisions of the Housepassed tax reform bill affecting them.
The General Assembly of the United Nations which reconvenes here today closed a lackluster 1968 session with a stinging rebuke from its president, the late Emilio Arenales of Guatemala.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A news release mailed out routinely by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare last Wednesday said its Secretary, Robert H. Finch, was starting a series of studies as a first step toward asking Congress to include out-of-hospital drug costs under Medicare.
VIENNA, Sept. 15 -- Only a few hundred of 50,000 Czechoslovaks who sought asylum in the West since their country's invasion were understood to have returned home under an amnesty that expired today.
Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday the 2.7 per cent decline in reported crime for July "holds out to all New York the promise of a safer city." decline was disclosed Sunday by the Police Department.
The seventh New York Film Festival opens tonight in the new Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Britain ran a surplus on her international trade last month, for the first time in more than two years.
The Socialist Labor party and the Socialist Workers party denounced yesterday attempts by supporters of Mayor Lindsay to put them off the Nov. 4 ballot as "blatantly undemocratic."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- Secretary General Thant called today for the inclusion of Communist China in disarmament talks so that "the mad momentum of the arms race" could at last be broken.
CAIRO, Ill., Sept. 15 (UPI) -Police Chief William H. Petersen and Mayor Lee P. Stenzel resigned today, plunging this racially torn city into a new crisis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Last January, when the Senate's Republicans were locked in mortal combat over their assistant leadership, there appeared in this space the rather snide comment that if the claim of Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania to have a majority was sustained, Scott would "distinguish himself as the first moderate Republican who has learned to count."
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 15 -The proprietor of a Bronx sporting-goods store was arrested in a Commack motel tonight as he allegedly tried to sell a bomb to a Treasury agent.

The split over pricing policies among major computer manufacturers widened yesterday with the announcement by the Control Data Corporation that it was raising its charges for computer products and maintenance services.

The Monsanto Company, which had planned to sell $150-million of debentures tomorrow, announced last night that because of "unfavorable conditions in the bond market" it had withdrawn the offering from registration.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The British Government insisted tonight that the barricades in Belfast come down and rejected the conditions for removal set by a group of Roman Catholics.
Willie Mays is alive and well, and so are the San Francisco Giants.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 15 -- Israeli military officials imposed new restrictions today on west-bank truck drivers engaged in trade with Jordan across the "open bridges."

" I have Dick Manoff in the office here with me," said George F. Burns on the telephone yesterday. He was speaking from the office of the president of the Smith-Corona Marchant Division of the SCM Corporation.

CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Sept. 15 (UPI) -- A riot unit was forced to use tear gas to subdue more than 200 marine prisoners who attacked guards in the brig here last night, the Marine Corps disclosed today.

The election of Richard M. Wasserman, president of Levitt and Sons, Inc., as chief executive officer of the home and community building concern was announced yesterday by Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the parent company.
PARIS, Sept. 15 -- Social unrest spread through France today on the eve of a major debate in Parliament on the Government's economic and financial policies.

Tenured faculty members of the City University last night overwhelmingly ratified a threeyear contract that, their union said, would give them a salary scale higher than that of any other university in the nation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -President Nixon agreed today that the United States should land men on Mars but should not rush into an expensive highpriority program to do it.
TRADERS with long memories may have noticed an old friend on the American Stock Exchange most-active list yesterday. There it was, Westec Corporation, with a volume of 47,300 and off 1/8 at 5 5/8.

A one-week test of controlling traffic entering a busy section of the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens began yesterday. City traffic officials expressed optimism as to the outcome. The objective is to reduce snarls on the road, which is the main artery to Kennedy International Airport.

DALLAS, Sept. 15 -- As matters evolved in the last 30 days, Calvin Hill of the Dallas Cowboys has turned out to be the National Football League's answer to O. J. Simpson. Hill is the new starting halfback of the Cowboys, one of pro football's powerhouse teams, and he has shown skills that leave one breathless.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Unless President Nixon is much more different from most of his countrymen than he has led anyone to suspect, he has come back from vacation with a satchel full of snapshots. They are in color and are mounted as slides.

For one reason or another, usually meteorological, the Harkness Youth Dancers were not able to present all ballets as scheduled last week during their official debut. Last night the new company gave a full program in Central Park's Delacorte Theater, repeating some of the previous works and adding two, Robert Scevers's "Nocturne" and Luigi's "Jazz Mission."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 15 -- A $28-million "gamble" to grab the major share of an anticipated boom in world demand for uranium has been announced in South Africa -- the world's largest producer of the nuclear fuel.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday in moderate trading.

AMONG other things, the fight for first place between the New York Mets and the Chicago Cubs is probably the most lettered pennant race so far -- lettered in the sense of signs painted and displayed by the fans of the two clubs.

TWISTE, West Germany, Sept. 11 -- West Germany's 160,000-man army is about to undergo a major reorganization, shifting from more or less offensive strategy and equipment toward a defensive concept, according to its commander, Lieut. Gen. Albert Schnez.

A private collection of American art covering the last half century and estimated to be worth $4-million to $7-million was deeded to the State University of New York yesterday by Mr. and Mrs. Roy R. Neuberger.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- Secretary General Thant announced at the start of the Security Council session today that measures had been taken to protect some members against personal harm.

HE could be fresh from a youth insurrection anywhere in the Western world in his rib-tight brown sweater and brown corduroy pants. His brown hair waves around his neck, and his eyes, intensely blue against his olive complexion, have a zealot's gleam.

" It's a little jewel in the heart of the city," said Martin Lang, director of the city's Bureau of Water Pollution Control, as he looked out at Jamaica Bay from a motorboat slicing through waters murky with pollution.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept 15 (AP) -- Syria inaugurated today her international airport, terming it "the biggest and most modern" in the Middle East.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, attacked Mayor Lindsay yesterday as an "egocentric man," who used "slander" and the "big lie" to protect his political career.
It was interesting to learn that the Post Office Department is testing the delivery of mail. Service certainly could be improved.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Budget Bureau announced stiff guidelines today for the 75 per cent construction cutback President Nixon ordered Sept. 4. The bureau also warned the states indirectly to go along or risk reduced Federal aid.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -President Nixon will announce the second stage of American troop withdrawals from South Vietnam tomorrow morning, the White House said today.

NO doubt the greatest woman player the game has seen was Helen Sobel, who died last week in Detroit at the age of 59. During the nineteen-forties and the nineteen-fifties, mainly as the partner of Charles Goren, she put together a string of victories in national competitions that hardly any of the male experts could equal.
Agribusiness Fund, Inc., announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement here covering the sale of a new type of mutual fund to residents of New York State.

MONTREAL, Sept. 15 (AP) -Ron Fairly drove in four runs with a home run and pair of doubles and John Bateman hit a two-run homer as the Montreal Expos walloped the Chicago Cubs, 8-2, tonight behind Mike Wegener's three-hitter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- The Defense Department told the armed forces today to allow protest within their ranks unless it interfered with morale, discipline or military "effectiveness."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- Brazil's top military men met in secret today to choose a successor to President Arthur da Costa e Silva, who suffered a stroke earlier this month. His physicians have since recommended complete rest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A group of House Democratic liberals said today that they would try to persuade their colleagues to adopt a legislative program on which a Democratic record for the 1970 elections could be based.

CAIRO, Sept. 15 -- The semiofficial Egyptian newspaper Al Ahram urged Palestinian organizations today to call on Arab states to welcome any Arab Jews who want to return from Israel to their former homes in Arab lands.

John Nuveen Co., the beleaguered investment banking firm, was sold yesterday to Investors Diversified Services, the nation's largest mutual-fund management concern. The purchase was expected to permit Nuveen Co. to continue to do business.
The Continental Can Company announced yesterday that it had signed contracts with six major beverage companies to install can-making operations at 10 of their canning plants.

" DEATH and vulgarity," said Oscar Wilde, "are the only two facts in the 19th century that one cannot explain away." Which perhaps accounts for the invention of the modern mystery novel in that same century: "The tale of ratiocination" explains away death by superimposing a logical pattern.

The president of the United Electrical Workers said yesterday that workers at the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation were determined to make up their losses in real wages by obtaining a contract provision for cost-of-living adjustments.
Dennis McLain won't win 30 games this season, but Detroit's young right - hander showed last night at Yankee Stadium that he was still one of baseball's consummate performers.

For college students in need of financial assistance, the road to a loan has become a chaotic obstacle course. The current realities are a long way from the promises made three years ago when -- in an effort to shift the loan burden from the Federal Treasury to commercial money lenders -- bankers were depicted as the benevolent supporters of youths in search of higher education.

THE girl was slim and blond, and she said her name was Rainbow. The boy at her side was 'Shadow, and they laughed easily together as they strolled hand-in-hand over the grassy, sun-drenched mini-hills of Central Park.
BOSTON, Sept. 15 -- Barbara Harris is back in town.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, said today that a Life magazine contention that he had received an extraordinarily high payment for land condemned by South Carolina was a "liberal smear" intended to undermine his influence in Washington.
The United States Court of Appeals yesterday held that an insurance company had acted in bad faith when it failed to tell a policyholder that it had been offered a settlement in a negligence case.

The increasing degradation of the earth environment is due in part to a deficient accounting system. A pure environment accounting system would put a monetary value on such crimes as the murder of Lake Erie, and would make it possible for society to find out the price of using chemical fertilizers and allowing steel mills to discharge waste into rivers.

TORONTO, Sept. 15 -- The Economic Council of Canada said today that with luck and the right policies, Canada's standard of living could make an "astonishingly large" jump of nearly one-third in the next five years.

News of a $96-million surplus in Britain's trade balance for August spurred a wideranging advance in prices yesterday on the London stock market.
DETROIT, Sept. 15 -- The Ford Motor Company's PhilcoFord Division is getting out of the home-laundry, kitchen-range and dishwasher business.

Monthly steel production by the basic oxygen process has for the first time overtaken the long-dominant open hearth method, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The fund drive of the New York March of Dimes will open Oct. 20 at the 15th annual luncheon and fashion show of the Nelson Rosenthal Group, an organization named in memory of a young polio victim.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- Municipal Judge Earl Warren Jr., held court in a saloon here today to give the jury a close look at a naked dancing girl.

Salvatore William Bonanno, son of Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno, the former Mafia leader, was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on a charge of unlawfully concealing assets to keep them from the Internal Revenue Service.

Debbie Reynolds, who on Tuesday night made her debut in "Here's Debbie," notified the National Broadcasting Company last night that she regarded her contract as having been breached by inclusion of a commercial for Pall Mall cigarettes.
ABILENE, KAN., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower slipped quietly into Abilene today to spend a few minutes at the grave of her husband, the former President.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -- Two prominent bankers predicted via a new medium today that the next move in interest rates would be downward. Gaylord A. Freeman, chairman of the First National Bank of Chicago, said he was not as confident as he had been earlier that the prime rate would drop to 7 1/2 per cent from its present 8 1/2 level, but that some change could come by year end.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- The Presbytery of Chicago urged today an investigation, with a view to perjury charges, of testimony given last year before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations alleging immoral and illegal conduct at the First Presbyterian Church of Chicago in dealing with a Negro street gang.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 17 --- A Federal Court judge here upheld today a suburban school board's right to expel a 16-year-old high school pupil because the boy's hair style did not meet a rule that hair must stay "above the collar, over the ears and above the eyes."

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- North Vietnamese diplomats showed photographs of bombing victims to the wives of fourmissing American fliers today, then promised to try to let them know what had happened to their husbands.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Nixon disclosed today that he would send Congress a message next week asking for a 10 per cent increase in Social Security benefits, effective next April 1.
David L. Cole, mediator in the Metropolitan Opera dispute, expressed concern yesterday over the possibility of losing the entire season unless differences were speedily resolved.

The RCA Corporation disclosed yesterday that it was working on a robot sailboat that could navigate to any point at sea, remain there unattended for as much as a year, and return home on command sent by radio.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 17 -It's been a long time since Lehigh has had a winning football season and the Engineers hardly needed additional preseason problems such as the heavy attack of influenza that swept the team the last few weeks. But then maybe they are getting used to football's troublesome ways.
KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 17 -- The Rangers started playing hockey for money today -$5 a man.
Two major New York bank holding companies announced yesterday an agreement they hope will allow both of them to break into the fast-growing banking market in Rochester.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 17. -- Another small increase in Texas oil production was authorized by the Texas Railroad Commission today after its monthly proration hearing.

Every recent development involving the European Economic Community underscores the fact that Gaullism did not die with the General's abrupt departure from the Elysee in April. It will take a long time for the dedicated "Europeans" to regain the momentum toward unity they once had developed -- if, indeed, they are ever able to do so.

BONN, Sept. 17 -- Violence erupted in the election campaign in West Germany late last night when two young men were shot and wounded during a demonstration in Kassel against Adolf von Thadden, leader of the controversial, right-wing National Democratic party.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- More than 200 young squatters, many in need of shoes and soap -- who are occupying a stately four-story Georgian mansion in Mayfair, today ignored a court order requiring them to leave.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -The Executive Council voted today to grant stays of execution for 15 months to four condemned prisoners on death row at Walpole State Prison. Their present respites are due to expire in 13 days.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -The Chrysler Corporation agreed today to consider discontinuing an often-criticized advertising practice that it had engaged in for 30 years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -The Nixon Administration reaffirmed today its determination to hold Government spending this year to a maximum of $192.9-billion, but its revised budget figures showed that estimated Government tax collections were dwindling somewhat.

A total of 1,800 city children took part in the 1969 summer Head Start program operated by the Roman Catholic Archdiocesan Department of Education in cooperation with New York Catholic Charities, the department announced yesterday.
The United States Court of Appeals refused yesterday to delay the bribery-conspiracy trial of Roy M. Cohn and three others set to start Tuesday in Federal District Court.

Both Mayor Lindsay's administration and Controller Mario A. Procaccino charged in briefs filed in the Appellate Division yesterday that a 43.3 per cent average Blue Cross rate increase would disrupt legislative efforts to hold down soaring hospital costs.

MONTREAL, Sept. 17 -- The saga of the New York Mets was enhanced tonight by a three-city airlift that rushed the team's stock of baseball bats to Montreal just in time for a three-run rally against the Expos.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 17 -- The massive granite castle, with its tower, marble hall and magnificent oak staircase, has stood on Bellevue Avenue for more than a century, a monument of the dignity of bygone eras.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 -- The St. Louis Cardinals, who have three healthy quarterbacks, open the National Football League season on Sunday in Dallas, where the Cowboys have the injured Craig Morton plus two rookies, Roger Staubach and Bob Belden. The Cardinal quarterbacks are Charlie Johnson, who will start; Jim Hart, and the recently acquired King Hill.

In India, where a man's impression upon life can be erased as casually as sun and wind destroy the growing seeds, an American woman with alphabets, books and slates has upset a tradition thousands of years old.
Prices of United States Treasury securities sank yesterday as the market adjusted to terms of the Government's refunding operation, announced late on Wednesday.
A decline m Interest rates this year or early in 1970 was predicted yesterday by economists and bankers at a seminar on money markets at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.
A suspicious fire that swept rapidly through a three-story Brooklyn tenement early yesterday morning killed one woman and five children.

The Federal Reserve System appears to have tightened credit significantly in the last month or so, just when signs are starting to appear that inflationary pressure in the economy is finally beginning to cool.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Senate Finance Committee, at a secret meeting yesterday, voted approval of one of the major items in the tax reform bill. Ironically, by that very action it set the stage for possible postponement into next year of any Senate vote on the rest of the reform bill.
PARIS, Sept. 18 -- Negotiators for North Vietnam and the Vietcong heaped scorn today on President Nixon's announced withdrawal of more American troops.

Small bands of antiwar demonstrators turned out at the United Nations and the Waldorf Astoria Hotel yesterday to picket President Nixon, while others were promising an autumn of large-scale protests against his Vietnam policies.
Some city streets are dirty because some sanitationmen are cheating on the job: They are trucking the same garbage out of city dumps that they truck into them.
This morning, granted fair weather and efficient water pumps, Mayor Lindsay will hold his weekly cabinet meeting in Brooklyn's Prospect Park, next to three new water fountains.

Advanced European techniques of prefabricating high-rise housing are expected to be introduced in the United States soon by at least half a dozen engineering concerns from England, France, Italy, Denmark, Sweden and West Germany.
The stock market forged ahead slightly yesterday, fueled partly by hopes of a cut in the prime rate before yearend and partly in expectation of the latest short-interest figures.
Short-interest positions on the New York Stock Exchange as of the Sept. 15 settlement date increased for the second consecutive month, the exchange reported yesterday.
Prices were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday on the 2American Stock Exchange.
" You may say we're encouraged," a Lindsay man said yesterday.

Charging that Fifth Avenue merchants would lose "thousands of dollars in sales," the Fifth Avenue Association has asked the Police Commissioner to reroute the Oct. 11 United Hispanic American parade onto the Avenue of the Americas.

AREA A -- Northeastern winds bringing rain and turbulent waves have recently cut fishing off the New Jersey coast to "virtually zero," according to John Falkiewicz at Surf City, N. J. The rough seas are expected to subside for the weekend.

VIENNA, Sept. 18 -- The armed forces of the Soviet Union, Poland, East Germany and Czechoslovakia will participate in joint exercises on Polish territory at the end of this month, it was announced today.

A plan to provide $2-billion for mass transit -- half of it to go to New York, half to New Jersey -- was suggested yesterday by the chairman of the Mayor's Committee to Help Save the 20-cent Subway Fare.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The first Federal appropriation looking toward the construction of a railway and highway transportation system in Alaska's mineral and oil-rich far north was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- President Nixon is about to name a Presidential commission, headed by one of his old law partners, to study the extent to which the Federal tax structure may be too burdensome on business and to make recommendations for changes.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A documentary film on pollution of Lake Erie, produced by the National Broadcasting Company, allegedly used portions of an educational film on pollution of Germany's Rhine River.

The New York Jets' game against the Boston Patriots scheduled for Shea Stadium on Oct. 5 has been shifted to Boston College Alumni Field, it was announced yesterday by Milt Woodard, president of the American Football League.
DETROIT, Sept. 18 -- The Chrysler Corporation today joined the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company in raising new prices more than $100 a car.

Soviet and United States negotiators resumed discussions on Middle East tensions yesterday, aiming to isolate specific issues on which Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, might make progress when they meet next week.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18 -- It is not true, as you might have begun to suspect, that there really is only one American cultural center, a portable structure that is crated up and shipped to city after city, complete with dignitaries and journalists, just in time for the next festive opening.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 18 -- Two Marine regiments stationed along the demilitarized zone and an Army airborne brigade assigned to guard Saigon will make up the combat contingent of troops to be withdrawn from South Vietnam by Dec. 15, United States spokesmen announced here today.
An off-duty patrolman tried in vain early yesterday to rescue a 36-year-old postal worker who was shot and killed in the lobby of a Bronx apartment building.

The proposals of Theodore Kheel to impose auto tolls on bridges and of others radically to restrict the use of the auto in midtown Manhattan, imply that the transit system is now capable of absorbing the added load.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., the conglomerate with interests in the entertainment, agricultural, automotive and other industries, announced last night a series of transactions with Philip J. Levin, a director, that will eventually give Mr. Levin control of its real estate subsidiary.
OTTAWA, Sept. 18 -- Mitchell Sharp, Minister of External Affairs, said today that "Canada welcomes the use of the Arctic waters as a transportation route for vessels of all flags."

IT'S Istanbul, not Constantinople, and the lady in question lives in Budapest anyway. The Socialist Workers party was removed yesterday from the ballot in the citywide November elections when the Board of Elections ruled that most of the signatures on its petition were invalid.

BONN, Sept. 18 -- Wildcat strikes broke out today among West Germany's 1.2 million several thousands of West Germany's 1.2 million public service employes, causing both major political parties to interrupt election campaign tours.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Senator John Sherman Cooper called today for an investigation by the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees to determine whether American forces were already committed to combat in Laos.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 -- The state's Urban Development Corporation has offered to help finance and plan community facilities at the site of the proposed state office building in Harlem in an effort to break through opposition that since June has held up construction on a planned $20-million office tower.

Management of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., has decided not to make any recommendations whether shareholders should tender their shares in response to Kirk Kerkorian's latest tender offer for more M-G-M shares.

A New York Telephone Company executive, conceding that there were "service problems" in the metropolitan area, told a Public Service Commission hearing yesterday that the company was prepared to spend $10-billion over the next 10 years to improve service.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 18 -- The army was in control of all strategic areas in Rosario, Argentina's second largest city, today following two days of rioting, in which two persons were killed. The rioting stems from a railroad strike.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The panel on Take-overs and Mergers tonight rejected an appeal by Robert Maxwell, chairman of Pergamon Press, Ltd., of some of its findings against him in the Leasco Data Processing Equipment Corporation's bid to control Pergamon.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 18 -- Following are excerpts from an interim report of the long-range study committee of Harvard University's Board of Overseers, made public today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- An official of the American Bar Association declared today that there was no conflict of interest in the participation of Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. in a controversial labor case in 1963.

INGMAR BERGMAN'S "The Ritual," which was shown last night at the New York Film Festival and will be repeated on Saturday afternoon, is one of the director's most personal and self-indulgent works, an attempt to exorcise the artist's fears of his own irrelevancy while also satirizing those people to whom he is irrelevant.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Following is the text of the proposed constitutional amendment approved today by the House of Representatives that would abolish the Electoral College and provide for the election of the President by popular vote:
A neat, well-dressed 18-year-old black youth leaned against the door of a Y.M.H.A. in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning.

President Nixon's maiden speech to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday was, in the main, a defensive reiteration of old American policies on the great issues that confront this 24th session. It was disappointingly lacking in concrete new proposals that would indicate that the United States, at least, is prepared to try harder to help the U.N. work more effectively for peace.

SAIGON, South Vietnem, Sept. 18 -- The Army announced tonight that it would try six of the eight Special Forces soldiers who were arrested two months ago in connection with the alleged murder of a Vietnamese agent.

There were no easy answers to that question on last night's fascinating exploration of man's perennial struggle with his environment on the television network of the Columbia Broadcasting System. The saga of Suzie Wong, the golden-hearted, pure-souled, prostitute, first told in book form then later as a play and next as a film, is being transformed into a musical.
A member of the Securities and Exchange Commission took aim here yesterday at the obscure jargon in prospectuses submitted to the Government for review.
The aviation industry is more upset than it has been for a long time because of the recent mid-air collision near Indianapolis in which 83 persons were killed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A House committee cleared the way today for final passage this fall of what seems certain to be the strongest coal mine health and safety bill ever enacted by Congress.
The New York City Ballet has warned some of its subscribers that failure to reach agreement in labor contract talks with its orchestra might result in cancellation of all or part of its season.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino attacked the Lindsay administration's record in housing yesterday and charged that the city was "suffering from the worst housing shortage in its history."

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y. -- Gallimaufry is defined as a hodgepodge, and a very pleasant hodgepodge indeed is the collection of four shops that bear this over-all name. They are in a shingle building in the parking lot opposite the Croton-Harmon railroad station.

The state Mental Hygiene Department is investigating the case of a 32-year-old patient at Brooklyn State Hospital whose disappearance last month was said not to have been reported to the police or to his parents until his father went to visit him four days later.

The staff of Mayor Lindsay's Commission on Inflation and Economic Welfare, appointed in late August, has made its first report -- a proposed Federal tax reform program that its says could provide the city with at least $240-million in extra revenue.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- An attorney representing four Chicago newspapers said late today he had worked out an agreement with Chief Federal Judge William J. Campbell modifying the judge's earlier order that barred cameras and recording devices in or near the Federal Building.
A team of city representatives began an inspection yesterday of subway car repair shops operated by the Transit Authority.
One securities salesman and two former salesmen were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to manipulate a stock on the American Stock Exchange in 1964.

Whether people in Israel pray, farm, marry, build settlements, sip coffee in cafes or make love or war, they're never very far from a camera. That's the impression given by "Israel: The Reality," a show on what may be the world's most thoroughly-photographed young country, opening today at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 18 -- A Harvard University Overseers' report, made public today, has found students and many professors unhappy over the quality of the university's teaching and its relevance to the world outside.
City inspectors found yesterday that violations of the Federal truth-in-lending law among furniture dealers in Harlem were as common there as 18 per cent annual interest rates.
The Board of Estimate was persuaded yesterday to delay action on a West Side urban renewal project for five weeks.

" Acts," a feature-length, factual color film drama about the work and conflict between the minister of the Washington Square Church and his arts consultant, is nearing completion after more than a year's work. It is slated to be released to theaters this winter.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- An elevated train rammed the rear of another Chicago Transit Authority train tonight on the South Side, derailing one car and sending 249 persons to hospitals.

The Board of Education announced yesterday that "a modest increase" of 10 cents a day in the price of school lunches for pupils would go into effect Monday, Oct. 6, but that free lunches would still be served to those who qualified for them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- After eight weeks of debate, the Senate completed action this evening on a military authorization bill that may mark a postwar turning point in the relationship between the Pentagon and Congress and in the nation's strategic plans and foreign commitments.
SAIGON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- United States, South Viet namese and enemy battle deaths increased slightly last week, it was reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The House of Representatives approved overwhelmingly today the first major change in 165 years in the nation's system of choosing its President.
Artists who had never met a corporation head and company executives, most of whom had never spoken to an artist, met yesterday in the Savoy Room of the Plaza Hotel.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had approved a series of rules changes to permit public ownership of securities of member corporations.
The president of the Real Estate Board of New York said yesterday that private construction in the city had been halted by the Federal tax reforms now pending in Congress.
Jack Hiatt has lost 31 pounds and a lot of points on his batting average this season.

Fred Papert, the boss of Papert, Koenig, Lois, is convinced that his agency lost three clients with a total of $24-million in billings so far this year because of P. K. L.'s well-publicized attempts to diversify.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- In conjunction with President Nixon's appeal to the United Nations to help stop airline hijacking, the State Department announced today that it was making new efforts to extradite hijackers from nations in which they may take refuge.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 18 -- Rhodesian troops and police swept into a mountainous district along the Mozambique border at dawn today and evicted the rebellious Tangwena tribe from its ancestral homeland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor said today that he had rejected strong pressures to remove the Green Berets case from the jurisdiction of the military command in Saigon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Mike Ryan's eighth-inning single scored Larry Hisle, a pinch-runner, with the tie-breaking run and set up an insurance run as well today in a 5-3 triumph for the Philadelphia Phillies over the Chicago Cubs.

The Long Island Rail Road's phantom train -- the 7:55 A.M. from Babylon to Brooklyn, which has not run since June 12 -- will probably be restored to service within a week, a railroad official said yesterday.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 18 -- The loss of Lew Alcindor to the Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association in the bidding war last May is felt with every workout by the New York Nets.

Higher fines for gypsy cabs that operate illegally by cruising for fares were urged yesterday by Mayor Lindsay. Enforcement, he said, "is handicapped by imposition of low fines, frequently $5 or $10."
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 18 -- Dancing Flower, one of three starters in the race who didn't break stride, won the $30,328.97 Proximity Trot tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
Mayor Lindsay declared in his third annual report on his administration yesterday that his efforts had "begun to show positive results across the entire spectrum of city government."

Mr. Goldman likes to take things apart to see how they work. So when he (or somebody) came up with the idea for "The Season," it was perfect for William Goldman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A faction on the District of Columbia Board of Education is pushing Rhody A. McCoy, administrator of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville Demonstration School District in Brooklyn, for the job of Superintendent of Schools in the nation's capital.

An antitrust suit charging "harmful control" of thoroughbred racing was filed in Federal Court here yesterday against the New York Racing Association, The Jockey Club and two horse-breeding magazines. Also named in the suit were the directors of the various organizations cited.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 -- Ilie Nastase and Arthur Ashe were drawn today for the opening singles match in the Davis Cup challenge round between Rumania and the United States starting tomorrow.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 -- The Cleveland Browns open their National Football League season in Philadelphia against the Eagles on Sunday with two rookies starting in the defensive backfield. They are Walt Sumner at cornerback and Freddie Summers at safety and they are replacing the injured Ben Davis and Ernie Kellermann.
The arrest of 20 welfare recipients on charges of concealing assets and income was announced yesterday by the city's Commissioner of Investigation, Robert K. Ruskin.

TRENTON, Sept. 18 -- A Superior Court judge ruled today that the State Commission of Investigation had the constitutional power to jail reputed Mafia figures who refused to testify at closed hearings on organized crime and official corruption.
MONTREAL, Sept. 18 -- Tom Seaver pitched the New York Mets one step closer to ecstasy tonight when he overpowered the Montreal Expos, 2-0, and moved his team five games in front with only 13 to play.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Federal District Judge James B. Parsons has ordered a suburban high school to readmit a 17-year-old boy it had suspended because of his long hair and short mustache.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 18 -- Laverne Hanover, the extraordinary 3-year-old colt owned by Thomas W. Murphy Jr. of New York, captured the annual Little Brown Jug today.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 18 -- Lawyers for a former Peace Corps volunteer, who has allegedly declared he would go to jail rather than serve in the armed forces, continued today in United States District Court to seek to clarify dates in his Selective Service record.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Col. Dale J. Crittenberger, a United States Army brigade commander and the son of a noted World War II general, was killed in a helicopter collision in the Mekong Delta, the Army announced today.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 18 -- The first major decision of the Alex Webster regime was evident today when Tucker Frederickson and Ernie Koy, friends and hard-running backs, lined up in the same backfield.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 18 (AP) -- A hearing on a request for an autopsy on Mary Jo Kopechne was ordered today after District Attorney Edmund Dinis of Massachusetts said blood was in her mouth and nose when she was found dead in Senator Edward M. Kennedy's car.
KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 18 -- "Me give Brad advice?" asked Brad Park's father today. "I keep my mouth shut."

SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 18 -- After a surprising British team had taken a 3-point lead in the morning foursomes, the United States rallied on the last hole in the afternoon matches to come within a point of the leaders, 4 1/2-3 1/2, today as the biennial Ryder Cup series opened.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (Reuters) -- The American Medical Association recommended today changing Federal drug control laws to permit medical treatment rather than prison terms for drug addicts, at the discretion of the courts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A National Academy of Sciences Report, to be released tomorrow, says that a jetport could be built north of the Florida Everglades without destroying the huge wilderness park, but only after a number of technological problems were solved.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 18 -- In response to urgings for a Board of Trustees more representative of contemporary society, Stanford University announced today a revision of its governmental structure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- State Department and Arms Control and Disarmament Agency officials were thrown into confusion this morning by President Nixon's statement to the United Nations on the limitation of chemical and bacteriological weapons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A reporter, who until last month was an assistant to Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, has charged that the Nixon Administration's abrupt turn-around on Mississippi school desegregation was forced by pressure from the Senator.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The man who has been the voice of the country's home-builders has now been chosen by President Nixon to deal with them as Federal Housing Commissioner.

The temperature fell into the low 60's yesterday, not the best kind of weather for Joe Namath's aching knees, but the New York Jet quarterback worked a full hour and a half with the offense at the Rikers Island training field.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange eased yesterday but losses were cut by a moderate rally near the close.

HONG KONG, Sept. 18 -- The Chinese Communist Government expressed defiance today of the atomic power of the Soviet Union and the United States and said aggression against China by either power or both not only would be wiped out but would be met with a worldwide revolutionary war that would "overthrow U. S. imperialism.

ATHENS, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Nicole Duclos of France came through in her very last stride tonight to defeat her teammate, Colette Besson, the Olympic champion, and win the women's 400-meter run at the European track and field championships.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- President Nixon appealed to the member countries of the United Nations today for diplomatic assistance in bringing about peace in Vietnam.

One thousand junior and senior high school students in the New York area have been chosen as winners of the 1969-70 Lincoln Center Student Awards. They will each attend five performances at Lincoln Center -- two concerts by the New York Philharmonic and one performance each by the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center, the New York City Ballet and the New York City Opera.

THE television networks bided their time yesterday in responding to reports that the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence had established a direct relationship between televised violence and real-life violence, something heretofore believed to be beyond the reach of convincing research.
Trading picked up slightly and so did prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
The New York Telephone Company told the Public Service Commission yesterday that inexperienced employes were the key cause of deficient operator service.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Policemen and terrorists fought a gun battle outside the United States consulate today and two policemen were wounded. The police said that a fire bomb had been thrown in a patrol car but that the consulate had not been damaged.

In its present form, the delegatory system of the United States is an instrument of expedience rather than an institution of the people. It is a cumbersome and unnecessary middleman between the people and the potency of their votes. That situation should be changed now, while the excitement of the political campaign is not present to serve as a distraction -- while the change will be for the people, not for any particular candidate.
The click of a mallet against a wooden ball has not been heard this summer on the Ramble in Central Park.
Selected glamour stocks enjoyed a field day yesterday, reflecting purchases by mutual funds and other institutions, as the general market edged slightly higher.

" BOY," a Japanese film shown last night at the New York Film Festival, dramatically elaborates a true case history, that of a family adept at faking injuries by cars -- a cunning spill to the pavement, a mention of the police at the hospital -- and raking in quick pay-offs from anxious motorists.
The executive director of an antipoverty agency on Staten Island has resigned after admitting that he had misappropriated about $1,000, the City Community Development Agency said yesterday.

PETER LUKE, the author of "Hadrian VII," once remonstrated with those reviewers who said, or at least hinted, that he had written a merely indifferent play that had been carried to glory by the virtuoso performance in the title role of Alec McCowen.

Several hundred thousand Conservative party supporters over the country have been asked to join the Retire John Lindsay Club and to donate money to Senator John J. Marchi's campaign for Mayor so that "John Lindsay's dream of capturing the Republican party and winning the White House for the ultra liberals will be finished."
Your editorial "Setbacks to Peace in Nigeria," Sept. 16, has more relevance in boosting the public posture of Nigeria than stating the true facts to your readers.
TOKYO, Sept. 19 -- Coca-Cola is finding the going somewhat sticky in Japan these days.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Mike Torrez scattered seven hits today for his eighth straight victory in pitching the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-2 victory over Chicago and a double-header split after the Cubs took the opener, 2-1, on Jim Hickman's disputed ground-rule double in the 10th inning.

Nearly three years after the "truth in packaging" law was signed by President Johnson, its effects are showing up in supermarkets in the form of Federal Trade Commission regulations. Shoppers are no longer assailed with such unintelligible descriptives on labels as "jumbo" or "king-sized," but that still leaves them with much less information than they need to make value comparisons of the items they want to buy.

DURANGO, Colo. -- Standing like a huge unanswered question, a giant pile of finely ground gray leftovers from a uranium mill confronts the business district of this Old West tourist town from across the Animas River.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Senate, weary after 2 1/2 months of debating military spending, quickly passed a $3.7-billion space authorization today after brief skirmishes around the issue of the program's future.

Although Princeton and Rutgers, the teams that started it all 100 years ago, do not meet until next week, college football's centennial season opens today with several outstanding games on the schedule.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Hank Bauer was dismissed as manager of the Oakland Athletics tonight and replaced by one of his coaches, John McNamara.

The people who live in the Two Bridges Model School District on the Lower East Side -- the Lopezes, the Wongs, the Spadaforas and many of their neighbors -- went to the polls on Thursday to vote on the local school board.

If you haven't already bought a ticket for today's Grambling-Morgan State game in Yankee Stadium, you'll get your best view of the two teams in the second annual charity Invitation Football Classic tonight on Channel 11 at 11:30 when the game will be shown on tape.

ROME, Sept. 19 -- Alitalia, Italy's state-controlled international airline, announced today that it was planning to break an international rate agreement by offering a $299 round-trip fare for tourist-class passengers between Rome and New York -- the lowest ever.

BOWMANVILLE, Ontario, Sept. 19 -- Jackie Stewart, the long-haired mod Scot who already has wrapped up the world driving championship, will try tomorrow to tie the late Jim Clark's record of seven Grand Prix victories in one season.

A city official leading a team inspecting subway-repair shops praised the workmanship and the cleanliness of the shops yesterday, but he added that there was a need of expanded maintenance training to end a personnel shortage.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A national conference on the arts, sponsored by the National Endowment for the Arts, concluded a three-day meeting today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 19 -- This season's crop of 2-year-old trotters has failed to produce a single 2-minute performance. However, some especially promising juveniles will go postward in tomorrow night's $90,986.86 Westbury Futurity at Roosevelt Raceway.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 -- Just when the New York Yankees were entertaining thoughts of overhauling the Washington Senators for fourth place in the American League's Eastern Division, they found themselves overmatched tonight against the division champions, the Orioles, and lost a 4-2 decision before 9,223 chilled fans.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Nixon expressed disappointment today over the slow pace on his legislative proposals.

Tht three major party candidates for Controller called yesterday for legislation to enable the city to tax real estate owned by the Federal and State Governments and such nonprofit organizations as professional societies and private clubs.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 19 -- India is considering raising the level of her relations with North Vietnam from consulate to ambassadorial and establishing some kind of official link with the provisional revolutionary government created by the Vietcong in South Vietnam, officials disclosed today.
In a Sept. 5 letter a tenant erroneously complained that month-to-month tenants were not afforded protection against gouging under the Rent Stabilization Law.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A peace offensive, Johnson-style, meant two dozen senior officials racing around the globe parading good intentions, the Pentagon proving the inevitability of victory on its charts and the State Department running up its antenna to catch the faintest groan of weakness in the enemy camp.

The five justices of the Appellate Division in Manhattan heard arguments yesterday on an attempt by Blue Cross to reinstate a proposed 43.3 per cent average rate increase, which was blocked temporarily by a lower court two weeks ago.

Plans for a $97-million petrochemical complex in the Netherlands were announced yesterday by the Royal Dutch-Shell Group of oil companies and Dutch State Mines, a chemical company owned by the Netherlands Government.
THE National Football League's 50th season begins tomorrow with eight games, one matching two of the most powerful teams -- the Rams and the Colts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Senator Stuart Symington announced today that the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on foreign commitments was already investigating the extent of United States military involvement in Laos.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Following, in translation from the Russian, are excerpts from the speech in the General Assembly today by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union:

A major business group warned yesterday that nations cannot regard "paper gold" and other measures to bolster the world monetary system as a cure-all for ills caused by inflation or domestic policies detrimental to other countries.

Prodded by their students and the threat of renewed tumult on the campus, college presidents have been urging President Nixon for some time to reform the military draft system drastically or abolish it altogether. With the new academic year, the President has decided to shift the prod to Congress in much more energetic fashion than he has up to now.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Secretary General Thant told the United Nations today that he felt that "time is running out" for efforts to save world peace. He suggested that the decade of the 1970's be dedicated as the "disarmament decade," in which extra efforts should be made to bring the arms race under control and end it.

A SOFT documentary on "A Matter of Conscience: Ethics in Government" was presented last night as a special on the network of the American Broadcasting Company. After the unparalleled instance of a Supreme Court Justice resigning under fire for a conflict of interest, A.B.C. analyzed the recurring problem with a gentleness hardly befitting the issue.

The economy is now at the point where tight money is beginning to force the private sector to adjust downward some of its excessive demands for goods and services, a leading Wall Street economist said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The crash of an airliner near Cincinnati in 1967 in which 70 persons were killed probably stemmed from an attempted night landing with poor visibility, inadequate landing aids on the ground and insufficient altitude cross-checks by the crew, the National Transportation Safety Board ruled today.

NEWARK, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- A Federal judge refused today to allow the New Jersey State branch of the American Civil Liberties Union to start contempt proceedings against the commanding general of Fort Dix for allegedly failing to release a conscientious objector as ordered by a court.
Bobby Bonds might have himself convinced that he's not a home-run hitter, but he can't get anyone else to believe him.

That dangerous ambush by the Pittsburgh Pirates, so nervously foreseen by the more jittery New York Met followers, actually took place at Shea Stadium last night before more than 50,000 people. But despite the loss of two games, 8-2 and 8-0, the Mets actually moved closer to clinching first place in the National League East.

A group of Wall Street brokers and other businessmen had a taste of some of the more advanced styles in men's apparel this week and their over-all reaction was similar to that of many of those downtown to the current stock market: cautious watching and waiting.

The London stock market extended its late rally of Thursday, yesterday with further moderate gains.

The New York Stock Exchange is suffering from lower volume this year, but the commodity exchanges generally are doing well. Volume of futures contracts traded from January through August totaled 7,132,521 contracts, 21 per cent ahead of the same 1968 period, according to John W. Clagett, president of the Association of Commodity Exchange Firms, Inc.
