SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 -- Miss Angela Davis, an acknowledged member of the Communist party, was dismissed today from her post as acting assistant professor of philosophy on the Los Angeles campus of the University of California.

BONN, Sept. 19 -- A high Western source disclosed today that the Soviet Union had retreated from its maximum demands on West Germany and West Berlin in notes to Bonn and the three Western allied powers last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Discussions with informed Government and Congressional sources here indicate that none of the nuclear powers, except Britain, has shown any recent interest in making a reality of the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear arms. Only Britain has completed ratification.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A document prepared by a Department of Transportation staff member severely criticizes the department's activities and abilities with regard to the transportation of hazardous materials.

OTTAWA, Sept. 19 -- Canada announced today that she would reduce her military forces in Europe from 9,800 men to 5,000 men and would equip them only with non-nuclear weapons.

Dick Cavett walked up the back stairs of the American Broadcasting Company's Studio 15 on West 58th Street, unlocked the door to his tiny, recently refurbished dressing suite, walked inside, and sniffed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The White House announced today that the Apollo 11 astronauts would make a 22-nation tour starting Sept. 29 to stress United States willingness to share its space knowledge.

Shareholders of American Metal Climax, Inc., and the Ayrshire Collieries Corporation, at separate meetings yesterday, approved the previously proposed merger of Ayrshire into Amax. It will be effective Oct. 31.
Two teen-agers were held without bail yesterday in the Bronx in connection with the death of an 85-year-old woman they allegedly suspected of telling the police that they had committed burglary.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- "In all candor," a Senate leader said, "I just don't think much about Europe except in connection with a cut in our troop strength there."
A strange group of men was sighted in midtown Manhattan yesterday, peering at the tall buildings and wondering which way to Yankee Stadium.

The new-issue market -- where shares of companies that have never had public owners are traded -- has regained a measure of the buoyancy it enjoyed last spring. This is evident from the number of companies that went public this week with fully registered offerings (16), the trading volume ("the heaviest in a long time") and sharp price gains in several issues.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Prospects faded today for Senate action on the Supreme Court nomination of Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. before the 1969 court term opens on Oct. 6.

SHIN-NI, South Korea, Sept. 17 -- "President Park is No. 1," said Lee Chin Hwa, a grizzled farmer picking red peppers in his plot near the highway from Seoul to Pusan. "I would vote for him," he added.

The search for a missing fur trader and his guide in the Amazonian jungles of Colombia has brought to light a tribe that seems to be living in the Stone Age and communicates in a tongue unlike any other known language.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The House voted $2-million today to go ahead with long-delayed plans for a $45-million rebuilding and extension of the crumbling west front of the Capitol.

ATHENS, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Ian Stewart, a British distance runner, and a quartet of West German girls stole the top honors at the European track and field championships today, but the Soviet Union and East Germany were tied in the race for gold medals, with eight each.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The International Monetary Fund announced today the details of the standby agreement with France permitting a drawing by France of up to $985-million in various currencies over the next year.

Many freshmen who registered for courses at Columbia University yesterday used a guide prepared by former students that graded their teachers more severely than they themselves may be judged after classes start on Thursday.
MIAMI, Sept. 19 -- The Cuban Government announced today that it had enacted a law under which persons who hijacked airplanes or boats to Cuba could be extradited to their country of origin.

Cigarette advertisements face a possible legal ban here in subways, buses and any "place of public assembly or public conveyance."

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 19 -- The nation's mining engineers hope to improve the image of an industry regarded in many quarters as a primary despoiler of the nation's natural resources and beauty. That mood was apparent today as the three-day Rocky Mountain Minerals Conference of the Society of Mining Engineers concluded formal sessions and 2,000 engineers, metallurgists minerals scientists and guests dispersed to tour nearby mines, mills and refineries.
Workers at more than 100 day-care centers that have been closed for three weeks voted approval yesterday of a new contract and made plans to return to work Monday.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Pat O'Neal in the Shields Class and Randy Bartholomew in the Etchelis 22 class launched quests for national sailing championships perfectly today. They both finished first in the two races of their respective events.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The trademark for an invention patented this week by Robert Brooks of New York is TUFI, meaning "this umbrella folds itself." As manufactured, it comes in three models -- for men, women and golfers.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Governor Rockefeller conceded tonight that New York State, as a whole, ranked far down the list among states in industrial growth. However, the Governor attributed the state's position to a lag in manufacturing employment in New York City.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The latest round of talks between Japan and the United States on the textile import problem concluded today, with the next move up to the Japanese.

Gromyko, addressing the General Assembly today, rebuffed President Nixon's suggestion of a big-power arms embargo in the Middle East and ignored the President's appeal to United Nations members for diplomatic assistance in ending the Vietnam war.

With its simple humors, embodied in the slapstick of its clowns, and its ability to make the physically impossible seem possible, summed up in its acrobats and conjurors, the circus combines good nature with the willing suspension of disbelief that Coleridge noted as a requirement of poetry.

Congress has voted to destroy the west front of the Capitol, a scheme proposed by the non-architect Architect of the Capitol. This will add another disaster to the long list he has perpetrated on the Hill, including the destruction of the East Front, and the horror of the Rayburn Building.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Grant B. Cooper, who defended Sirhan B. Sirhan, the convicted assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was fined $1,000 today for unlawfully possessing a secret grand jury transcript.
PARIS, Sept. 23 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle, out of power since last April, sees France descending from the heights to which he sought to lead her.
BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- Dick Williams, who in his first year as a major league manager in 1967 led the Boston Red Sox to their "miracle pennant," was dismissed today.
Share prices on the London stock market drifted easier over a wide front yesterday on lack of buying interest.
For two days, some 700,000 years ago, the flat-browed Java man looked into the sky and saw a glittering cloud plunging toward the earth.

The New York Advisory Committee of the Committee of European Shipowners has chosen Ib Alvin, who has represented Danish shipowners on the committee since 1964, as its new chairman. He succeeds the late George Harris.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Linda Kristine, a faithful member of the Bleacher Bums, observed her 23d birthday at Wrigley Field today, but the Cubs didn't join the celebration.
TWICE a year Ohrbach's prays its fifth floor with an intoxicating scent known as "Celebrity" and basks in euphoria.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 23 -Yasir Arafat, the top Palestinian guerrilla leader, reported today that guerrillas of Al Fatah were fighting against Israeli forces in the northern sector of the Jordan Valley in an attempt to prevent the Israelis from repairing what the Arabs regard as an important dam.
The Arches of Science Award, including a gold medal and $25,000, has been won by Gerard Piel, publisher of Scientific American.
Indian Head, Inc. reported record sales and profits yesterday for the third quarter and the nine-month period ended Aug. 30.
Corporate bond prices declined yesterday, and the yield on a new issue of triple-A utility bonds was set at 8.15 per cent, highest on record for such an investment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The first serious test of President Nixon's plan to turn the Post Office into a Government corporation bogged down today in parliamentary confusion, with neither side claiming victory.
ATLANTA, Sept. 23 (AP) -Sixteen Georgia school districts have gained an indefinite delay in the cutoff of Federal funds on the basis of a court decision.
Several persons identified by the police as Black Panthers entered some classrooms in a Washington Heights school yesterday and told pupils to go home.

CLIFTON, N.J., Sept. 23 -Former Gov. Robert B. Meyner, the Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, accused his Republican opponent of McCarthyism tonight in a campaign debate in which each man charged the other with conflicts of interest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. denied today that there was any impropriety in his purchase of stock in the Brunswick Corporation at a time when the company had a case pending before his court.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Joseph H. Blatchford, director of the Peace Corps, said at his first news conference today that "reports of the demise of the Peace Corps are greatly exaggerated."

As cooperative apartment house on Manhattan's fashionable East Side and a leading real estate agency were fined $1,000 yesterday by the city's Commission on Human Rights for discriminating against a Jewish lawyer.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept. 23 -- Dave DeBusschere's hulking 6-foot-6-inch frame registered 238 pounds today on the scale in the training room at the State University at Farmingdale.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -The managing director of the International Monetary Fund formally proposed today the creation of $9.5-billion of the new Special Drawing Rights or "paper gold" over the next three years -- a necessary first step before expected approval of the historic move at the Fund's annual meeting next week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Government filed a proposed antitrust settlement today under which the Scott Paper Company and Chemotronics, Inc., of Ann Arbor, Mich., would be forced to make available licenses for processing a type of porous plastic foam.

It is clear from the recent statements of President Nixon at the United Nations and Generals Thieu and Ky in Saigon that the United States and South Vietnamese Governments are now running into a serious crisis over their divergent objectives in the war.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- European currency markets were unsettled today by uncertainties surrounding the West German elections on Sunday. Foreignexchange dealers predicted mounting pressures as the week progresses.

BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 23 -Joe Sam Walker, convicted of murder in 1949 in the slaying of a University of Colorado coed, was ordered released from prison today after his conviction was reversed last month because of pretrial publicity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Andrew F. Brimmer, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, warned banks that sponsor credit cards today against excessively restrictive standards for participation in their creditcard systems.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -The head of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries expressed impatience today with Administration delays in coming forward with a new maritime program.

It is regrettable that the patients in the city's municipal hospitals continue to be forgotten even during election time. Recently the Mayor upgraded police, fire and sanitation services. WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The House ethics committee concluded today that last year's "ghost votes" in the House were not all accidental, although plenty of honest errors were made.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The White House said today that President Nixon was expected to appoint a new chairman for the Federal Trade Commission soon.
The controversy over what is happening to the city's welfare program rests on the fact that the rolls grew more than three times faster last year than this year.
A $4-million suit on behalf of Al Salerno and Bill Valentine, the two American League umpires dismissed abruptly two weeks before the 1968 season ended, was filed yesterday in Federal Court here.
MEN, you'd better make sure your chests are in good shape because you may soon be baring them in places where they've never been bared before.

The Madison Square Garden Corporation and the G. W. Land and Development Corporation, headed by Philip J. Levin, are locked in battle for control of Roosevelt Raceway.

Santa Fe Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it had signed a memorandum of intent with Dresser Industries, Inc., to consolidate the interests of the two companies.
TRENTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -The state today approved the purchase of 75 new passenger cars for the Erie Lackawanna Railroad at a cost of $12.5million.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 23 -- Plans to create a Latin-American traveler's check and a dollarbacked bond for the region are being pressed before the ninth annual meeting of heads of the area's central banks and finance ministries, who began a four-day conference here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The children of the late George Preston Marshall, who controlled 52 per cent of the stock of the Washington Redskins, gained an apparent victory when a United States District Court judge named the American Security and Trust Company as collector of Marshall's estate.
Suppliers to the city will have to pay all their employes at least $2.50 an hour under a law passed yesterday by the City Council. The law is effective Jan. 1.
WITH last night's return of the City Center Joffrey Ballet to its ancestral home at the New York City Center, the 1969-70 dance season may be considered to have started. And a very good start it was.
Silver futures advanced yesterday in another day of heavy trading. One impetus came from higher prices accepted for bids at the Government's weekly silver auctions yesterday in Washington.

Financier Kirk Kerkorian's tender offer for 620,000 shares of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., expired yesterday amid indications that it had been oversubscribed.

Exactly seven years after the day of its opening, the new Philharmonic Hall was unveiled last night. It has a new look, a new sound, and there was a feeling of success in the air. Both of the big powers voted for the resolution.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Every Administration sooner or later develops its badge of influence. There were PT-boat tie clasps under John F. Kennedy and the LBJ-brand cuff links under Lyndon B. Johnson.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 23 -- The first public demonstrations were conducted here today of an anti-midair collision system the airlines are expected to install, starting probably in 1971.

MANILA, Sept. 23 -- The Philippine election campaign is welcome in the Tondo shantytown slum area here -- partly because the posters it brings keep out the rain in the wood and corrugated iron huts and partly because it may bring the party agents and votebuying gifts of 20 pesos ($5).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The possibility of Federal Government purchase of railroad tracks and rights-of-way to assure passenger service was suggested today by Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Treasury bill rates showed little change at today's auction from last month's levels, the Government reported today. The one-year bill, however, reached a record level.

Two large natural gas discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico, off the coast of Texas, were announced yesterday by Texaco, Inc. The discoveries were made on tracts leased from the Federal Government in 1968.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The big story in British newspapers over much of the last week has been a row at London Weekend Television, one of the commercial broadcasting companies. The owners dismissed their managing director, Michael Peacock, apparently on the ground that profits were too low.

About a year from now, a half-dozen or so small houses that look exactly as they did in Colonial times will be up for rent in Newport, R. I. They are being restored by Doris Duke, who has long maintained an estate, Rough Point, in the famous resort.

THE Cavalier King Charles spaniel is a popular little toy dog in England, Germany and the Netherlands. But in the United States, his progress has been slow. The Cavalier isn't registered in the American Kennel Club stud book and so must be shown in the miscellaneous class, and cannot become a champion.
Prices edged down yesterday in moderate trading on the American Stock Exchange.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 24 -- With troops patrolling the streets and a curfew imposed in most of the riot-torn areas, the six-day outbreak of religious rioting in Gujarat State has been brought under control, the state authorities asserted today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Battlefield action remained low today but terrorism against civilians continued.

Like crowds storming the Bastille, the Mighty Mets stormed their locker room shortly after 9 o'clock on their night to remember and touched off one of the loudest, wildest, wettest victory celebrations in baseball history.

The Labor Department's adoption of the so-called "Philadelphia Plan" is billed as representing a Nixon Administration policy decision to concentrate on increasing job opportunities for minority groups. This may be one of those areas in which the Administration's future deeds will speak louder than its present words; but if taken at face value, it is a remarkable development, with both hopeful and warning elements.
The Bowater Paper Corporation announced yesterday it would increase newspaper prices to $152 a ton, effective Jan. 1. Other major producers took no immediate action.
Detectives evaded an elaborate security system as they raided what they described as heroin processing plant in the Bronx early yesterday morning.

Gus Hall, the leader of the United States Communist party, says Moscow has offered Peking a three-point program for relaxing tensions, based on immediate talks to resolve border conflicts, resumption of relations at the ambassadorial level and trade negotiations.
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 24 -- The nation's two largest Presbyterian churches quietly took the first step today toward mending the division that drove them apart during the Civil War.
Net income of the General Tire and Rubber Company fell in the third quarter and the nine months ended Aug. 31, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced today a reorganization of its civil rights division, racked with dissension for the last month over the Nixon Administration's school desegregation policies.

The Curtis Publishing Company and the Perfect Film and Chemical Corporation, locked in a legal battle since the death of The Saturday Evening Post magazine, announced last night that they had reached an agreement in principle on an out-of-cour tsettlement.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 24 -- Henry E. Parker, a 41-year-old Negro making his first bid for public office, is mounting a vigorous challenge to this city's solidly established Democratic party organization.
MORE than a decade ago, a friend and I hiked to the top of a small mountain in New Hampshire to ice-fish for pickerel.
The Waterfront Commission said yesterday that it did not consider it proper for two longshoremen to be carried on a pier payroll while laying brick in a dock boss's suburban backyard.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A succession of labor union spokesmen criticized the ethical record of Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. in Senate testimony today, with scant mention of the Supreme Court nominee's labor record.

The three major candidates for Mayor have signed agreements binding them to arbitration if charges of mudslinging or racism are injected into their campaign, the Fair Campaign practices Committee and the American Arbitration Association, announced yesterday.
A band of about 20 young white radicals invaded Erasmus Hall High School yesterday afternoon, tied up two teachers and harangued students with a New Left political tirade.

Two of the city's oldest voluntary hospitals, both founded in 1881, announced yesterday that they had merged in an attempt for economies and greater efficiency while expanding or combining medical services.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Violence on television must be reduced because it encourages emulation in real life and strengthens, among low-income youth, "a distorted, pathological view of society," the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Vilence said today.
John (Gentleman Johnny) Masiello, a reputed Mafioso, obtained a delay yesterday for the third time in his trial for criminal contempt in State Supreme Court, the Bronx.

SAN YSIDRO, Calif., Sept. 24 -- In the 30 twin cities that straddle the United States-Mexican border from here to the Gulf, the Government's drive on marijuana smuggling has become one of the hottest issues since Pancho Villa raided frontier towns.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- There was no increase in savings in August in savings-and-loan associations, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. The month usually sees a large inflow, such as the $366-million of last year.

Silver once again was the star performer in commodity futures trading yesterday. The action began undramtically enough with lower opening prices, following the London market which did not rise yesterday to match the strong Tuesday showing in silver prices here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The moderate wing of the Republican party gained power in the Senate today by electing Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania as minority leader and Senator Robert P. Griffin of Michigan as whip.

The Boys' Club of New York will hold its 21st annual Autumn in New York dinner dance at the Plaza on Oct. 16 -- with artichokes as the theme.
ALTHOUGH the repertory of North African food may not be the most extensive on earth, it must certainly be counted among the most fascinating. And impressional.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Nixon Administration proposed today a new farm program that would turn the problems of 400,000 marginal growers over to the welfare system and also reduce restraints on production.

Liability insurance amounting to as much as $300,000 will be required of garage and parking lot operators, starting Nov. 14, under regulations announced yesterday by Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 24 -- The conference of the leaders of Islamic nations neared its conclusion last night amid confusion and dissension.

Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the keystone in the worldwide mutual fund complex of Bernard Cornfeld, made its first public offering of common stock yesterday and investors quickly bid the shares to a large premium.

Senator Howard Baker's double defeat yesterday -- for minority leader and then for Republican whip -- is significant even though it should not be interpreted wholly along ideological lines. With the traditional reverence for seniority characteristic of Capitol Hill, many Republican Senators were no doubt keenly aware that Hugh Scott is 68 and Mr. Baker 43; that Senator Scott has put 26 years into Congressional service and Senator Baker two and a half.

SALEM, Va., Sept. 24 -- Picking up where they left off in last season's playoff with Baltimore, the New York Knickerbockers opened their preseason National Basketball Association play by whipping the Bullets tonight, 116-101, at the Civic Center. The game was also the first for the losers.

Controller Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday that there was an "all-time high increase in crime in New York City in the first six months of 1969" according to statistics from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -News item: Once again, something is happening in Laos. Maybe.

Failure to consult the community was charged to the Lindsay administration yesterday by two officials from Queens in connection with city plans to open a Phoenix House addict-rehabilitation center in Far Rockaway.

Michael Bourgeot is French, and he is visiting this country to teach piano at Ball State University in Muncie, Ind. At his Town Hall debut last night, it was no surprise, then, that his best work was in music of his countrymen.
Loans totaling $91.4-million to India, Kenya, Uganda and Ghana were announced yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, or World Bank.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Three cities -- Boston, Philadelphia and Washington -- put in arty, multimedia bids today to be the site of an American exposition in 1976, although there is some question if Boston really wants it.
TANNED, paunchy executives of old-line companies with unexciting earnings records are probably considerably more relaxed these days.

The state is investigating all sales of one-family and two-family houses in the Crown Heights and East Flatbush sections of Brooklyn because of "blockbusting" charges, Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo announced yesterday.
Frontier Airlines, Inc., the nation's largest local service airline, was awarded $7,920,681 yesterday by a Federal judge in New York as a result of a stockholder's lawsuit.
The Mets' final home game of the season last night proved a costly one for some of the fans who poured across Shea Stadium to celebrate the Mets' victory. It also proved costly for the Stadium.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 24 -- Three young men robbed a suburban savings and loan office today of $275, then shot and killed four women "in cold blood" after herding them into a vault, the police said. The gunmen fled in a 1954 model green car.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright intends to use the State Department's disclosure of the absence of a formal, written request from Saigon for American troops "for all it's worth" in making his case against the war in Vietnam, an aide to the Senator said today.

MATSUE, Japan, Thursday, Sept. 25 -- Premier Eisaku Sato said here today that the time was approaching when Japan would play the leading role in matters relating to Asian security with the United States cooperating from the sidelines.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Republican Congressional leaders joined the Democrats today in calling for an increase in Social Security benefits by Jan. 1, four months earlier than President Nixon had proposed.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- More than half of the world's owners of oil tankers have agreed to pay up to $10-million in compensation to every country whose shoreline and waters are polluted by oil from their vessels. The agreement becomes operative Oct. 6, it was announced today.
Lowell M. Birrell, one-time fugitive financier, charged yesterday that United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau had entered into an illegal conspiracy to harass and perseccute him.
Eighteen people, 16 students and 2 former teachers, began serving jail sentences yesterday for criminal trespass in connection with a sit-in demonstration last May at Queensborough Community College.

JIM NABORS makes the transition at 8 o'clock tonight on the Columbia Broadcasting System from the awkward bumpkin Gomer Pyle in the Marine Corps to a singing host in evening clothes on his own variety show. The program is an hour for those down home where the Nielsen flowers grow.
A Federal judge was asked yesterday to declare the draft laws unconstitutional on the basis of a historical analysis of the framing and adoption of the Constitution.
GABORONE, Botswana, Sept. 17 -- Sir Seretse Khama, Botswana's clever and confident President, demonstrated the other day his skill in electoral politics.

Demanding immediate approval of an urban renewal project, about a dozen demonstrators paralyzed a Planning Commission hearing at City Hall for three hours yesterday, then wrestled with policemen, ripped out a microphone and spilled papers on the floor.

Budget Director Frederick O'R. Hayes said yesterday that there were still so many "uncertainties" about income and outgo in this year's budget that the city might have to resort to deficit financing for the first time since Mayor Lindsay took office.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- A rich retrospective of paintings by Maria Elena Vieira da Silva, the Portuguese-born abstract artist, opened today at the Museum of Modern Art here with 90 works, executed from 1935 through 1969.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 24 -- George Meany sharply criticized the Nixon Administration today for attempting, he said, to make "a whipping boy" of the building trades unions by charging them with discrimination against black workers.
FORT WORTH, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Dykes Askew Simmons Jr., who spent 10 years in a Mexican prison for murder before escaping in April of this year, was found beaten to death tonight.
Stock prices slid slowly into minus territory yesterday with weakness apparent in glamour issues and other recent market favorites. Declines outpaced advances by a 7-to-5 ratio.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Significant pressure from many sides is developing here for a much faster withdrawal of American troops from South Vietnam than President Nixon has prescribed so far.
The Legislature's approval last spring of the state's $6.9-billion budget violated the State Constitution, a judge ruled yesterday.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 24 -- The first concrete steps toward the expansion of a Latin American payments clearing union were being drafted by the region's central bank governors and finance ministers at their ninth annual meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- President Nixon still favors retention of the 27 1/2 per cent oil depletion allowance but would not veto a tax reform bill that reduced it, the White House indicated today.

ALBANY, Sept. 24 -- The Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal, today upheld a lower court ruling ordering a special Democratic primary next Tuesday to choose the party's nominee for Borough President of Queens.
SAN DIEGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Tom Dukes checked a San Francisco rally in the eighth innings tonight as San Diego scored its second victory over the Giants, 3-2.

The Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company has tentatively agreed to exchange stock for the wet-shaving business of Eversharp, Inc., the two concerns announced last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans expressed concern today over the possibility that the consumer movement would get out of hand.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 24 -- Now that the pro football public has begun to appreciate Joe Namath, another question exists: How much longer can he last?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A rebellious House Banking Committee voted down, 21-13 today committee chairman Wright Patman's proposal to investigate alleged improper activities by the bank lobby.
SAN DIEGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- American skippers, headed by James Schoonmaker of Miami, swept the first eight places in yesterday's second race of the Star Class world championships.

HONG KONG, Sept. 24 -- Vice President Ton Duc Thang, an 81 - year - old Vietnamese Communist leader and a native of southern Vietnam, was eleeted yesterday to succeed Ho Chi Minh as President of North Vietnam.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 -- On the other side of the New York baseball coin, the Yankees battled futilely tonight for 14 innings before losing their fifth straight road game, a 1-0 defeat at the hands of the Red Sox.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 24 -- A Brazilian Army colonel watched the first few thousand copies of last Sunday's issue of the daily newspaper O Estado de Sao Paulo roll off the presses. Then he ordered the presses stopped and confiscated the edition.

Badische Anilin Soda-Fabrik of West Germany is expected to announce soon that it will invest $100-million in a chemical complex in Beaufort County, S. C. It would be by far the biggest single German investment in the United States since the end of World War II and double the outlays projected by Badische Anilin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- The House Armed Services Committee today rejected the attacks on the ABM, the C-5A and other recent targets of defense critics, but voted to require a 176,000-man military personnel cut.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 24 -- An Israeli commission of inquiry into the fire in the Mosque of Al Aksa last month concluded today that it was the work of an arsonist who succeeded in setting the blaze because of the negligence of Moslem guards.

With the prices of food, clothing, housing and medical care at their fingertips, a group of unhappy Bronx housewives told a newly established City Commission on Inflation yesterday that rising prices were causing despair among low- and middle-income families.
Recommendations for resolving the contract dispute between Metropolitan Opera and its performers were submitted yesterday to Mayor Lindsay and to both sides by David L. Cole, mediator.

New evidence that multiple sclerosis may be strictly an environmental disease that, like polio, plagues the populations of some nations more than others was presented at a conference on the disease here yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 24 -- President Kingman Brewster Jr. of Yale proposed tonight that the tradition of an indefinite term for the university's president be ended and -- to drive the point home -- he put his own job on the line.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Government moved today to settle an antitrust suit under which a West German company and its wholly owned American subsidiary were accused of restricting resale of certain pesticides.
Prices on the London stock market recovered most of their initial small losses yesterday near the close. Quiet trading reflected extreme caution ahead of the West German elections on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Navy announced mild disciplinary action against the commander of the Sealab 3 project and a senior petty officer today in the death of a civilian aquanaut, Berry L. Cannon, during a deep sea experiment off California last February.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 24 -- Byegone, a free-legged pacer owned, trained and driven by John Patterson Sr., easily won tonight's featured $6,500 handicap one-mile race for Class A/2-A-3 pacers at Roosevelt Raceway.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Pancho Gonzales defeated Ken Rosewall, 6-4, 11-13, 7-5, to gain the quarterfinals of the Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament today. The match lasted 2 hours 22 minutes.

BONN, Sept. 24 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger today ordered West German money markets to close tomorrow and Friday to head off a new wave of speculative buying of the Deutsche Mark before the national election Sunday.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 25 -- The mayoral candidate endorsed by the Democratic organization here won an easy victory tonight in the party's primary over two insurgents, one of whom was the first Negro to make a significant bid for the office.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- If the Atlanta Braves and San Francisco Giants tie for first place in the National League's Western Division, they will play one game in Atlanta Oct. 3 to decide the champions.

Distillers Corporation - Seagrams, Ltd., yesterday reported record sales and higher profits for the fiscal year ended July 31.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 25 -- Demonstrators invaded the Center for International Affairs at Harvard University today, terrorizing and roughing up members of the staff and painting antiwar slogans and obscenities on the building's walls.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Just off Smithfield, the great open square containing London's meat market, there is a small street called Cloth Fair. Its houses, going back three centuries, evoke the intimate domestic London of the past. Lucky tourists find it as they seek the Norman Church of St. Bartholomew the Great, halfhidden next door.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- In corridors here, which rustle with corner conversations on how the Middle East question might be brought to a real peace, there is one quiet diplomat who has been involved for 20 years in discussions of armistice agreements for the Middle East.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- More than 2,000 angry white construction workers Jammed the sidewalks around the United States Customs House here today, brawling with the police and preventing Negro leaders from appearing at a Labor Department hearing on building trades discrimination.

New York, the weekly magazine that explained how to be poor on $80,000 a year, raised some money yesterday.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- The Swedish tanker Claude lay beached and deserted near here tonight, two of her holds still brimming with highly inflammable liquid butane gas.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 25 (AP) -Andras Balczo of Hungary won the cross-country run today and captured the world modern pentathlon championship for the fifth consecutive time. The Soviet Union won the team championship with 15,730 points. Hungary was next with 15,622.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange edged down again yesterday in reduced trading volume.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- A new arts festival, held in and near Windsor Castle, has had such a success in the last week that it seems certain to become an annual event.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- A Jury of two men and 10 women was chosen today for the trial of eight leaders of protest demonstrations at the Democratic National Convention last year.

The shaped poem combines the qualities of concrete verse and those of the formal poem. The look of the poem is the subject and springboard of the work. It is an old device as those who remember George Herbert's "Altar" and "Easter Wings" will testify.

THE most frequent error made when using an aerosol paint is not holding the spray can a uniform distance from the work. Moving it too close will result in runs or drips. CHERRY HILL, N. J., Sept. 28 -- Alan Garner of Denver, Pa., took a virtual stranglehold on the open jumper division at the Cooper Hospital Horse Show today when he rode the winners of two classes.

Your excellent editorial on the arms race [Sept. 24] wrongly gives me credit for the phrase "scorpions in a bottle." The fault for your inadvertent error is mine. I had assumed that the phrase was now so much a part of the language that quotation marks and attribution would be unnecessary.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Jim Grabowski caught a swing pass from Bart Starr and bulled into the end zone in the fourth quarter today to break a 7-7 deadlock and give the Green Bay Packers a 14-7 victory over the San Francisco 49ers.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Calvin Hill bolted for 141 yards and two touchdowns today to give the Dallas Cowboys a 21-17 come-from-behind victory over the New Orleans Saints.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 -- Black members of the United Steelworkers of America called upon the organization this weekend to name a Negro representative to the executive board of the union.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Sept. 28 -- A Yonkers man wanted for the armed robbery of a Bronx tavern and the shooting of an off-duty patrolman last July was arrested here last night at the apartment of a local physician.

OLONGAPO, the Philippines, Sept. 16 -- Mrs. Anastasia Acuna's main worry is that a young man may tempt her daughter Erlinda into marriage. Since Linda is 19 and pretty, Mrs. Acuna's fears are realistic, although Linda maintains that there is no danger.
Kevin Rogan shared little in the glory of Chaminade's Catholic Schools Football League championship last season. He was a defensive back and defensive backs are not apt to be publicized.

As far as Japan is concerned the current system of fixed currency exchange rates should be maintained.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Nothing maddens many of the more sentimental or richer residents of Chelsea, which covers 659 acres in southwest London, than the world fame and the weekend fury of its main street. The King's Road is its name.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Billy Casper, playing despite what seemed a hopeless cause, shot birdies on the last four holes today to win the $55,000 first prize in the Alcan Golfer of the Year Tournament with a final six-under-par 66 for 270.

STONY BROOK, L. I. -- In the center of a broad sunny meadow half-encircled by tall trees just beginning to surrender, in flashes of red and gold, to the turn of season, several hundred men, women and children worked industriously Saturday.

ATHENS, Sept. 28 -- In a move to increase Greece's recovering tourist trade, the Athens regime has absolved all Greeks residing abroad of their army draft obligations, if they wish to visit Greece next year.

THE bridge tournament calendar offers enthusiasts several opportunities to escape from the wintry weather of New York to more salubrious climates. WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -Senator Edward M. Kennedy moved today to take the military draft issue away from the Administration by contending that the executive branch already has authority, without any Congressional action, to implement reforms in the Selective Service System.

The "clever" evasion of the Netcong, N. J., Board of Education in its continuing campaign to put religious observance into the public schools has one obvious lesson for young people: it's all right to cheat if one does it in the name of religion and holiness.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The United States Command said the movement of American marines was beginning today under President Nixon's schedule for the withdrawal of 35,000 more men by mid-December.
Frederick H. Burkhardt, president of the American Council of Learned Societies, was elected chairman of the Board of Higher Education last night to succeed Porter R. Chandler.
Real estate leaders said yesterday that owners of 200,000 apartments had pledged to have rent reductions and refunds in their Oct. 1 billings as mandated by the city's new rent law.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 29 (AP) -- A judge took under advisement today the latest motion by the parents of Mary Jo Kopechne to block an autopsy on their daughter.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- A 30-year-old Methodist minister, who worked closely with neighborhood street gangs, and his wife were found stabbed repeatedly and slain today in their seven-room apartment at 2038 North Seminary Avenue on Chicago's near North Side.
Stocks drifted down on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in continued light trading.
" Do you want to hear a great thing?" asked Richard Roud, whose job it is to choose the movies for the New York Film Festival. "In all these years, nobody has ever offered me a bribe."

Sara Grey, a young, blond girl wearing a green sweater and a plaid miniskirt, brought a fresh, contemporary aura to the traditional art of unaccompanied ballad singing last night at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

Two new hospitals for mentally ill children in New York State will stand unused this fall because the Legislature failed to appropriate the funds needed to set them in operation, a member of Congress charged yesterday.
Columbia University has started legal action to revoke a doctoral degree in economics it granted in 1962, on the ground that the "original thesis" had been plagiarized.

HONOLULU, Sept. 29 -- The American Bankers Association, meeting here in the luxury hotels on Waikiki Beach for its 95th annual convention, was faced today with the prospect of a showdown with the Congress of Racial Equality, one of the nation's more militant civil rights groups.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Capt. Robert F. Marasco, the Special Forces officer who had been accused of killing a suspected Vietnamese double agent until the charges were dropped yesterday, told his wife in a letter that some aspects of the case "would have international implications and affect even the [Paris] peace talks."

Premier Golda Meir of Israel, enveloped in the reverent affection of thousands of New Yorkers and the watchful security of legions of police, opened a three-day visit to the city yesterday with repeated declarations that her country yearned for peace.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Senate opponents of a proposal to guarantee workmen's compensation payments to coal workers afflicted with "black lung" disease delayed today the first test vote on a broad Federal coal mine health and safety bill.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 29 -Gen. Alfredo Ovando Candia, Bolivia's new President, said today that he was willing to establish relations with Cuba, if Cuba strictly avoided interfering in Bolivian affairs.

LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The twice-postponed heavyweight fight between Jimmy Ellis, the World Boxing Association champion from Louisville, Ky., and Henry Cooper of Britain finally was canceled today, because the Briton has to undergo leg surgery.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 -- Automobile manufacturers are taking a cautious approach to production scheduling for the remainder of this year, planning about 8 per cent fewer car assemblies than in October, November and December of 1968.
The Times has been publishing a series of news articles about drug addiction and the defense of the citizenry against crime connected with narcotic addicts.

ANITA LOOS, the author, said that a girl who collected diamonds would be wise to hock them for a sable or two, and Dina Merrill, the actress, said she probably shouldn't be there, the temptations were so irresistible.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 -- An estimated $250,000 worth of high-grade hashish was seized here yesterday by Customs Bureau officials who found 78 pounds of the drug concealed in an ornate marble tabletop.

MOSCOW, Sept. 29 -- More than 40 Soviet dissidents have sent an appeal to Secretary General Thant of the United Nations asking him to have "violations of human rights" in the Soviet Union placed before the Human Rights Commission for discussion.

A two-month decline in contracts for future construction in the United States was reversed with the placement of more than $6.5-billion worth of orders in August, according to a monthly summary prepared by the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill, Inc.

Your recent editorial "Stopgap for Air Controllers" contains certain portions which detract from an otherwise accurate portrayal of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization's (PATCO's) position.
BONN, Sept. 29 -- The West German coalition Government ordered the Central Bank today to permit the mark to rise in value according to the demands of the free market.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Justice Department asked Congress today to increase the maximum fine for criminal antitrust violations to $500,000 from $50,000.
DRAGONS seems to be the main export of Sikkim: They are all over the rugs the country sends here and they are certainly the main motif of Sikkimese jewelry.
The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) has named as its next president a 42-year-old lawyer who joined the company last year.
Moviegoers throughout the country have been exceptionally curious about "I Am Curious (Yellow)."
Michael Piemonte has been appointed vice president-administration and controls, for the American Express travel division. He formerly was director of corporate marketing services.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The North Vietnamese delegation to the peace talks here, faced with a wave of requests for help in locating American war prisoners, angrily accused the United States today of "exploiting family sentiment" to camouflage its pursuit of the war in South Vietnam.

LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Six Green Beret officers, freed of murder charges in the death of an alleged Vietnamese double agent, jubilantly staged a pre-dawn barracks beer party today and prepared to go home, declaring that they had never doubted the outcome of the case.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 29 -- Laotian patrols over the weekend re-entered Muong Soui, the bitterly contested valley town 105 miles north of here, as North Vietnamese troops, estimated at four battalions, withdrew eastward under pressure from heavy American bombing.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands -- Although 85 per cent of the residents of the United States Virgin Islands are Negroes and Negroes control the islands' government, racial tensions here have increased noticeably in recent months.

The Conservative party leader in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn announced yesterday that his organization would support Mario A. Procaccino, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, because John J. Marchi, the Republican-Conservative candidate "obviously cannot defeat Mayor Lindsay."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Army, conceding that it was helpless to enlist the cooperation of the Central Intelligence Agency, today abruptly dropped its case against six Special Forces soldiers who were arrested in July in connection with the alleged murder of a Vietnamese agent.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The West German decision today to let the robust mark increase in value by "floating" temporarily in foreign-exchange trading stirred excitement in European financial centers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Despite Administration warnings that the United States would be placed in an "extremely awkward and seemingly dangerous position," Senate Democratic leaders refused today to call up legislation to extend the interest equalization tax.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- While about 150 lawyers picketed the court building or roamed the corridors, Judge Julius J. Hoffman vacated today contempt citations against four defense lawyers in the trial of the "Chicago eight." Judge Hoffman had held the four lawyers in contempt for failing to appear last week when the trial of eight leaders of demonstrations at last summer's Democratic National Convention began in Federal District Court in Chicago.
Fears that the NATO alliance might founder on the rocks of a trade war were experessed here yesterday by a former Democratic adviser, Theodore C. Sorensen.

The Long Island Rail Road's fall schedule went into effect yesterday, but only 25 trains serving resort areas on summer weekends were removed from service despite widespread fears that several commuter trains would be eliminated.

Magic Chef, Inc., a stove and air - conditioning equipment manufacturing company, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday a proposed public offering of 1.04 million common shares to be sold by an underwriting syndicate managed by Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co.
Business copying machines yesterday joined the growing list of items that will bear higher price tags in the months ahead.

ANCHORAGE, Sept. 29 -- The Atomic Energy Commission's plans for an underground weapons test in the Aleutian Islands on Thursday rolled forward today despite mounting criticism in Washington and elsewhere.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Cesar Chavez, the leader of the California grape boycott, accused growers today of "systematic poisoning" of field workers with pesticides.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- "We are in a period of transition at Harvard," said Prof. Stanley Hoffmann as he settled behind a book-laden desk in his office at the Littauer Center for Public Administration.

The Egyptian Foreign Minister, Mahmoud Riad, chided Israeli leaders yesterday for dismissing the territorial issue in the Middle East conflict as just a question of "a little sand" and ridiculed the Israeli assertion that everything was "negotiable."
TOKYO, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- The United States Ambassador to Japan, Armin Meyer, warned today that America could not tolerate forever a trade deficit with Japan soaring into billions of dollars.

Ohio State, rated the nation's No. 1 college football team without having played a game, justified its ranking in its opener Saturday.

The director of the United States Open tennis championships urged the West Side Tennis Club yesterday to plow up its grass courts and install a synthetic surface. He also called for streamlining the scoring system to stimulate interest in tennis.

Net income of the Avco Corporation rose slightly in the quarter ended Aug. 31 and the nine-month period, the company reported yesterday.
Severe crowding conditions, including youngsters sleeping in auditoriums and doubling up in nursery beds, were reported at the city's two children's shelters yesterday by the welfare workers union.
President Nixon's handling of the Vietnam War is viewed favorably by 35 per cent of the American people, a new low for his eight months in the White House, according to the latest Louis Harris poll.

Controller Mario A. Procaccino complained that he was strong-armed by one of Mayor Lindsay's aides yesterday and barred from entering the Mayor's office while accompanying Mrs. Golda Meir to an informal meeting there.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 29 -- Talks on the proposed Government take-over of 51 per cent of Zambia's partly American-owned giant copper industry resumed here today.

I., .Sept. 30 -- If it's money that will hold the interest of the harness racing fans at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night, their attention should be focused on the fourth race -- the New York Sire Stakes. WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Treasury Department proposed today that students and others who work only part of the year and do not earn enough to owe any Federal income tax be relieved of the inconvenience of having taxes withheld and then having to file for a refund.
The Food and Drug Administration has told 22 manufacturers of cosmetics and baby lotions in the New York-New Jersey area to improve the way they test products for possible contamination.

EUGENE ORMANDY brought his Phildelphia Orchestra into New York last night for its first Philharmonic Hall concert of the season, with an unusual program. Usually the opener is an official affair, with a tried-and-true soloist in a true-and-tried repertory.

HARTFORD, Sept. 30 -- A suit challenging the constitutionality of state aid to parochial and other nonpublic schools was filed today in the United States District Court for Connecticut.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 30 -- Within a few weeks, Tom Nieporte will pack his golf clubs and move south to join his Wife and nine children in Boca Raton, Fla. Queens Borough President Sidney Leviss, the Democratic organization choice, scored a clear-cut victory in yesterday's special primary election for the Democratic nomination for his post.

At long last the most respected and effective leader of postwar Greece has plunged wholeheartedly into the expanding effort to rid his country of a brutal and incompetent military dictatorship. Constantine Caramanlis waited a long time from his self-imposed exile in Paris to commit his enormous prestige to the fight against the colonels, but his savage, detailed indictment of them yesterday removes all doubts about where he stands.

HONOLULU, Sept. 30 -- The Nixon Administration plans to press for extension of the Federal income tax surcharge at a level of 5 per cent through the middle of next year, a high official said here today. Under present law, the surcharge, which is now at a 10 per cent rate, will expire on Dec. 31.

Bampton Castle lost his first steeplechase skirmish of the season yesterday at Belmont Park, but the old war horse may have worked himself into winning shape for the bigger battle to came. Even at 12, jumpers with class aren't ready for retirement.

WARSAW, Sept. 30 -- Polish newspapers said today that the elections in West Germany had disclosed small, but significant, shifts toward a new realism.

Premier Golda Meir of Israel carried her quest for stability in the Middle East to the mass media, to Secretary of State William P. Rogers and to an emotional audience of Jewish youth yesterday in a prelude to a gala dinner in her honor last night.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 30 -- The Board of Education here has placed the blame for its failure to deal with a lapse of liability insurance coverage of the city school system on Mrs. Henrietta Nagel, its $14,000-a-year board secretary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Prices farmers receive for their products dropped 1.5 per cent during the month ended Sept. 15, but were still 3 per cent above the level of a year earlier, the Agriculture Department reported today.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 30 -- More than 3,000 followers of the Rev. Ian Paisley, the Protestant extremist leader, gathered outside Parliament today to protest any concessions by the Government to Ulster's Roman Catholic population.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 30 -- A Federal District Court Court judge who ruled today that schools in Chesterfield County must be desegregated in 1970-71 described a statement by the Nixon Administration last July as one that dragged "a red herring across the path of progress toward desegregation."

DETROIT, Sept. 30 -- Gov. William G. Milliken of Michigan proposed today a far-reaching reform of the state's public school system that would shift the burden of school financing from the local communities to the state.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- European speculators bet on even higher values for the floating German mark today with heavy new purchases of the currency at premium prices.
Stock prices staged a slow but steady retreat yesterday as volume on the New York Stock Exchange ambled at its most leisurely pace in more than three weeks.

WHEN Willie Mays stepped up to bat as a pinch-hitter a little more than a week ago and smote a home run, he advanced to a new and spectacular plateau in baseball history. For Willie the Wonder it was homer No. 600 and only the incomparable Babe Ruth hit that many. In fact, the Babe stands at 714 in solitary grandeur.
State Senator John J. Marchi promised yesterday that if elected Mayor he would try to help establish a fourth daily newspaper in the city.

The warning by Jerris Leonard, chief of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, that a Supreme Court order to desegregate all Southern schools could not be enforced strikes at the foundation of government by law. It is astonishing as the declared stance of an Administration that, in its rhetoric, has so consistently vowed to uphold law and order.

Rose Wildes, surely one of the most beautiful sopranos in the music business today, made her New York debut last night in a Town Hall Artist Award Recital sponsored by the New York Singing Teachers Association. She is a graduate of Florida State University, and has studied here with Hallie Nowland.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Informed European diplomats at the United Nations believe that there has been some progress during the last two weeks on a possible settlement of the Middle Eastern conflict.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- From mysterious start to melodramatic finish, the case of the Green Berets has been a case of "Who's in charge here, anyway?"
FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 30 -- The mark increased in value here today by 4 per cent, or 3.84 marks to the dollar, the first day it was fully exposed to the law of supply and demand.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 30 -- The RCA Corporation made a bid here today to capture a new consumer market -- prerecorded television programs on tape.

BILLINGS, Mont. -- It's 15 miles southeast on Highway 87-212 to the turnoff to the Rosell Ranch on the Crow Reservation. A mile farther, over a winding gravel route, lies the peaceful tepee encampment in a cottonwood grove along Pryor Creek where scenes for "Little Big Man" are being shot.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Nixon Administration opposed today more "massive doses of Federal money" to overcome man-made wastes that pollute cities and the countryside.

Unemployed musicians of the Metropolitan Opera will stage a gala performance for their own benefit at Philharmonic Hall on Friday, Oct. 17, featuring orchestra, chorus and leading singers such as Cornell MacNeil, Jerome Hines and George Shirley.
The Police Department reported yesterday the arrest of 1,295 persons on felony narcotics charges in August, topping the previous record of 1,132 set in April.
For years Lee Strasberg has labored largely within the confines of the Actors Studio. As a result, he says, "Our influence is very wide -- but indirect."

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Constantine Caramanlis, the former Premier of Greece now in self-imposed exile, ended nearly two years of silence today and appealed to his country's military forces to help overthrow the army-backed regime.

Eastern Air Lines, which once said "See how much better an airline can be," then "We want everyone to fly," then "We make it easier to fly" and finally "Smiling faces going places," is coming up with a new one -- indeed a grand one, an imposing one, an overpowering one.

" Have you voted, brother?" The question was directed through a loudspeaker mounted atop a battered station wagon toward a bearded man loping along a sidewalk yesterday in the slums of Brooklyn's East New York.
The Lindsay administration announced plans yesterday to build 1,500 units of low-income and middle-income housing on the Brooklyn waterfront between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- When Col. Henry Harold Tufts was mentioned in a newspaper article on riot training some 19 months ago the writer called him "a peppery, middle-aged soldier" who was always chewing a cigar.

A member of the local school board involved in the controversy over Junior High School 164 resigned yesterday, depriving the panel of the legal strength to appoint a new acting principal for the school or take any other official actions.

AN expert can sometimes bring home contracts at the table that lesser mortals would find difficult with all four hands exposed. The diagramed deal, played many years ago in England, is a good example. The hero was the late Capt. Ewart Kempson, who was a great writer and a great cardplayer.
PODUNK CENTER, Iowa, Sept. 30 (AP) -- America's best known hick town, Podunk Center, will be auctioned off Oct. 14.

About 5,000 members of District 65 of the National Council of Distributive Workers held a rally in front of their union headquarters at 13 Astor Place yesterday to emphasize their demands for a $100 a week minimum wage.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today supported the Federal Communications Commission's plan for licensing pay television throughout the nation.

The Art Dealers Association of America has told the city of Miami Beach that "an undue proportion" of art works in the city-owned Bass Museum are either "grossly overattributed or outright fakes," and has backed up its charges with detailed analyses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Informed South Vietnamese sources here said today that Saigon had started negotiating with Washington for an increase in economic and military assistance as American troops were withdrawn from Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30--Led by President Nixon, the Administration and its principal Congressional spokesmen mounted new efforts today to dampen criticism of the Vietnam war and build a united front for the American negotiating position.
PARIS, Sept. 30 -- North Vietnam was authoritatively reported today to have agreed to supply the names of some, if not all, United States prisoners of war that it is holding.

In the last few weeks 24 prominent professors and the presidents of Michigan and Yale Universities advised their students to resist actively the Nixon Vietnam policy (news stories Sept. 16 and 23). For those of us who respect education, it is tempting to let ourselves be swept along behind these scholarly leaders.

There was a long list of people with aches and pains on the desk of the New York Jets coach, Weeb Ewbank, as the world champions resumed practice yesterday at Rikers Island, but the only one causing serious conern was the knee injury to Jim Hudson, the strong safety.
The Beatrice Foods Company yesterday announced higher profits and sales for the quarter and six months ended Aug. 31.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 30 -- The finding that hundreds of thousands of Americans are seriously misusing codeine-based cough syrups and paregoric has caused the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs to propose new restrictions on their sale.

WASHINGTON -- When Richard McGarrah Helms, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, is home, he's still not too far removed from cloak-and-dagger work. He and his wife like to relax in their Chevy Chase apartment by reading spy stories to each other.

THIS is the year for boldly scaled patterns -- preferably in offbeat or brilliant colors, preferably used on more than one surface in a room, preferably serving as a background for traditional furnishings and preferably accented by at least one piece of modern furniture.

The controversy over the nomination of Judge Haynsworth has taken an unfortunate turn. Judge Haynsworth testified that he was not aware of the business connection between Carolina Vend-A-Matic Company in which he had a substantial interest and role, and one of the parties to the Darlington litigation when he participated in the decision in that case.

Afro-American art and contemporary jazz were blended last night at the Whitney Museum of American Art in a program prepared by the Harlem Cultural Council. An audience of 400 in the museum's fourth floor gallery watched a shifting panorama of slides of paintings, sculpture and masks on three walls of the gallery while Horacee Arnold's jazz quintet, The Here and Now Company, played a musical interpretation of the art work.

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 30 -- Christine Keeler, star of the big political scandal of the 1960's, has reappeared in England as a figure of controversy. This time the fate of the Tory Government is not at stake. Instead she is making people think about the right to privacy in an increasingly shrill and intrusive world.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Judge Julius J. Hoffman today ordered the jury in the trial of the "Chicago eight" sequestered in a downtown hotel following indications that two jurors had been threatened.
Roosevelt Raceway accuses Joseph Harris, its former treasurer, of lining his pockets by manipulation of the track's stock and bank accounts.
The college football season will be one of high-geared offensives, according to the first individual statistics, released yesterday by the National Collegiate Sports Services.

Asserting that the Government had been lax in not affording a timely hearing, Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley yesterday dismissed complaints against six women arrested after an antiwar demonstration on July 3.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 30 -- The crew of Apollo 11 were met in this lofty Andean capital today by a welcoming turnout that far exceeded official expectations.

Although West Germany caught the world by surprise in cutting the mark free from its 25-cent peg and letting it float upward, there had long been every reason to believe that an appreciation of the German mark was coming. In fact, the move was long overdue.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 30 -- The Delaware Department of Justice dropped a blasphemy charge against a high school student, today, explaining that the 143-year-old statute that re-suited in the charge was probably unconstitutional.
ATLANTA, Sept. 30 -- The South rose again tonight as the Atlanta Braves, sparked by Rico Carry, edged Cincinnati, 3-2, and clinched the National League's Western Division title.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Sept. 30 -- Paul Laxalt, Nevada's popular young Republican Governor, announced today that his career in elective politics would end next year when his term expires.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, Oct. 1 -- Communist China today celebrated its 20th anniversary with a huge rally in Peking's Tienanmen Square where Mao-Tse-tung made his first public appearance in more than four months, the Peking radio said.

The world's scheduled trans-Atlantic airlines -- which have just had one of their least profitable summers in history -- are opening a counterattack against what they consider a major source of their troubles: the so-called supplemental airlines that fly passengers abroad at half the regular fare.

FORT WORTH, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Mrs. Marge Mason of West Englewood, N.J., shot a two-over-par 75 today to take the first-round lead in the United State Golf Association's women's senior amateur championship.

IT was one of the first fashionable parties of the season, and there wasn't a see-through dress or a plunging neckline in sight. The room was a sea of brocade and fur trim, cut velvet and silk, classically cut wools and what one guest referred to as "dear little dresses."
CHINGOLA, Zambia, Sept. 30 -- Ever since the Rev. Colin Morris arrived in Zambia (then called Northern Rhodesia) in April, 1956, he has been a decidedly political parson.

PEKING, Oct. 1 (Agence France-Presse) -- An apparently healthy Chairman Mao Tse-tung presided today over China's annual National Day mass meeting at which the Chinese people were told to prepare for possible war with the United States or the Soviet Union.
An agreement in principle has been reached for the Briggs Manufacturing Company to acquire the Philip Carey Corporation for stock worth about $72-million.
OTTAWA, Oct. 1 -- A few days ago Lester B. Pearson was chatting about the study of economic development and international aid that a commission he headed had just submitted to the World Bank.
The 23-year-old daughter of a New York State bank examiner was arrested yesterday as an accomplice in the robbery of a Queens bank the day before.

In light trading, issues on the American Stock Exchange meandered downward yesterday. At the close, the price index was $26.41, down 11 cents, on volume of 2,744,410 shares, compared with 3,145-595 the day before.

LAC LAVOIE, Quebec -- We had just taken off from Lac Lavoie, which is near the Labrador border and the site of the northernmost of the St. Lawrence Fishing and Hunting Club's camps, when we saw a big bull moose feeding in a marsh on the edge of a small bay.
The Board of Education was unable to explain yesterday why almost 3 million textbooks that had been ordered for the start of school in September had failed to appear.
City Council President Francis X. Smith charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay had sharply reduced manpower in the police narcotics squad after a dramatic pre-primary buildup last June.

ATHENS, Oct. 1 -- The call for prompt restoration of democracy in Greece issued last night by former Premier Constantine Caramanlis who is in self-imposed exile in Paris, was censored from the Greek press today by the country's army-backed regime.

TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 1 -- A lean, blond West Pointer, Col. Robert B. Rheault, once commander of the Army's 3,000 Special Forces personnel in Vietnam, led six of his smiling comrades off a plane here today denying that they had killed an alleged Vietnamese double agent.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler, perhaps the biggest over-all bond trading firm in Wall Street and a major dealer in large blocks of stock, broke a longstanding tradition yesterday. It reported earnings -- up 10 per cent for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.

Down in the depths of Columbus Circle, where the IRT and IND cross paths, is the tiny auditorium of the New York Cultural Center. When the center was Huntington Hartford's Gallery of Modern Art, till last July, the 154-seat hall was used primarily for lectures and the showing of films.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Ernie Banks is still smiling, yes, he is. Listen to Ernie. "Happy Wednesday, everybody. Welcome to beautiful Wrigley Field. What a day. Why, you couldn't have asked for a better day, to play if we made it ourselves, Randy."

BRASILIA -- Thirteen years ago men and machines began shaping the dry earth of a dying farm on Brazil's central plateau into a new capital that would fuse the country's cosmopolitan coast and its stagnant backlands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The director of the Office of Economic Opportunity said today that the agency's Civil Rights Division was inefficient and for that reason he was replacing the entire unit. Donald Rumsfeld, the director, announced a reassignment of some personnel last Thursday and placed the entire civil rights division on the reassignment list.

Standing in a noonday shopping crowd on Fifth Avenue, State Senator John J. Marchi yesterday accused United States Senator Jacob K. Javits of using "unfair" and "insulting" tactics to win votes for Mayor Lindsay.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Two witnesses told a Senate inquiry today that a ring of noncommissioned officers had stolen $5,000 to $7,000 a week from slot machines alone while mismanaging service clubs in West Germany.

HONOLULU, Oct. 1 -- A senior official of the nation's largest bank predicted here today that the prime rate -- the minimum interest charge on loans to the most credit-worthy borrowers -- would decline by early next year at the latest.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Senator Edward W. Brooke called on President Nixon today to withdraw the nomination of Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. to the Supreme Court.

BONN, Oct. 1 -- The West German Mark increased in value another percentage point to 5 per cent over its former fixed parity of 25 cents today, its second day of floating free in response to market pressures.
