WHY, cries the reader, review such books at all? And if the reviewer responds that, surely, any form of communication engaging the imaginations of millions of people deserves (perhaps nervous) attention, the reader is entitled to respond, with William Jovanovich, "Some things may not be worth communicating, as we know from television."
Nearly 18 per cent of Medicaid patients received "unsatisfactory care" on eye problems, according to the first results of the city Health Department's audit of optometric service.

Controller Mario A. Procaccino predicted yesterday that he would be elected Mayor by a plurality of 300,000 votes. According to an aide, Mr. Procaccino's prediction was based on his own hunch rather than on information derived from polls.
The dispute over trans-Atlantic air fares was thrown into further confusion yesterday as airline officials opened a series of secret meeting here in an effort to find a way out of the controversy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The first international study of aid to the poor countries by an independent commission of eight distinguished citizens from as many countries, concluded today that the aid effort was "flagging" at the very time that the drive for economic development was beginning to produce results.

The memory of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, whose 100th birthday anniversary is being observed today, was recently described as having become, at one and the same time, "inspiring and irrelevant" in the India of 1969.

DETROIT, Oct. 1 (AP) -- One of the richest private art collections in the United States has been left to the city of Detroit, it was disclosed yesterday when the will of Robert Hudson Tannahill, 76-year-old heir to a department store fortune, was filed for probate. Mr. Tannahill died last Thursday.
ROME, Oct. 1 -- Pope Paul VI said today that "animal, barbarous and subhuman degradations" of permissive eroticism had made modern society no longer worthy to be called "civilization."

TOKYO, Oct. 1 -- The United States agreed today to grant Japan Airlines a new Great Circle route to New York by way of Anchorage, Alaska, in return for permission to send more charter flights to this country.

KANSAS STATE, Washington, Boston University, Navy, and, not to be forgotten, Moravian, will have a common bond in football Saturday as each faces a team with a long undefeated streak and each is expected to lose.

SAN YSIDRO, Calif., Oct. 1 -- Ten days of relentless warfare on the smuggling of marijuana and dangerous drugs across the Mexican border has convinced United States enforcement officials of the futility of trying to dry up the illicit traffic with currently available money, manpower and equipment.

DURING the 1969 baseball season, whose regular schedule ends today, run-production was noticeably greater than in 1968. Since 1968 was, everything considered, the poorest-hitting year in the history of major league baseball, the fact of increase is neither as impor tant or informative as the amount of increase.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Nixon ordered the Selective Service System today to let graduate students who are eligible for the draft finish the school year before they are inducted.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Judge Julius J. Hoffman removed a 23-year-old woman from the jury in the trial of the "Chicago eight" today after he showed her a threatening letter.

With the visit of Israeli Premier Meir to Washington in search of a deeper U.S. economic, military and diplomatic commitment to her state, it is proper for Americans to pause and take inventory of our nation's Mideast policy.

Any New Yorker who wants to vote in the mayoral election Nov. 4 has four more days to register. Regular local registration starts in 5,318 Election Districts at 5:30 P.M. today and continues until 10:30 P.M.

ATLANTA, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Charles Morgan Jr., counsel for a former doctor whose military conviction is on appeal, changed today that Representative F. Edward Hebert, Democrat of Louisiana, had apparently tried to influence the case by writing to Chief Justice Warren E. Burger.

The Xerox Corporation's computer subsidiary, known until yesterday as the Scientific Data Systems, or SDS for short, will no longer be confused with The Students for a Democratic Society, the campus rebel group that bears the same initials.

MADRID, Oct. 1 -- Spain applied a modest amount of additional pressure on Gibraltar today to mark the expiration of the United Nations General Assembly's deadline calling for the tiny British-held colony to be turned over to this country.
WARSAW, Oct. 1 -- Consultations begun in Moscow today by the Polish Communist party chief, Wladyslaw Gomulka, are thought here to be centering on West Germany.

FEW exhibitors have enjoyed the success in any breed attained by Glenna and the late Robert Crafts of Stew, Ohio. Comparative newcomers -- their Crafdal Farm was not registered until 1958 -- they have done it the hard way.

Joe Namath said yesterday that "more than likely" this would be his last season in pro football. But the flamboyant quarterback of the world champion New York Jets added that he would not make a firm decision until after the current campaign ends.

Representative Mario Biaggi said yesterday that he would seek a court order from Kings County Supreme Court for an autopsy on a marine recruit who was buried in a Booklyn cemetery after he died during training at Parris Island last July.
The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., re-i ported yesterday that salesi and profits rose in the fiscal] second quarter and first half, ended Aug. 23.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- A leader of the rebellious group of civil rights lawyers in the Justice Department has been forced to resign after criticizing an action by Attorney General John N. Mitchell in open court.

An object radiating waves of the most energetic form known to science -- the so-called gamma rays -- has been discovered in the constellation Sagittarius. It is the first such point source of gamma rays detected in the heavens.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 1 -- For companies seeking an intimate annual stockholders' meeting, away from the hurly-burly of the big city and the noisy stockholders asking where the money went, the Madison Square Garden Corporation has the answer.

The city's Board of Ethics ruled unanimously yesterday that Mayor Lindsay did not violate the Code of Ethics last month when he accepted a free ride on a plane owned by a drug company doing business with the city.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 1 -- South Korea showed off its military might today in a massive Armed Forces Day parade here during which President Chung Hee Park declared that his country was "fully prepared to crush" any new North Korean aggression.

TOULOUSE, France, Oct. 1 -- The Concorde, the British-French jet transport, broke the sound barrier today for the first time. The news spurred British and French hopes of gaining a big slice of the commercial airliner market -- largely at the expense of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The White House acknowledged today that President Nixon was involved in shaping the decision to drop murder charges against eight Special Forces soldiers in South Vietnam.
If there's a better 2-year-old around than Silent Screen, he hasn't stuck his head out of the barn yet.
British Government bonds led prices on the London Stock Exchange higher yesterday in moderately active trading.

NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 1 -- Workers streaming into the Western Electric Company plant for the 6 A.M. shift today found their new United States Representative-elect, Michael J. Harington, at the gate to thank them for their support.
NEWARK, Oct. 1 -- Capt. Robert F. Marasco dismissed as "ridiculous" today the Army's charge that he was the Green Beret "triggerman" who shot and killed a reputed Vietnamese double agent.
The familiar claws of tight credit and Vietnam peace frustration raked the stock market anew yesterday. Prices appeared to be poised for a critical test of the 1969 lows.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 1 -- Bartolomeo Giaccone of White Plains owns only one horse and tonight he brought his entire family to Roosevelt Raceway to see this horse -- Jack Minbar -- take the richest New York Sire Stakes event in history.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- The Netherlands denounced aircraft hijacking today as a "growing menace" and asked that the General Assembly consider the subject of piracy in the air as a matter of urgency.

A SUPERLATIVE documentary, "In Search of Rembrandt," that beautifully and imaginatively used the television medium to explain to a general audience the genius and complexity of the artist, was presented last night by National Educational Television.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 1 -- Olof Palme, the Minister of Education, was elected today as the leader of the Social Democratic party and, in effect, Sweden's next Premier. A fiery and controversial man, Mr. Palme, 42 years old, succeeds Tage Erlander, who is retiring as party leader and Premier after 23 consecutive years in office.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 1 -- A Soviet Embassy spokesman tonight denounced as a "provocation from beginning to end" the Lebanese Government's charge that two Russians had tried to steal a Lebanese jet fighter plane.
A $5-million libel suit against I. D. Robbins, a housing expert and former president of the City Club, was dismissed yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Paul A. Fino.

Marya Mannes's characterization (letter Sept. 27) of those voters favoring John Marchi and Mario Procaccino as people who prefer leaders sharing "their own mediocrities," demonstrates in part why John Lindsay may well be defeated in November.
The special sanitation force that worked the four September Sundays will be extended "through October and November," Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

Robert M. Smith's Sept. 24 news article "U.S. Debating a Cutback in Germ War Stockpile" admirably summarizes our Vietnam use of chemical antipersonnel weapons such as the tear gas CS but omits mention of our much more massive use of chemical crop killers and defoliants.
Amid cries of "Shalom" from well-wishers, Premier Golda Meir of Israel ended a three-day visit to New York yesterday and flew to Los Angeles.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 -- The executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. decided today to recommend the expulsion of the 89,000-member International Chemical Workers Union for joining the Alliance for Labor Action of the teamsters and the auto workers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- It may take four to six more days of trading before the West German mark, floating freely since Tuesday, will settle at a level that the Bonn Government will accept as a basis for a parity change.

Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, told a large audience of businessmen yesterday that "we must not lose our cool if we see a good many of the wrong things entering the picture."
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 1 -- Jim Wright, the Long Island open champion, scored a three-under-par 67 today to share the 36-hole lead at 138 in the Metropolitan open golf championship with Tom Nieporte.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Describing himself as a concerned grandparent, Senator Barry Goldwater urged Congress today to crack down on "smut peddlers" using the mails to pander to children.
Having caused quite a stir in test markets with its Snack Pack -- single serving desserts in flip-top cans -- Hunt-Wesson is now introducing it into three major markets.
The Union Pacific Corporation, the holding company formed earlier this year to acquire control of the Union Pacific Railroad, announced yesterday revenue and earnings gains for the third quarter.

EXPERTS in this country have a strong aversion to individual tournaments because they dislike having to play with players of lesser ability. This aversion is not shared by the Europeans because the organizers of tournaments there are prepared to risk a little unpopularity by inviting the players they consider the strongest for such an event.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 1 -- Mexico's opposition student leaders said today that they would try to attend a memorial mass tomorrow in a small church near the site of an attack by army troops on a student rally a year ago.
PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The French Government expressed its displeasure today over distortions in Common Market agricultural rules touched off by the higher "floating" rate for the West German mark.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Representative Chalmers P. Wylie said today that former military newsmen had told him that statements by Congressmen and South Vietnamese leaders and reports of enemy violations of cease-fires had been banned by the United States Armed Forces Radio in South Vietnam.
ATLANTA, Oct. 1 -- A little statue of Charlie Brown rests on the desk of Luman Harris, but there is no similarity between the comic strip manager and the field boss of the Atlanta Braves.

The president of the New York branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, yesterday termed Representative Adam Clayton Powell "an Uncle Tom," a "hoax" and a "plague on this community" in the controversy over the State Office Building to be built in Harlem.

Cohn in Federal court yesterday, volunteered that, "in fairness to the defendants," he should explain that he had several motives other than alleged threats by Mr. Cohn for selling his stock in Fifth Avenue Coach Lines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The following is the text of the opening portion of the 230-page report of the Commission on International Development, headed by Lester B. Pearson, former Prime Minister of Canada. The commission was asked by the World Bank to examine the entire issue of aid for development of the poorer countries, and the report was made to the bank and generally distributed today.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Dame Margot Fonteyn flew from London to the United States yesterday after several days of frantic effort to cope with a financial crisis at the Royal Academy of Dancing, of which she is president. WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- A strike by Local 6 of the newspaper pressmen's union forced Washington's three daily newspapers to suspend publication today.
The New York Yankees, closing out the American League season with a flourish, won their fifth straight game last night and their second in succession over Cleveland, 4-3.

Good weather and an extra shopping day has made it possible for New York's leading department stores to achieve a sizable gain in September, according to a survey made yesterday.

Four leading city organizations have joined with the Citizens Voter Registration Campaign to urge major changes in the state's election law. The aim is to provide more time for registering and to simplify procedures here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- With few exceptions, President Nixon's appointees to Federal office have been distinguished chiefly for their lack of distinction. Clement F. Haynsworth, the South Carolina judge whom he proposes to seat on the Supreme Court, is no exception.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Planning to spend two days on what took the Senate eight weeks, the House opened debate today on its $21.3-billion version of the 1969 military appropriation bill. There appeared to be no question that the House would approve the Administration's Safeguard missile defense system, together with virtually all the other weapons provided for in the Defense Department measure.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The French Government today named Rene Nicoly, a man largely unknown, as the new director of the Paris Opera. There were educated guesses that he would not really be in charge of carrying out a reform that may not be a reform at all.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Rhetoric filtering through the White House these days has a familiar ring to it, evoking memories of Lyndon Johnson's efforts to shore up public support for the Vietnam war.

A CYNIC might suggest that there are only two kinds of laughter -- manic and depressive. Both receive a thorough workout in Jules Feiffer's "Little Murders," a comic horror story that is still fast catching up on reality at the Circle in the Square.
An automated system of making markets in over-the-counter securities was introduced yesterday by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, the brokerage house.
District 65 of the National Council of Distributive Workers has withdrawn 7,000 members from the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York (HIP), protesting a 37 per cent rate rise earlier this year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The New York Mets returned to their favorite battleground today and, with nothing at stake but their pride, defeated the Chicago Cubs in 12 innings for their ninth straight victory and No. 100 of the never-never season.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 1 -- The Rev. James E. Groppi, who has led three days of protests against welfare cuts here, was arrested for disorderly conduct today and held in the Dane County jail after refusing $50 personal bond.

A Bronx bartender, who had pleaded guilty to criminal contempt for refusing to answer questions of a grand jury investigating organized crime, changed his plea to not guilty yesterday when he came up for sentencing in State Supreme Court.

Men and women concerned about the drug problem on the lower East Side charged yesterday that the City Department of Social Services had refused to pressure addicts to "kick the habit," partly because a substantial part of the department's staff were drug users themselves.

The disclosure that a man who was ousted from the city's employ for political relations with notorious gangsters is about to be chosen judge of the Civil Court perfectly illustrates the corruption of the present system of electing judges.
Frozen pork bellies continued to set new life-of-contract highs yesterday, indicating possible higher prices for bacon.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday described as "scandalous" the unopposed candidacy for the Manhattan Civil Court of Philip J. Zichello, who was once forced to resign from a city job because he had been linked to racketeers.

THE recent 1969 Canadian championship in Pointe Claire, Que., which was also a zonal tournament, wound up in a first-place tie between International Master Duncan Suttles of Vancouver, B. C., and Zvonko Vranesic of Weston, Canada.
BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 1 -- Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart today reaffirmed in strong terms the Labor Government's determination to bring Britain into the European Common Market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Nixon Administration, as it approaches the start of talks on control of strategic arms, is conducting an intensive review of all its espionage capabilities to determine what types of accords the nation can live with if on-site inspection cannot be negotiated.
The Interim Board of Education, citing a need for continuity of leadership said yesterday that it had dropped a plan to rotate its top two posts among its members every three months.
When people talk about the Chicago Bears' offense, they usually are referring to the powerful running attack led by Gale Sayers and Ron Bull.
The money and capital markets, which nearly became disorderly early in the week, regained some of their equilibrium yesterday.
The National Broadcasting Company has won exclusive United States television rights to the 1972 Winter Olympic Games in Sapporo, Japan.
PETE ROZELLE, pro football's commissioner, said yesterday that he was about to begin negotiations with the networks over new television contracts that would run for three years beginning in 1970.
AMCHITKA ISLAND, Alaska, Oct. 1 -- Marine helicopters evacuated about 80 men from this island tonight, clearing the way for tomorrow's underground nuclear weapons test.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Democratic leaders were jubilant today over the election of a young antiwar liberal to a House seat in Massachusetts that had been in Republican hands for generations.

HONG KONG, Oct. 1 -- Considering the great symbolic importance of the occasion, celebrations in Peking today of the 20th anniversary of Communist rule in China appear to have been comparatively routine.

A freelance photographer who took pictures of Mrs. Aristotle S. Onassis and her son, John F. Kennedy Jr., bicycling in Central Park last week, pleaded not guilty in Criminal Court yesterday to charges of harassment.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Nixon Administration has signaled a slowdown and stretchout for the Model Cities urban-aid program by cutting $215-million from planned expenditures this year.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- European trading in the floating mark was quieter today, but rates continued to rise with Paris at one time quoting nearly 6 per cent over the former fixed parity.

Landlords appeared yesterday to be complying with the new city rent law in their October billings, according to Jason B. Nathan, the Housing and Development Administrator. "I am cautiously encouraged," he said.
Brokerage advertising is in as much of a slump as the market, with some ad budgets slashed as much as 50 per cent.
The art of the Calypsonian was explained and explored last night by a Calypsonian named John L. at the Folklore Center, 321 Avenue of the Americas.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Oct. 1 -- The Roman alphabet has virtually disappeared from public view here in favor of Arabic, in one of the first visible effects of the revolution that brought down the Libyan monarchy on Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1, (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that enrollment of Negroes in colleges increased 85 per cent from 1964 to 1968.

ROME, Oct. 1 -- Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe expressed informally today his personal sympathy with the move by Alitalia, the Italian air line, to reduce trans-Atlantic air fares by unilateral action.
A breakdown on a Babylon train west of the Freeport station yesterday morning caused delays of up to 40 minutes on all Long Island Rail Road trains entering and leaving Pennsylvania Station.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Oct. 1 -- Presiding Justice George J. Beldock of the Appellate Division said today that he would start an inquiry into the circumstances under which State Supreme Court Justice Arthur M. Cromarty signed a court order clearing title to a parcel of land for a corporation in which he was a partner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Republican leaders, continuing appeals for national unity on Vietnam, quoted President Nixon today as restating that he refuses to be "the first President to preside over an American defeat."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The threat of a national railroad shutdown this weekend appeared today to be forcing the Nixon Administration into the role of reluctant mediator in a major labor-management dispute.

An English-language version of the noted first novel, "One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich" by the Soviet author, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, has been scheduled for production next January in Norway by a combination of three British, American and Norwegian companies.
Mayor Lindsay told the faculty senate of the City University late yesterday that the city had "been forced to play the politics of scarcity" with the educational future of its youth.
A computer that will reduce from minutes to seconds the time it takes the city's police to dispatch a patrol car to help a citizen in trouble was inaugurated yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

Shortly before Election Day last year, candidate Richard Nixon said that the American people needed "new ideas, new men and new leadership . . . to bring an end to the war." The American people agreed and gave the Republican challenger a clear mandate to do the job.

The military-industrial-Congressional complex will have hit a new high in arrogant expropriation of public funds if the House supinely passes a $52-million addition to the military authorization bill introduced at the last minute by Chairman L. Mendel Rivers of the Armed Services Committee.

Representatives of leading conservation groups met yesterday with chief proponents of birth control and voluntary sterilization to discuss the problems of overpopulation and the deterioration of the earth's surface.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- As a contribution to the cause of militant feminism, "There'll Be Some Changes Made," at the Fortune Theater, has the distinction of being written by a man. Alun Owen's comedy is a four-character one for two couples.
A major insurance company disclosed here yesterday that it was studying methods of obtaining a seat on the New York Stock Exchange.

The city's newly created Commission on Inflation released a staff report yesterday contending that Federal restrictions on the importation of foreign oil were costing New York City residents more than $95-million a year.

New York's three candidates for Mayor are spending $523,000 for television and radio commercials, but the sum may go higher, depending upon contributions, which in turn depend upon the candidates' standings in preference polls.
Nathaniel R. Jones, a 43-year-old Negro lawyer was appointed general counsel of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday.

THE children had a wonderful time, getting almost as much dirt on themselves and on each other as on the bulbs they were planting 3 inches deep in soil that the Department of Parks had insisted couldn't grow anything.
BONN, Oct. 1 -- The Social Democrats and Free Democrats negotiating on a coalition to govern West Germany, reached agreement tonight on foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Senate Labor Committee approved today a bill to authorize $2.34-billion for the antipoverty program in the current year. That is $292-million more than President Nixon asked.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Grape growers and union organizers fought another round today over the right of the union to organize farm workers.

After six months of "talking across the table," a group of black artists has won special recognition from the Whitney Museum of American Art. The museum will stage a "major" black artists' exhibition next year, and it has established a fund for the acquisition of works by the younger and lesser-known among them.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 1 -- Representative William T. Cahill, the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, today accused former Gov. Robert B. Meyner, the Democratic candidate, of having precipitated the state's "crisis in higher education," and Mr. Meyner charged Mr. Cahill with voting against a number of urban aid programs in Congress.

The chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that for the first time telephone equipment was being diverted to the New York City area from areas that are less hard-pressed.

Kirk Kerkorian confirmed yesterday that about 1.4 million shares of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., had been tendered to him as a result of his recent tender offer but added that he would accept only 620,000 of them.

Emerson Boozer, running back for the New York Jets stood in the middle of the dressing room at Shea Stadium yesterday. He had two strips of tape hanging down from his upper lip like a Fu Manchu mustache, as he gave an imitation of Joe Namath calling signals.

The high quality of the judicial appointments announced by Mayor Lindsay yesterday only proves once again how much better it is that judges be appointed than elected. The contrast is striking between the caliber of the men just named by the Mayor to the city bench and that of a man just picked by local bosses as the one and only candidate in a forthcoming judicial election.

With only five days left to achieve the excellence of service promised by Governor Rockefeller, the Long Island Rail Road reported that about 5,000 commuters were delayed during yesterday's morning rush hour because of equipment trouble on five trains.

It was opening day for classes at the new Juilliard School at Lincoln Center, and the clock in the north lobby read 3:30. Upstairs, at the second-floor reception desk the clock stood at 6:08. Something was plainly wrong with the music school's opening tempo.

A corporation that buys $12-million annually in New York City Medicaid claims at a 10 per cent discount, and six of its officers were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the securities laws and conspiring to defraud the Government in the administration of the Medicaid program.
A last-minute effort to halt the Broadway opening last night of "The New Music Hall of Israel" failed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Assistant Attorney General Jerris Leonard defended the Nixon Administration's school desegregation policy today calling its critics "a lot of people who are frankly running off at the mouth."

The attempt of the New York City welfare officials to minimize their culpability in making unauthorized welfare payments is understandable. They have a duty to explain and the people have a right to know. The explanation, in at least one significant respect, is misleading and cruel.

A selective list o/ restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis o/ /our stars to none. The criterion is the ]ood and service in relation to the cost.
Prices of Government securities rose yesterday as the market, with no help this time from the Federal Reserve, continued to move up from the record lows reached early this week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it may soon limit the use of an artificial sweting chemical named cyclamate, which is widely used in soft drinks and diet foods.
The decision to build the SST is a misguided application of Federal funds in the air transportation industry. [Editorial, Sept. 28.]

Rain and not the Cleveland Indians kept the New York Yankees from achieving a break-even won-lost record last night as a downpour at the Stadium a few minutes before game time caused the cancellation of the season's finale.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2 -- Throughout the rainy day in this picturesque and horse-conscious Blue Grass country, the nicest things were being said about and predicted for Lindy's Pride in tomorrow's $64,757 Kentucky Futurity.
WASHINGTON -- Wendell Castle of Scottsville, N. Y., made a desk with a top of silver leaf and a protruding arm that keeps people from getting too close to the person behind.

Ralph S. Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, indicated yesterday that the exchange was studying the possibility of joining forces with the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange and the Midwest Stock Exchange to set up a nationwide clearing network.

TRENTON, Oct. 2 -- Former Gov. Robert B. Meyner, the Democratic candidate for Governor today accused Representative William T. Cahill, the Republican nominee, of using his Congressional office to block a post exchange liquor store at Fort Dix in behalf of off-post commercial liquor interests who paid him a fee.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Thousands of young Palestinians in Israeli-occupied territory can show off high school diplomas this week as a result of delicate negotiations by United Nations officials that entailed the cooperation of Israel and the United Arab Republic.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 2 -- New England's largest antiques show opened here today in the State Armory on Broad Street, and it not only has wares of often dazzling interest to collectors but some largely hidden antiquarian assets from old houses, too.
Another defection from the ranks of senior management at Eastern Air Lines became imminent yesterday.
The Interim Board of Education yesterday approved the construction of 64 "minischools" by June, 1971 to relieve overcrowding and shorttime instruction in the city's elementary-school system.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- A major study program of the National Heart Institute, which has collected invaluable data on heart attack rests for almost 20 years, is being closed down for lack of about $400,000 and about 20 staff positions.
ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 2 -- The new Government of Ghana will give its highest priority to agricultural expansion, Brig. A. A. Afrifa, the head of the Presidential commission, said today.

BONN, Oct. 2 -- As the "floating" mark traded today at 5.5 per cent above its official rate, a decision to end the uncertainties of free movement by pegging the mark to a new official parity was expected to be annouuced shortly, perhaps within days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, called today for a cease-fire and stand-fast in Vietnam, saying the United Stated should announce that its troops would fire only if they were attacked.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- North Vietnam refused today to provide any information on American prisoners of war on the ground that President Nixon had not replied "seriously" to the Vietcong's 10-point peace proposal.

Samuel Bronston, 61-year-old motion picture producer, was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on perjury charges growing out of an investigation into the bankruptcy of a corporation he owned.

It is inconceivable that Operation Intercept, or any other present law-enforcement program, will prove to be a solution to America's "drug problem," since the basis of this problem is not ineffective law enforcement, but rather a lack of scientific knowledge concerning the long-term effects of drug use.

THE big work on last night's New York Philharmonic concert, all hour-plus of it, was Carl Orff's "Carmina Burana." It is no stranger to New York and has constantly been in the repertory ever since its introduction to this country about 15 years ago (although it was composed in 1937).

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 2 -- George Meany opened the convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations here today with sharp criticism of the Nixon Administration's domestic policies.

Three creative men have left Jack Tinker Partners, a highly-regarded but troubled agency, to join Papert, Koenig, Lois Advertising, another highly regarded but troubled agency. They may ultimately get to run the place.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Hsieh Yung-Yo of Nationalist China led 90 of the world's best golfers with a five-under-par 66 today, but a 67 by Orville Moody gained the United States a tie with the Taiwan team for the first-round team lead in the World Cup competition.

THERE are spectacles at which performers and spectators ignite one another in contagious joy. It can happen at rare political rallies or, more recently, at Shea Stadium. Last night it happened at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, where "The New Music Hall of Israel" opened what is scheduled to be at least a nine-week engagement.

LINDENHURST, L.I., Oct. 2 -- The Suffolk County Medical Society is investigating the alleged refusal of a physician to leave his office to aid an 18-month-old girl who had fallen into her family's fishpond. The child die.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Much of the talk of the capital these days is about talk, or as a good Republican would put it, communication.

Fifty members of Students for a Democratic Society and the Medical Liberation Front at Columbia University disrupted a speech last night by Dr. Gerald S. Dorman, president of the American Medical Association.
Mayor Lindsay asked the Board of Ethics yesterday to investigate a European trip taken by four city officials under the auspices of an organization doing business with the city.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 2 -The Lebanese military authorities today banned the publication in Lebanon or transmission abroad of any further reports about the alleged attempt to steal a Mirage jet fighter.
TOKYO, Oct. 2 -- Japan's reserves of gold and foreign exchange reached $3,226,000,000 at the end of September, the highest level in the country's history.
A 91-count case of criminal contempt against John (Gentleman Johnny) Masiello was completed in little more than an hour yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court.

For six months, John V. Lindsay, Mario A. Procaccino and John J. Marchi campaigned for Mayor without all appearing before the same audience. And when they finally did, it turned out to be the wrong audience for each of them.
LESS than a week after being turned down virtually at the altar by one corporate suitor, the House of Valentino yesterday published its marriage banns with another.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Oct. 2 -- The United States is beginning a withdrawal from "revolutionary Libya" that seems almost certain to include the ultimate shutdown of the air base at Wheelus Field, on the outskirts of Tripoli.

Volunteers who have given their mornings and afternoons to the children at Bellevue Hospital will have an evening for themselves Thursday. But the children won't be neglected: The proceeds from the party, a $40-a-person dinner dance at the Plaza, will go to the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue, the organization that sponsors the volunteer activities.

SAIGON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The United States Command reported that American units had fought only four significant skirmishes over the last 24 hours. Two Americans were killed and four wounded in these actions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- "I've been pallbearer to six of my friends who told me to diet. You don't want to be the seventh," Representative John C. Kluczynski, Democrat of Illinois, said he tells friends who fuss at him about food.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Senate passed 73 to 0, today a far-ranging bill designed to protect the nation's 130,000 coal miners from black lung disease and underground explosions.
BONN, Oct. 2 -- "The commuter party," a Social Democrat said today with disdain about West Germany's Free Democratic party and what he regarded as its inclination to travel to places of power.

Trespassing charges against Robert (Sonny) Carson, head of Independent Brooklyn CORE, and several other Congress of Racial Equality members, stemming from a 1967 sit-in, were dropped yesterday in Brooklyn Criminal Court.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 2 -- Indians celebrated the centenary of the birth of Gandhi today by acknowledging that too often his precepts of non-violence and Hindu-Moslem amity are being ignored by his countrymen.

In another move to build better relations with its neighbors, Columbia University has joined with a community group to build a playground for neighborhood use on university-owned property off the campus.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- An Army colonel told a Senate inquiry today that a former provost marshal general had ordered criminal investigation records altered to omit references to William O. Wooldridge, then Sergeant Major of the Army.
State Senator John J. Marchi proposed yesterday a six-state attack on organized crime through establishment of a bipartisan Northeast Regional Commission of Investigation.

IF your name was Leek and you built boats for a living, wouldn't you change the name of your company? Right, and that is what John and Cecil Leek of Lower Bank, N. J., did in 1966, transforming C. P. Leek Sons into Pacemaker Corporation.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 2 (AP) -Arthur Ashe and Cliff Richey moved into the semifinals of the Pacific Coast international tennis tournament today with straight-set victories.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Forging ahead toward a foregone conclusion, the International Monetary Fund cast ballots today on a compromise plan to distribute $9.5-billion in "paper gold."

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The ironic Jean Anouilh is in a capricious mood in his new comedy, "Cher Antoine," which opened at the Comedie des Champs-Elysees last night. It is a play-within-a-play-within-a-play, and within it a Pirandello-esque author seeks the characters that have molded his personality and career.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright, Chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, told the Senate today that the Air Force had decided to send more planes to a base in Spain without informing the State Department or the Defense Department's Section of International Security Affairs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- A move to block deployment of the Safeguard antiballistic missile system was rejected by the House today after a scant four hours of debate.
The Hertz Corporation announced yesterday that it plans to buy 125,000 new 1970 cars and trucks valued at about $505-million.
A champagne reception on the mezzanine of the City Center will follow Tuesday evening's performance of the City Center Joffrey Ballet.

AMCHITKA ISLAND, Oct. 2 -- The controversial underground test of a hydrogen bomb was carried out today as planned on the south end of this island. A strong ground motion, lasting about 40 seconds, shook the control center 40 miles away.

James Reston in his Sept. 26 column says President Nixon cannot achieve his "one limited objective" (quoting the President) of giving "the South Vietnamese people what they want" unless he knows what they want. And he cannot know this, observes Mr. Reston, without fair elections, which cannot be held under the present Government.

Don Elliott Heald, general manager of WSB-TV in Atlanta, disassociated his station yesterday from last week's action of four Southeastern broadcasting organizations in asking for the removal of Nicholas Johnson as a member of the Federal Communications Commission.
The union that represents maintenance and service employes at 24 proprietary hospitals announced last night that it would strike seven hospitals this morning.

A spokesman for a group of educators supporting Controller Mario A. Procaccino charged yesterday that "two militants who tried to close the City University down" last spring were now paid workers on Mayor Lindsay's campaign staff.
BOSTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Eddie Kasko was named today as manager of the Boston Red Sox, promising to be "firm, fair and to treat ballplayers like men."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 2 -- Well-qualified informants report that military policemen investigating the kidnapping of the United States Ambassador, C. Burke Elbrick, have threatened and in at least one case used torture while interrogating persons who were later released.

Sanford D. Garelik, the Republican-Liberal candidate for City Council President, proposed yesterday that a separate court be set up for narcotic offenders and that a "Narcotics Offenders Act" be enacted to separate penalties for addicts and "hardened drug racketeers."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2 -- The United States military command announced today that 95 American soldiers died in combat last week, the lowest number in more than two years.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Secretary of State Rogers returned to Washington today after having met 77 times in 12 days with delegates to the United Nations from 70 countries.
LISBON, Oct. 2 -- Calouste Gulbenkian's "lifelong friends" were finally reunited here today with the opening of the Gulbenkian Center for Arts and Culture.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Secretary General Thant presented the General Assembly's Budget Committee today with his proposals for a record 1970 budget of $164,123,000. He cautioned that "financial malaise," caused in part by some members' refusal to pay assessments, threatened the organization's capacity to meet vital needs.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- There were unconfirmed reports in Moscow tonight of the arrival of a Chinese delegation to begin talks with the Soviet Union on resuming commercial relations, virtually paralyzed for several years.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2 -Foreign Minister Antonio Carrillo Flores said today that the United States had agreed to open high-level talks to find ways to reduce the damaging effects that the American drug blockade at the Mexican border has had on normal commerce and tourism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a suit today against one of the rapidly growing conglomerate companies, the Commonwealth United Corporation, charging it with a variety of misrepresentations and concealments concerning its financial condition and transactions.
IKOT ESOP, Nigeria, Sept. 25 -- A 4-year-old girl, long familiar with the routine, presented her thin leg to a young American physician, Dr. Beth Yankee.

American Presidential campaigns usually begin the day after Election Day, and 1972 is no exception. Every poll, every endorsement, and especially every local and state election is mulled over in much the way soothsayers once plied their comparable trade by studying the entrails of a pigeon. To any supporters of President Nixon who may be given to this arcane activity the special Congressional elections held since the fall of 1968 must seem full of foreboding.

Mayor Lindsay called yesterday for a massive Federal commitment to a nationwide Federal-state-local program of narcotics-addiction treatment and prevention. The program would cost $3-billion over the next five years, with half of that being spent in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- When Caspar Willard Weinberger, a leader of California's moderate Republicans, accepted appointment as Finance Director for Gov. Ronald Reagan, a conservative he had once opposed, he was not entirely enthusiastic.

Any frequent radio listener who is familiar with the droll tones of Stan Freberg knows from the past week's onslaught that Compoz, "that tiny blue pill," is the latest client of Freberg, Ltd. And on Sunday or Monday a TV spot will join the sales team for the over-the-counter sedative.
Commercial and industrial loans at major New York banks rose $175-million in the week ended Oct. 1, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
A laborer and the policeman who tried to rescue him were killed yesterday in "a one-in-a-million" accident when they breathed mysteriously lethal air in a water main compartment in Brooklyn.
Three persons died last night when a fire believed to have been started by an arsonist raced through the top floor of a three-story tenement in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
DETROIT, Oct. 2 -- Sales records tumbled in the automobile industry last month with introduction of the 1970 model providing the spur.

As loyal American citizens; proud of our Hispanic heritage, which has helped to enrich our great nation, we strongly protest your unwarranted and prejudiced editorial entitled "Wrong Time, Wrong Place" of Sept. 20.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2 -- Severe security measures were ordered here today to prevent public demonstrations by students on the first anniversary of the so-called "massacre of Tlatelolco" in which gunfire by troops killed at least 28 people and injured 200 at a student rally.

TALLULAH, La., Oct. 2 -- Seated in a black chair in his office, swatting flies, Tallulah's police chief, Zelma C. Wyche, today adjudged his efforts to win significant support by the town's white people to be something of a failure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Senator Charles E. Goodell said today that he may have put his political career "on the line" by proposing the withdrawal of all American troops from Vietnam by the end of next year.

Novelist, short-story writer, essayist, critic, esthetician, superintellectual -- Susan Sontag is an awesome literary lady. For many years she has harbored one large unfulfilled ambition. She wanted to direct movies.

The Gotham Chapter of the Brandeis University National Women's Committee has arranged a preview of the "Four Centuries of English Silver" exhibition for Tuesday evening at the Hartman Galleries at 978 Madison Avenue.
" Night Call," an innovative and controversial national radio program, honored four times in its 16 months on the air, will cease broadcasting next Friday. Its funding has run out.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Takeo Fukuda, the leading contender to be the next Premier of Japan, outlined proposals today for the most comprehensive change in Japanese security policy since World War II.

ATHENS, Oct. 2 -- Former Premier Constantine Caramanlis's call to the Greek armed forces to oust the country's 29-month-old military regime if its leaders refused to go was received with approval in many political quarters today.

A former executive of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines remained on close business and personal terms with Roy M. Cohn for more than four years after the executive says Mr. Cohn blackmailed him into selling his stock in the bus line in 1964, according to testimony in Federal Court yesterday.
Some old, friendly faces will be missing tonight when the Rangers make their 1969-70 debut in a National Hockey League preseason game against the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden.
MADRID, Oct. 2 -- The Spanish Government made public a new labor law today that, contrary to the hopes of some regime members, keeps control of labor union activities under tight Government rein.
The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico has embarked on a vast program to develop the largely neglected southwest third of the island, Gov. Luis A. Ferre disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Governor of West Germany's Central Bank declined to say specifically today how long the mark will "float" or what exchange rate will be established for it, but he emphasized that the current experiment "is of a temporary nature only."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- A generally pessimistic report about August conditions in manufacturing, a key sector of the economy, was issued today by the Department of Commerce.

BONN, Friday, Oct. 3 -- The Social Democratic party and the Free Democratic party announced early today, after three days of negotiations, that they had agreed on a basis for forming West Germany's next government.

A city Hospitals Department official told a legislative committee yeserday the present method of financing health and hospital care was a "disaster," and he called on the state to enact universal health insurance next year.
After dropping early in the session, stocks on the American Stock Exchange pepped up later in the day, both in prices and activity.

The formation of an educational research and consulting service to be known as the Center for Educational Inquiry was announced here yesterday by James A. Perkins, former president of Cornell University.

Victor Dubrovsky, conductor of Moscow's celebrated Osipov Balalaika Orchestra, pondered a problem: What would be exactly the right exit number to play during the group's 45-city American tour, which begins tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall?

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 2 -- A hearing was set for tomorrow in Federal District Court on appeals to free the Rev. James E. Groppi after four days of protests against welfare cuts by the State Legislature.
ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- The State Court of Appeals today reaffirmed Blue Cross rate increases averaging 43.3 per cent for 3.7 - million residents of New York City and surrounding counties.
WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 2 -- Nancy Whiskey and Lady Rica captured divisions of the $33,000 New York Sire Stakes for 2-year-old pacing fillies at rain-swept Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 2 -- Stewart L. Udall, outdoorsman, author, former Cabinet member and avid Thoreau-reader, has a new title -- adjunct professor in environmental humanism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Government denied applications for parole today from James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and Louis E. Wolfson, the multimillionaire industrialist.

The eight men who were, until this week, the defendants in the Green Beret murder case headed for their homes and a weekend of seclusion yesterday amid expressions of bitterness over the treatment they had received from the Army.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- The Soviet Union today bitterly denounced the visit of Premier Golda Meir to the United States and suggested that any further American arms shipments to Israel would indicate that the United States was not interested in settling the Middle East crisis.

LAC MABILLE, Quebec -- We slept one night at the St. Lawrence Fishing and Hunting Club's camp at Lac Mabille. A raw wind had been blowing all day, but after sunset it fell and the lake was like a shining piece of metal in the moonlight, a dull mirror from which the moon, the stars and the Northern Lights were reflected.

STOCKHOLM -- Olof Palme, who is about to be Premier of Sweden, is a small, soft-voiced man with strong opinions but a reflective manner. Each New York Met is about $10,000 richer today as a result of the team's having won the Eastern Division and National League championships. If the Mets go on to win the World Series, each man will get an additional $5,000 or more.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company "insider" case moved back into litigation yesterday in Federal Court here with the appearance of four witnesses who testified about the circumstances surrounding their sale of the company's stock in April, 1964.

Holy Cross College canceled the eight remaining football games on its schedule yesterday because of an outbreak of infectious hepatitis that had made 20 players seriously ill and the 55 others on the squad "probably ill."

Governor Rockefeller yesterday recalled his pledge to make the Long Island Rail Road the finest in the country by Oct. 7 and declared: "I'm saying that it's the best right now."

ELIOT Janeway, the economist and newsletter publisher, is of mixed mind. He's bullish on the economy -- he expects no recession -and he predicts a continued world boom.

THE Mets beat the Braves again yesterday. And what else is new? Thus did the Amazing Ones complete their stratospheric ascent from ground zero after a season that almost defies belief. By winning the National League pennant at Shea Stadium yesterday they now are entitled to go moon walking in the World Series.
Clouds sometimes have silver linings. The Government yesterday reported a substantial increase in unemployment and, as a consequence, bond prices rose and interest rates declined.

James C. Kellogg 3d, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, told Theodore Kheel yesterday that his proposal for doubling bridge tolls should be submitted "after the election" to the Legislatures of New York and New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Legislation to mint a dollar honoring the late President Eisenhower was blocked in the House at least temporarily today.

Odyssey House, a Manhattanbased institution that attempts to rehabilitate heroin addicts, has opened a special facility in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx to serve teen-agers and younger children exclusively.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported this evening.

A bit of Tin Pan Alloy was transferred yesterday to the United States Court House at Foley Square. Burton Lane, the composer, played "How Are Things in Glocca Morra?" "I can Dream, Can't I?" "It Might As Well Be Spring," "My Heart Belongs to Daddy," and "September Song" for 12 attentive jurors.

New Yorkers, historically aloof about all but the world's most spectacular events, lost their cool yesterday afternoon for the second time in less than two weeks as the magic 2 1/2 hours of the Mets' victory unfolded.

The chairman of Japan's largest commercial bank urged the United States yesterday to call a moratorium for two years on any new protectionist measures, either in the form of "tariff or non-tariff barriers."

The International Business Machines Corporation plans to tear down the 20-story office building on Madison Avenue that once served as its world headquarters and to replace it with a bigger skyscraper.

BERLIN, Oct. 6 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev of the Soviet Union and Walter Ulbricht of East Germany teamed up here today to make a guarded offer of good-neighborly relations to the next West German Government of Willy Brandt.

JONESPORT, Me. -- A large trailer truck, navigating down the narrow street of this tiny coastal town the other day, scraped some paint off the fender of a parked car. BOSTON bluefish is not a bluefish at all. It's a relative of cod and haddock and is known commonly as American pollock. Although it has been caught off Atlantic shores for years, it has not received the recognition it deserves. Now that haddock catches are small, the large muscled flesh of the pollock can be a satisfactory substitute.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Senate voted today to pump $7.5-million move into the halfcompleted John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on the banks of the Potomac.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Army announced today new assignments for seven soldiers involved in the Green Beret Vietnam incident. The assignments indicated that the Pentagon would be scrupulous in treating the men as innocent of all charges.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- The Senate Finance Committee was urged today to go after foundations that are created as tax havens by wealthy families but not to impose an income tax on foundations whose work is "the envy of the world."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Official opposition to the wearing of long hair is not peculiar to our electronic-petroleum society. Alexander the Great, believing that the beard afforded too convenient a handle to the enemy in close combat, ordered his entire army to shave.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 6 -- The Baltimore Orioles, plowing through Minnesota as easily as they did through the American League the whole year, captured their second pennant with an 11-2 victory today, and Frank Robinson immediately sounded their battle cry.

FORT WORTH, Oct. 6 -- The 10 young pianists who will advance to next week's semifinals in the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition represent four nationalities. Two are from Japan, one is Brazilian, one Mexican. Six are from the United States.

" Winter -- that's what's driving me crazy," Mrs. Margarita Robles said yesterday as she sat primly on a battered couch in the living room of the tiny six-room flat she shares with her eight children.

The London Stock Exchange registered widespread losses yesterday, due primarily to lack of buying interest.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 6 -- Earl Weaver, the youngest manager in the American League, is looking forward to playing the Mets in the World Series, and he has Billy Martin pulling for him.

The demonstration against the Vietnam war to be held next week on campuses across the country is an appeal by deeply concerned students to the nation's conscience. EARL HAMNER'S original play "Appalachian Autumn" is not a pillar of dramatic strength; nor is it immune to rudimentary theatrical excesses. JAKOV LIND'S fiction has always hit me like a local anesthetic -- a needle in the spine. The deeper things get, the less one feels. His characters cry out and inflate empty word balloons. Their blood is raspberry juice and their bones are Dresden china. Their catastrophes freeze the reader and leave him guiltily unconcerned, strangely preoccupied with the surface of Mr. Lind's art.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- What had seemed the most serious obstacle to replacing the Electoral College with a popular-vote choice of the President -- ratification of the reform plan by 38 state legislatures -- may not be so serious after all.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Wildcat strikes by refuse collectors plagued almost all of London today, and other public-service employes, such as gravediggers and lavatory attendants, joined the strikes in some areas. Some provincial towns were also affected.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Tom Cahill, Army's head football coach, will be 50 years old Saturday. Some of his friends plan a celebration in New York that evening to mark the half-century point in the life of the miracle man of The Plain.
MOSCOW, Oct. 7 -- Authoritative Soviet sources said today that Chinese agreement to hold general border talks appeared to represent a significant effort to reduce tensions.
The soaring cost of money and falling bond prices took their toll on bank earnings during the third quarter, reports published yesterday showed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- United States analysts of Chinese-Soviet relations said today that they considered the Chinese statement on border negotiations to be a major conciliatory step.
Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., announced yesterday a program that will enable investors for a 3 per cent premium to insure their portfolios against market declines.

WASHINGTON -- The National Ballet of Washington is most beautifully enterprising. It has, for example, a production of Bournonville's "La Sylphide" in its repertory, a classic 19th century ballet that is still something of a rarity in the international repertory.

THE National Broadcasting Company last night devoted virtually an entire evening of television to the obvious in journalism. Under the title "From Here to the 70's," the network unrolled yards of familiar film and tape and most of its major commentators in ornate essays that summarized the well - known complexities of the 1960's as a prelude to the next decade.
Silver futures swung high and low in trading yesterday on bullish enthusiasm later dampened by a Government comment.

Eight members of the Queens College SEEK (Search for Education, Elevation and Knowledge) program yesterday removed the furniture from the office of Dr. Ralph Lee, who was appointed director last month.

LEADING off the season's International Festival of Visiting Orchestras, presented by Carnegie Hall, was the Accademia Nazionale di Santa Cecilia, known to record buffs as the Santa Cecilia Orchestra and to others as the Orchestra of Rome.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A House committee inquiry into the reasons for rising meat prices was told today that retail costs had increased substantially faster than the amounts received by the producers.

Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., indicated yesterday that it planned to move forward with its public offering of equity as soon as possible, despite the adverse stock market conditions prevailing this year.
GENEVA, Oct. 7 -- Following is the text of a draft treaty on the prohibition of nuclear weapons on the seabed, submitted to the disarmament conference today by the United States and the Soviet Union:

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 7 -Lindy's Pride, who already has wrapped up the triple crown of trotting and needs only to win Friday night's Dexter Cup test at Roosevelt Raceway to complete the sweep of the Big Five, gained the No. 1 post position today for the season's richest trotting event.

If Governor Rockefeller aims to hold the next state budget below $7 billion, as now appears to be the case, the outlook is grim for improving state aid in such areas as education, health and welfare. Any such limitation would be a disaster to New York City and other local governments throughout the state.
It was coincidence that this year's award recital sponsored by the "Joy in Singing" organization should be given by a young woman named Joy.

The Architects' Renewal Committee in Harlem, a Federally funded organization of young city planners and architects, announced yesterday its opposition to construction of the planned state office building there.
There are 20 million households out there in America the beautiful that are especially beloved by advertisers. It's because the folks who live in them make and spend money.
The star of the show that opened at Madison Square Garden last night is Antonio Aguilar.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 7 -- Electric golf carts became an approved means of transportation today during a caddie shortage in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association championship.
A group of black intellectuals and activists called yesterday for a citywide work stoppage by black workers on Nov. 3 as a display of unity among the majority of Negroes.
" NEW BLACK ARTISTS," an exhibition of work by eight painters and four sculptors that opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum, is a show that a critic may greet with a sigh of relief.

Although a city regulation will require many grocery items to be marked with the unit price beginning Nov. 20, a food retailers association this week is promoting a pocket price computer that will help housewives figure the prices themselves.
An extension of one tender offer and the termination of a proposed merger highlighted merger and acquisition developments yesterday.

A suit seeking a Supreme Court order to open the books of the Blue Cross hospital insurance plan for audit by a court-appointed referee was announced yesterday by Controller Mario A. Procaccino, Democratic and Nonpartisan candidate for Mayor.
Six men were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring and attempting to bomb and burn two public schools in East Harlem.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 7 -- Emilio Garrastazu Medici, the little known army general named today by the country's military leaders to be the next President of Brazil, tonight promised a thorough reform program leading back to democratic institutions in the course of his term.
The London Stock Exchange continued its decline yesterday. This was the second consecutive day in which general lack of buying interest was cited for the losses.
After the Baltimore Orioles completed their demolition of the American League the other day, one of the biggest wreckers, Boog Powell, was asked about the Mets.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he had not seen "any signs" that Jesse Gray, the Harlem rent-strike leader and Democratic candidate for the City Council, was an extremist.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 7 -- Garrastazu, the name that Gen. Emilio Garrastazu Medici inherited from his Basque ancestors, means "willfullness" or "persistence."
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 7 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller of New York called today for a "politically realistic" United States approach to Latin America for its problems.
A television commercial on behalf of John V. Lindsay's campaign for re-election as mayor of New York contends that the job is the "second hardest" in the country. This may, or may not, be so.
The "Never on Sunday" trend may be on the way out among the nation's big stores.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 7 -- The Finn Class Gold Cup regatta began today with almost ideal northeast winds of 16 to 18 knots after a five-day delay because of high winds and rough seas caused by Hurricane Inga.

A play dealing with a prominent stage and film actor who appeared before a Congressional committee investigating Communist influence in Hollywood will be one of the five productions in the American National Theater and Academy special matinee series this season.
BOB MILLIGAN, Yale's sophomore flankerback, was among a quartet of newcomers in the Ivy League who earned plaudits for outstanding performances last Saturday.
The election of Warren N. Burding as chairman of the executive committee of the Lever Brothers Company was announced yesterday by Milton C. Mumford, chairman of the board.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Philip M. Crane, an outspokenly conservative lecturer and writer, won tonight from six other Republicans in a primary race for the North Shore's 13th Congressional District seat.
PRAGUE, Oct. 7 (UPI) -- A leading trade-union official demanded today that the purge of Czechoslovak liberals be extended to include organized labor.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- A thousand East German youths clashed with policemen here tonight after the police had tried repeatedly to keep them from gathering at the wall that has divided the city since 1961. Many of them apparently just wanted to see it.

Punters get noticed only when they make mistakes or don't do their jobs well. That's why Steve O'Neal, thrust into the preseason spotlight when he replaced Curley Johnson, the Jets' long-time kicker, is fast becoming a forgotten man.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Judge Julius J. Hoffman ruled today that round-the-clock police surveillance did not violate the right to privacy.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7 -- Mexicans joked this week that the name of the International Friendship Dam inaugurated on the Rio Grande a month ago by President Nixon and President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz should be changed to Dam Friendship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A Cuban MIG-17 was able to slip into Florida undetected Sunday because two of three special Air Force radar picket planes, designed to guard against just that sort of penetration, had been grounded for budgetary reasons two days before the incident, military sources said today.
PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 7 -- The New York Knickerbockers raced to their fifth National Basketaball Association preseason victory in seven tries tonight by whipping Detroit, 124-108.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 (UPI) -- Zelmo Beaty, the Atlanta Hawks' star center, signed a four-year contract with the Los Angeles Stars today and became the third National Basketball Association player in recent months to jump to the rival American Basketball Association.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 7 -- The Wisconsin Supreme Court refused today to release the Rev. James E. Groppi from jail on bail pending a decision by a lower court judge on a writ of habeas corpus.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A supporter of Clement F. Haynsworth Jr.'s Supreme Court nomination asserted today that the charges of ethical impropriety against Mr. Haynsworth had been grossly exaggerated by his opponents and by the press.
In a move aimed at diversification, Bache Co. disclosed yesterday that it had formed a new subsidiary to provide investment counseling to large investors.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 7 -- The engineer of one of two trains of the Penn Central's New Haven division that collided head on near Darien on Aug. 20 had received both written and spoken instructions to pull into a siding to allow the other train to pass, the National Transportation Safety Board was told today.

MONTREAL, Wednesday, Oct. 8 -- Montreal's 3,700 policemen struck for more money yesterday and many of the 2,400 firemen followed suit. Government leaders said that the city was "threatened by anarchy" as criminals had a field day, holding up 19 commercial establishments, 10 of them banks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Maj. Gen. Carl C. Turner, a former Provost Marshal General of the Army, who is also a former Chief United States Marshal, told a Senate inquiry today that he had received weapons at no cost from the Chicago and Kansas City, Mo., police departments.

When Sacha Distel trots out into the spotlight in the Persian Room at the Plaza Hotel, resplendent in a blue nylon velour jacket and ruffled shirt for what he refers to as "my first live appearance in New York," he brings with him a background studded with a variety of high achievements.
MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 7 (UPI) -- The "lesson plan" at Mobile County Training School next week is simple: When each World Series game starts, all classes end.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 7 -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel's intensified campaign against water polluters ran into mixed results today as hearings opened in the cases of four steel companies that discharge wastes into badly contaminated Lake Erie.
PARIS, Oct. 7 -- From 50 to 150 letters are arriving each day in an old Left Bank mansion on the Rue de Varenne that has been converted into Government offices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) -- The United States potash industry, located principally in New Mexico, is "in a precarious position" because of imports from Canada, the state's two Senators told the United States Tariff Commission today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Cuba today spurned all cooperation with the Organization of American States, even to halt recent "piracy" of aircraft and ships, for which she blamed the United States and its allies.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- A clash in East Berlin yesterday between policemen and 1,000 youths was preceded by a demonstration in which slogans were shouted against the Communist leadership of Walter Ulbricht.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) -- The Chairman of one of President Nixon's economic task forces suggested today its report was being kept secret because it was unpopular at the Justice Department.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 8 -- Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian playwright whose works have appeared on New York and London stages, was released from political detention today after more than two years in prison.
United States business going abroad will have an easier time cutting through the red tape of customs arrangements for goods they plan to take along for display purposes.

HOLY CROSS expects to play its 10-game varsity football schedule in 1970 despite the fact that it canceled its remaining eight games this year because of an outbreak of hepatitis that infected all 75 members of the team.

WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 8 -- The Representative Town Meeting here -- a successor to the old-time New England town meeting -- usually concerns itself with such issues as local school budgets and sewage-disposal plants, but early this morning it passed a resolution asking President Nixon and Congress "to take immediate action to withdraw from the war in Vietnam."

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 8 -- One hundred members of the Princeton University faculty, expressing opposition to the war in Vietnam, voted this afternoon to "encourage participation in the Oct. 15 moratorium."

The rare-coin collection of the late Cardinal Spellman, said to be worth at least $500,000, has been sold to a dealer here, with the proceeds earmarked for aid to needy youths, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy took the unusual step today of issuing a formal statement in an attempt to make "crystal clear" the Admin istration's belief that "any unemployment in our country, however small, is an unhappy condition."
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Oct. 8 -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel was repeatedly booed and jeered and was barely able to finish a speech today before an all-Indian audience.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- John W. Gardner, the Republican who heads the Urban Coalition, is seriously concerned over what he regards as a lack of leadership and forward movement by the Nixon Administration in critical domestic areas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Sufferers from the "noise pollution" of jet aircraft gathered here today to plan some counternoise of their own, and also just to commiserate about the torture of living near big airports.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 8 -- A dusty, battered United States Army truck bearing 10 Vietnamese children pulled up one recent afternoon in front of a modern gray-stone building in the Saigon suburb of Cholon.
PARIS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- America's three Apollo 11 astronauts got medals and friendly cheers from thousands of Parisians today.
FORT WORTH, Oct. 8 -- For the first time in a decade, a new type of bomber, the FB-111A, was added today to the Strategic Air Command fleet.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- The war in Vietnam is giving doctors special problems in predicting which of the wounded will live and which will die, a panel of military surgeons said here today.
Increases in the price of aluminum were extended to international markets yesterday following price increases in this country earlier in the week.

Controller Mario A. Procaccino, in an interim audit made public yesterday, challenged the "legality and propriety" of the $259,594 paid to Norman Frank by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association Health and Welfare Fund over a six-year period.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Nixon Administration won a narrow victory today as the House turned down a proposed $1-billion appropriation to finance grants to states and local communities for water treatment facilities in the fight for clean water.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 8 -- Six staff members of the Rand Corporation, all of whom have done research on Vietnam for the Federal Government, have urged the United States to make a unilateral withdrawal of its troops from South Vietnam within a year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Dr. Pyotr L. Kapitsa, dean of Soviet physicists, aligned himself today with a little-heard-from group of Soviet scientists who believe in the ultimate convergence of the Soviet and American systems of government.
Mayor Lindsay pledged yesterday that his first task during the next four years if he is re-elected would be to build "a government of reconciliation."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Harry said, "Why don't we go to see 'I Am Curious (Yellow)' tomorrow afternoon? WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The State Department suggested today that further negotiations between the Justice Department and two big oil companies could result in a settlement of legal issues under which the companies could go ahead with a merger.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird, contending that his predecessor, Robert S. McNamara, held the job too long, says he plans to run the Defense Department only through President Nixon's first term.

CAIRO, Oct. 8 -- The United Arab Republic emphasized again today that it saw possibilities for seeking an Arab-Israeli settlement in a "Rhodes formula" of indirect discussions through an intermediary. It insisted, however, that such bargaining must under no circumstances "be construed as direct talks."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission asked for comments today from all interested parties on the proposed new rules of the New York Stock Exchange covering public ownership of member firms.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Nixon's proposal to convert the Post Office Department into a public corporation was rejected today by the House Post Office Committee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8 -- Frank Champi, who came off the Harvard bench last year to direct the Crimson's great closing rally against Yale that produced a tie for the Ivy League championship, has left the 1969 football squad after two games.

HONG KONG, Oct. 8 -- The announcement by Peking yesterday of an agreement to hold border talks with the Soviet Union was a maneuver in the best tradition of Mao Tse-tung's classic precept of people's war.
TEL AVIV, Oct. 8 (Reuters) -- Israeli jets struck twice today against an Arab guerrilla base in Jordan, a military spokesman said.

Dr. Arthur C. Logan, former chairman of Haryou-Act, yesterday assaliled the involvement of the Democratic county leaders in the selection of members of a new corporation to operate the city's hospitals.
