HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 8 -- Thomas Lundquist, a youthful Swede with a lot of experience in dinghies but not very well known with Finn Class sloops, was winner of the second race in the Finn Gold Cup series being sailed this week in Bermuda.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- In the light of a recent court decision, the Patent Office is receding from its firm stand against patenting software, or computer programs.
The Soviet-American agreement on a treaty to ban nuclear weapons on the sea floor offers the Geneva Disarmament Conference something to show for its labors -- but not much.

CRESSKILL, N.J., Oct. 8 -- The Northern Valley Chapter for Project Hope, which helps support the hospital ship Hope, has arranged luncheons for Oct. 22 and 23, and a masked ball for Oct. 24, all at the Tammy Brook Country Club here. A fashion show will be part of each event.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Clement F. Haynsworth Jr.'s prospects for confirmation as a Supreme Court Justice suffered a severe setback today when two members of the Senate Republican leadership announced their opposition to the nomination.

SOMEWHERE in the vastness of Lake Ontario, the survivors among 25,000 young cohoe salmon stocked in the spring of last year are headed back to the scenes of their childhood as mature, eight-to-10-pound fish.

BONN, Oct. 8 -- West Germany's outgoing Cabinet decided today to ease the "floating" mark's effect on exports by shelving temporarily the 4 per cent tax on exports it introduced last November as a substitute for an upward revaluation.
The son of a New York policeman and an honor student from Yonkers will be in the Notre Dame line-up Saturday when the Irish face Army at Yankee Stadium.
The New York Mets announced yesterday a sellout of all box and reserved seat tickets for the World Series games at Shea Stadium. Fans were urged to stop sending mail orders for tickets.

Jervis Langdon Jr., chairman and president of the Chicago, Rock Island, Pacific Railroad, told the line s stockholders yesterday that after having "taken a look" at a preliminary budget for 1970, the outlook for that financially ailing carrier is "alarming."

IN a day when concert programs, and especially violin programs, are as standardized as the contents of a barrel of tenpenny nails, Ruggiero Ricci has come up with something new. The eminent violinist, leading off the centennial concert series of St. John's University last night in Philharmonic Hall, did have a conventional first half.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Controversial Rich Allen, the hard-hitting first baseman of the Philadelphia Phillies, was traded to the St. Louis Cardinals today in a seven-player deal that brought Tim McCarver, a catcher, and Curt Flood, an outfielder, to the Phillies.

I am fearful that recent criticism of the Federal Trade Commission will blunt the impact of the exceedingly important work which the commission performs in attacking anti-competitive practices and protecting consumers against deception.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on legislation designed to help thousands of college students obtain tuition loans from private lending institutions.
Vincent Aparo, one of 22 witnesses indicted last spring for defiance of Bronx grand jury investigating organized crime, received the maximum sentence yesterday of one year in prison.

August Heckscher, the head of the city's park system, and his predecessor. Thomas P. F. Hoving, charged yesterday that Controller Mario A. Procaccino's recent white paper on parks was "an extraordinary act of plagiarism" from the Lindsay white paper of 1965.

If style -- and stylistic distinctions -- were all there was to singing, Paul Sperry's recital in Alice Tully Hall last night would have been a major event of the season. As it was, the tenor's program, distinguished in content and artfully performed, provided an unusually rewarding evening.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Oct. 4 -- The days are growing warmer in this Indian Ocean metropolis, with its graceful palm trees and bustling harbor, as spring gradually gives way to summer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The House Agriculture Committee voted approval today of a $610-million food stamp program for the current fiscal year. But the committee left dangling a Senate-passed plan to broaden efforts aimed at feeding the poor.
Prices declined on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, closing near the day's lows in quiet trading.

Representatives of 16 medical schools and research institutes reported yesterday they had been forced to curtail their programs drastically because of cutbacks in Medicaid reimbursements and Federal research grants.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 8 -- Lindy's Pride a 10-time winner in 16 outings this season, was barred today from the betting in Friday night's $175,955.91 Dexter Cup Trot for 3-year-olds at Roosevelt Raceway.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 8 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Colts traded a promising young linebacker, Ron Porter, today after he was dropped from the team by Coach Don Shula.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation acknowledged at a Federal hearing today that it was slightly behind schedule in completing a few items of a $7-million program of water pollution control facilities.

Controller Mario A. Procaccino accused Mayor Lindsay yesterday of "deceit and dishonesty" in his handling of the narcotics problem. At the same time, the Mayor was helping to start a methadone project in Brooklyn that is privately operated on public funds.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that he would urge the 1970 Legislature to move to reconstitute the Board of Elections in New York City by constitutional amendment.

TRW, Inc., achieved the highest sales and earnings in its history for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, it was reported yesterday by J. D. Wright, chairman and chief executive officer of the diversified industrial producer.

The Board of Education and the Board of Elections announced yesterday that they would normally ask the state to postpone the local school board elections to be held here on Jan. 27 under the school decentralization law.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 8 -- The Portuguese political police have started criminal proceedings against a prominent actress, Maria Barroso, who is a candidate for the democratic opposition in the Oct. 26 elections to the National Assembly.

CHICAGO, Oct 8 -- When a defense attorney asked a witness what "Mr. Hoffman" did one day in August, 1968, Judge Julius J. Hoffman leaned down from the bench to admonish him. "Let's be a little more precise," he said.

MANHASSET, L. I., Oct. 8 -- Yesterday, Governor Rockefeller announced that the Long Island Rail Road was the finest commuter line in the country." Today, 4,000 of its passengers , were delayed up to 47 minutes.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Brooks Robinson of the Baltimore Orioles has read a lot in recent weeks about the New York Mets and their ace pitchers, Tom Seaver and Jerry Koosman, but glowing adjectives about their mound exploits haven't impressed the star third baseman.
A new crack appeared yesterday in the international airlines trans-Atlantic fare agreement, a development that some industry sources said had moved the airlines closer to an all-out price war.

CASTEAU, Belgium, Oct. 8 -- Senator John Sherman Cooper has warned the European allies that the United States is likely to reduce its troop strength and financial contributions to the North Atlantic alliance unless they increase the strength and effectiveness of their forces.

MOSCOW, Oct. 8 -- The Defense Ministry newspaper today attacked the Israeli radio for attempting to spread Zionism in the Soviet Union, and denied that there was discrimination against Jews in this country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Recent intelligence reports on Soviet nuclear-powered submarines have convinced military analysts that in the rivalry for supremacy under the seas the United States is likely to stay ahead for some years to come.

VERGENNES, Vt., Oct. 8 -- The public will be able to tell the 1970 Volkswagen from its predecessors. The bug is still bug-like, but there are new louvers -- or slits -- in the rear-engine lid that make the new model easily distinguishable from the old.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 8 -- Joseph H. Blatchford, the director of the Peace Corps, disclosed tonight that the United States proposed to establish an exchange program in which foreign youths would work in American communities.
LONDON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Striking garbagemen clashed today with workers trying to clear mounting rubbish in London's Hackney district where the strike began 16 days ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, Premier of Laos, voiced confidence today that President Nixon would give Laos the support necessary to defend her independence and territorial integrity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey was reported by Congressional sources today to have assured President Nixon of his public support if the Administration should decide in favor of "systematic withdrawal" of all American combat forces from Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff charged today that a group of Army sergeants and former sergeants had used stolen money as capital to form a corporation that sold goods to service clubs in Vietnam.

Joseph Curran asserted his authority as leader of the National Maritime Union yesterday by dramatically denouncing a small dissident group at the union's national convention.
A 53-year-old Manhattan woman bit off the fingertip of a mugger during an attack last year. The severed bit of finger led yesterday to the seizure of a suspect by the police.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, has apologized to two Connecticut policewomen after a bumping incident in a downtown Washington restaurant last week.

TUNIS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Tunisian Government appealed to foreign countries today for helicopters and rescue materials after 10 days of flooding rainstorms. More than 500 people have been listed as known dead.

Dr. Leslie K. Gulton, who was replaced earlier this month as president and chief executive officer of Gulton Industries, Inc., by Walter F. Gips Jr., has resigned as chairman and director, it was disclosed yesterday.

On the second level of Shea Stadium, in the offices of the National League champion Mets, telephones rang incessantly yesterday.

Earnings of major New York City banks have been hit hard by soaring money costs, reports published yesterday showed. Three major banking institutions disclosed thirdquarter earnings, and all three were lower than in the 1968 period.

The New York Jets' game with the Houston Oilers at Shea Stadium, originally set for Oct. 19, has been rescheduled for the Flushing Meadow park on Monday, Oct. 20, with an 8 P.M. kickoff.

Meyner charged tonight that more than $2-million in land along one projected interstate highway and lying in the path of another had been purchased in the name of two close associates of Representative William T. Cahill, the Republican nominee for Governor.

By this weekend, however, the effort had mushroomed into a massive national demonstration.

BRUCE McLAREN considers motor racing hard work. Jackie Stewart is a swinger and a devoted father. Pedro Rodriguez separates his religion from racing. Stirling Moss is sorry there's so little fun left in racing.

TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Tom Durrance bolted over center for 1 yard and a touchdown with 2 minutes 10 seconds left and John Reaves passed to Carlos Alverez for a 2-point conversion today as Florida came from behind for an 18-17 victory over stubborn Tulane.

The State Health Department is challenging widely circulated contentions by a University of Pittsburgh physicist that radio-active fallout from nuclear weapons tests has increased children's death rates and cancers.
Three candidates supported by critics of the governing board of the Two Bridges model school district on the Lower East Side have been elected members of the local board in a community vote.
Will improved Chinese-Soviet relations cost Western businessmen and countries billions of dollars in Chinese orders?
ATHENS, Oct. 11 -- Two new revisions in Greece's school curriculums reflect the zeal of the military-backed government in refurbishing the national image.
The motorship Acadia Forest is somewhere in mid-Pacific headed for New Orleans to begin the first service in the world as a barge-carrying mother ship.

ONTARIO, Calif., Oct. 11 Drag racing's "supernationals" were created here this week with the singing of a five-year agreement by the National Hot Rod Association and Ontario Motor Speedway. The first "supernational" scheduled for Nov. 22, 1970 has been listed on the calendar of the Federation Internationale de l'Automobile and therefore becomes the first internationally sanctioned drag meet.

What do you give a museum that has everything? Everything, of course. That solution was hit on by the late investment banker Robert Lehman, who at his death last August left the Metropolitan Museum of Art (and don't, please, refer to it as "the Met" in your will) his priceless collection of 3,000 objects, ranging over eight centuries of the fine and decorative arts.

BULB forcing is one of the easiest of all gardening activities. Children take to it with enthusiasm. Many hardy bulbs can be forced to bloom indoors. Most popular are tulips, hyacinths and daffodils. Somewhat less popular, but just as easy to grow, are crocus, grape hyacinths, Iris reticulata and Scilla siberica.

The time for a reversal of the Administration's anti-inflationary policy may soon be at hand, Paul W. McCracken, the chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, said recently. "The perfect time would be when it seems premature," he told an interviewer. "If you wait until you are absolutely sure that you have turned the corner, it's probably too late."

DALLAS, Oct. 11 -- The forward pass is alive and well in the University of Texas playbook as the unbeaten Longhorns proved today with a thrilling 27-17 victory over Oklahoma before a sellout crowd of 71,938 in the Cotton Bowl.

Hope for an early return to normal elevator maintenance and construction work was dashed yesterday when repairmen in Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers rejected recommendations of union leaders to settle their week-old strike.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Union College's homecoming was spoiled today by the University of Rochester, which defeated the Dutchmen, 34-28.

Judging from the disparity between the experiences of George L. Rosenblatt (letter of Sept. 14) and my own upon leaving the Soviet Union, I believe that one must expect inconsistency by the Soviets in the handling of foreign exchange.

The millions who read Mary Jane Ward's 1946 novel, "The Snake Pit" were shocked by its picture of the average state psychiatric institution. Crowded to the eaves, always short of personnel (especially psychiatrists), they were literally animal corrals, where patients were penned up either to win their own way back to mental health, or to live out their days in mindless futility.

Artificiality has always been one of the great attractions of finance. JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Archie Manning passed for two touchdowns and the Missisisippi defense halted the Georgia attack today to give the Rebels a 25-17 upset victory over the 7th-ranked and defending Southeastern Conference champions.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 -- The nation's first family, minus the President, unwittingly disturbed Mike Cuellar's pregame ritual today, but the Baltimore pitcher followed all his other superstitions and they were enough to eradicate the Mets' magic.

OUR glass-enclosed porch by the brook was a fine place for breakfast on a summer morning, but poor ventilation made it stifling by midday. In winter, it felt colder than the great outdoors because it was unheated and uninsulated.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 11 -- The New York Knickerbockers closed out their National Basketball Association exhibition season tonight by losing to the Baltimore Bullets, 119-108. The Bullets were paced by Gus Johnson's 33 points.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 11 -- Rich Policastro, the stellar Rutgers quarterback, completed 29 of 52 passes today, but two that Lehigh intercepted paved the way for the Engineers' 17 to 7 upset.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The American Bar Association committee that endorsed Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr.'s Supreme Court nomination two weeks ago will meet again in New York tomorrow to consider recent charges of improper financial conduct that have been leveled against the nominee.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- The economy of New England seems to have marked time during the late spring and early summer of 1969, sharing none of the advances elsewhere in the nation. The question for the area is whether the plateau was the forerunner of an August and September dip in indexes on a national scale, or a temporary lull.

In spite of the political opposition of members of the House of Representatives, the Administration's proposal to provide for automatic cost-of-living increases in Social Security benefits makes good economic and political sense.

DETROIT -- In a valley of the modern skyline hero is an ivy-covered, brownstone anachronism called the Detroit Club. Its red, sun-faded canopy is a time tunnel leading away from noisy downtown traffic into a quiet, unhurried 19th century.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- In a fundamental revision of maritime policy, the Nixon Administration is preparing to ask Congress next week for funds to expand the activities of the American merchant fleet and to revive the construction of commercial vessels in domestic shipyards.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 -- During their frantic, fabulous homestretch drive to a National League pennant, the New York Mets were showered with gifts by the opposition -- gift runs, gift hits, gift misplays. But on this lovely spring-like afternoon, the Orioles gave them nothing -- not even the right time.

GREENWICH, Conn. Oct. 11 -- Thomas R. Young's Shearwater, a 36-foot blue-hulled cutter out of nearby Riverside Yacht Club, won the Windward Cup today. She placed first on corrected time in the cruising division of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's 14th annual Stratford Shoal event that concluded the distance-racing season on Long Island Sound.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 11 -- After more than two months of weary weekend journeys, the New York Jets will oppose the Cincinnati Bengals here tomorrow in a temporary farewell to American Football League travel. The world champions are an 8-point betting favorite over Paul Brown's expansion team in its second season.

WASHINGTON -- "In the Army, your life can literally depend upon another person's reliability," said one Army professional last week. "An army is built on the trust of men in each other. If you don't have it, you don't have an army."

It also is a land of works of art half - hidden in country churches or buried for the last 2,000 years.

No natural phenomena with which we have intimate contact are more awesome than the cosmic rays. Scores of these extremely high energy particles flash through out bodies every second. DEARBORN, Mich. -- Just 90 years ago this month, Thomas Alva Edison electrified the world by demonstrating the first practical electric light in his old, gray laboratory building in Menlo Park, N. J. Exactly 50 years later, Edison re-enacted the lighting of the famous globe here in this suburban Detroit community -- in the very same laboratory building.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 -- Even before a blow was struck in the World Series today, baseball men agreed that the Mets would have to be more amazing than ever to defeat the Baltimore Orioles.

Little squadrons of Brillo-like clouds hover over the stalled lines of Volkswagens on the way to somewhere. To where? Not, certainly, to the 10th Bienal of Sao Paulo, from which I have returned dazed by uncompromising banality.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Federal Home Loan Bank System is making record use of its borrowing and lending functions to offset the funds shortage in the housing industry, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

NEWARK, Oct. 13 -- A debate tonight at Rutgers University's campus here between the Republican and Democratic candidates for Governor was disrupted and cut short by catcalls and obscene epithets of racial agitators.
BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- Fritz Woehrn, a former Gestapo official who served as a close aide to Col. Adolf Eichmann, was sentenced to 12 years' imprisonment today by a court in West Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Former President Lyndon B. Johnson's top economic adviser predicted today that unemployment will probably rise somewhat above 4 per cent this winter and next spring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A review of an appeal by tobacco manufacturers and broadcasters who objected to the Government's rule that requires radio and television stations to carry antismoking messages was denied today by the Supreme Court.

Warren Weaver's news report (Oct. 8) of a survey which shows that thirty state legislatures favor direct election of the President ironically points up an additional undemocratic feature of the Constitution -- the process for ratifying amendments.
MOSCOW, Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union launched this afternoon into earth orbit its third manned Soyuz spacecraft in as many days.
DETROIT, Oct. 13 -- The newcar sales bubble burst, or at least developed a slow leak, in early October, industry reports showed today.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Bernadette Devlin, the 22-year-old Member of Parliament from Northern Ireland, tonight charged the House of Commons and the Government with responsibility for the violence and turmoil in her country.

THERE are no curtain calls at Arthur Kopit's new play, "Indians." Buffalo Bill, the semi-hero, shuffles off into celebrated oblivion, and the audience at the Brooks Atkinson Theater is itself left to shuffle out into West 47th Street, with little applause to buffer the break between fantasy and reality.
The Park Avenue Antiques Fair opened yesterday with what collectors and dealers agreed was an upgraded and more inviting show.

THE National Geographic Society begins another series of its specials tonight, and the first is about a subject of perennial interest: "The Mystery of Animal Behavior." The program, seen at a preview, contains much superb film footage on animal ways of life around the world.

A police command post with electronic eyes to watch rioters or demonstrators anywhere in New York and an elaborate data system to keep track of every policeman was put into action yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- John H. Reed, chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, today urged the licensing of towboat operators to avert further catastrophes on the inland waterways.
The Felt Forum fight card turned out to be a fine night for Long Island boxers and some members of the New York City Police Department.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Tuesday, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- British troops, expecting more rioting by Protestants last night, received a respite when a heavy rain fell.

NEWARK, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Representatives for striking drivers of the Inter-City Bus Company agreed to terms tonight in their 12-day wage strike, which has left 35,000 Jersey commuters without regular transportation.

The Joint Task Force of Federal, state and city agencies created here last July is ready to present evidence on organized crime to a Federal grand jury.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Senate Finance Committee agreed today to repeal a provision of the tax law known as the unlimited charitable deduction. Under it, about 100 extremely wealthy individuals have been able to escape payment of all or nearly all Federal income tax.

The International Paper Company, which has introduced its disposable diapers into several markets, has just leaped into San Francisco with a whole line of other paper products -- tissues, towels and napkins. And they're prepared to promote the dickens out of them.
Prices moved up along a broad front yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, buoyed by the September trade figures for Britain.

CLIFTON WHARTON has done it again. As the newly appointed president of Michigan State University, Dr. Wharton will be the first Negro president of a major, predominantly white college in the country.

The Golden Anniversary Titian Ball to benefit the Italian Welfare League will honor Mrs. Generoso Pope on Oct. 25 at the Hotel Biltmore. The gala event will mark 50 years of service here by the league. Mrs. Pope has been a benefactor of the league for many years.

President Nixon made it plain, in his radio talk yesterday, that the Administration views the wage-price spiral as the chief unmet threat in the fight to stabilize the dollar. His rejection of both mandatory controls and guidelines as devices for checking that spiral places on labor and management a heavy responsibility.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17 -- The economic policies of the Nixon Administration are slowing the nation's economic growth and increasing unemployment, Nathaniel Goldfinger, research director of the A.F.L-C.I.O., said here today.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 16 -- Until this season, the Yale Repertory Theatre had been something of a stepchild on campus, sharing the university theater with the undergraduates. Last night the company opened its first exclusive home, a new interim theater, with a production of Richard Brinsley Sheridan's "The Rivals." Both the theater and the production are cause for celebration and subscription.

THE Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center lived up to advance billing last night in Tully Hall. There was a mixed program in which were something old, something new, something unfamiliar, and everything interesting.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 17 -- Dr. Clifton Reginald Wharton Jr., a 43-year-old economist from New York City, today was elected president of Michigan State University, which has 40,000 students.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The man whom President Nixon has named to chart the course of the nation's credit sometimes appears lost to those around him.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 17 -- South Vietnamese Government sources said that Government patrol boats today fired on and hit a Soviet ship that they described as an intelligence trawler. The sources said the ship had ignored challenges and intruded into Vietnamese territorial waters off Danang.

GENEVA, Oct. 17 -- Arthur Brawer, an American who is accused of having masterminded an ingenious attempt to swindle the Chase Manhattan Bank out of more than $11-million with a faked Telex message to a Zurich bank, is in the hands of the Swiss police.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced its first proposed complaint under the truth-in-lending act, accusing the nation's largest jeweler of failing to make complete disclosure of credit charges.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Nixon told the nation today, "We are on the road to recovery from the disease of runaway prices." He predicted further gains in the fight against inflation and asked all segments of American society to exercise economic restraint.
SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Oct. 18 -- President Chung Hee Park swept to a resounding victory today in his bid to win the right to seek a third term.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Terry McMillan threw one touchdown pass and scored once on a run to spark a 22-point second quarter today as fifth-ranked Missouri posted a 31-21 Big Eight victory over Oklahoma State in a heavy rain.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 18 -- Dartmouth came to town today loaded for bear and before the unbeaten Indians left, they found the hunting excellent at Brown Stadium, tomahawking the Bruins by 38-13.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Princeton got off on the wrong foot in its non-Ivy League football game with Colgate today and then spent the rest of the afternoon futilely seeking to regain its equilibrium as it bowed, 35-28, at Palmer Stadium.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18 -- Dennis Dummit threw two touchdown passes to Gwen Cooper today as the University of California, Los Angeles, scored a 32-0 Pacific-8 football victory over California.

ONE of the feature exhibitions at the Nov. 21-23 twenty-first National Postage Stamp Show here will be a complete pane of the Grandma Moses multicolored commemorative stamp without its title, "Grandma Moses," across the top, and without "6c U.S. Postage" at the base.

SINCE he retired last June as Chief Justice of the United States, Earl Warren has spent much of his time traveling with Mrs. Warren. Last month, shortly before the Supreme Court reconvened under his successor, Warren Burger, he was in London and agreed to an interview.

THE late Dr. Thomas Ollive Mabbott gained fame not only as a man of letters, but as a numismatist who was an authority on ancient, medieval and foreign coinage. Born in New York, Dr. Mabbott became interested in the hobby as a youth and during his lifetime assembled a collection of more than 20,000 pieces, most of which were ancient Greek, Roman and Byzantine monies and medals.

NEW DELHI -- The prospering textile city of Armedabad was one of the few places in northern India that could boast a history of relative Hindu-Moslem harmony. LOUIS, Oct. 19 -- The Minnesota Vikings, who rank right behind Dallas and Los Angeles at the top level of the National Football League, did a methodical job of destroying the St. Louis Cardinals today. The Vikings gained their fourth victory in five games, 27-10, as their great defense once more took away the foe's offense.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- An upward revaluation of the West German mark, to a new parity higher than originally expected when the decision was made to "float" it on Sept. 29, was viewed as a strong possibility in European money centers today.

Separate investigations of the hiring by the Lindsay administration of 10 young men alleged to have police records were ordered yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and Queens District Attorney Thomas A. Mackell.
The Who, the British rock group, began a six-day run of its opera, "Tommy," with an impressive opening last night at the Fillmore East.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner said yesterday that he "would be glad" to serve as chairman of a screening committee to help pick two appointees to the Board of Education.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday an $887,834 grant to the Arizona Job College, the nation's first comprehensive educational and retraining program for migrant farm workers.

In 1870, which was 28 years before the City of Brooklyn surrendered its independence to become one of New York's five boroughs, a small college was opened at the request of the Most Rev. John D. Loughlin, Brooklyn's first Roman Catholic bishop.
Four persons, including a mother and her son, have been arrested on charges that they purchased and cashed welfare checks from postal employes in Brooklyn who had allegedly stolen them.
A new program to finance an estimated total of 80,000 federally aided apartment units was announced yesterday.
Ted Williams, who led the Washington Senators to their first winning season in 17 years, has been selected The Associated Press's American League manager of the year.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- More than 10,000 sea birds have died off the northwest coast of Britain in the last few weeks, but the cause remains a mystery.
A tentative settlement of a wage strike by elevator repairmen was announced yesterday by Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange moved up yesterday in moderately active trading volume.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 20 -- Thousands of Bolivians celebrated the nationalization of the American-owned Bolivia Gulf Oil Company with a parade and fiery speeches on a specially decreed holiday here today while their Government struggled privately with the possible commercial consequences of the seizure.

Robert J. Bonadonna, corporate traffic manager of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., has been elected president of the New York Retail Traffic Association, Inc., a non-profit group of thirty-three New York area based retail organizations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Pentagon said today that 212,000 jobs in the defense industry would be eliminated by next spring because of recent defense spending cuts.

GENEVA, Oct. 20 -- The United States said today there was an urgent need for progress toward the removal of non-tariff barriers to the free flow of international trade. The way was paved yesterday by a Federal District Court in New Haven for the consummation of the largest combined merger deal in American business history.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Frank Sinatra, for whom a warrant was issued in New Jersey after he failed to appear before an investigation panel to answer questions about organized crime, said today that he would not appear voluntarily because "I am not willing to be part of any three-ring circus."

Territory seized from China by Czarist Russia under four treaties and the so-called "thalweg" or center-line principle of river boundaries are involved in the border negotiations now under way in Peking.

Birny Mason Jr., chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, reported yesterday that the company's earnings in the third quarter had risen 14 per cent to $43,751,000, or 72 cents a share, from $38,243,000, or 64 cents a share, a year earlier.
A team of astronomers from Cornell University reported yesterday that a pulsar in the Crab Nebula has a slight, but quite remarkable, wobble.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Prime Minister Kobi A. Busia of Ghana said today that his nation "is paying dearly, and will have to do so for years to come, for the corruption, the inefficiency, and the inordinate ambition" of the former regime led by Kwame Nkrumah.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 21 -Legislative supporters of a proposal calling for a Federal constitutional convention won a procedural battle here today when the State Assembly voted, 51 to 45, to open floor debate on the measure Nov. 4.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 21 -- The United States today called on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to join the battle against the destruction by advanced technology of man's environment.

Some of the smoothest piano-playing to be heard nowadays is being done by Michael Rogers, the young pianist who returned to Carnegie Hall last night for his second recital there within two years. Since making his debut at Town Hall in 1961, Mr. Rogers has also appeared in the Young Artist Series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Palestine Liberation Organization said that Lebanese troops shelled Arab guerrillas holed up in a border village early today, killing five taking the rest prisoner.

Seven contracts and nine companies who had pleaded guilty to rigging bids on $16million worth of contracts to do trenching and paving work for Consolidated Edison in Westchester County were sentenced yesterday to pay fines from $500 to $25,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The White House circulated on Capitol Hill today a three-page "fact sheet" outlining political and military steps taken by the Nixon Administration to de-escalate and settle the Vietnam war. Sources in Congress regarded the move as an attempt by the Administration to keep the critics of its Vietnam policy on the defensive.

The housing proposal for Welfare Island shown in The Times (news story, Oct. 10) reflects the city's apple pie approach to housing (a slice for low income, a slice for the elderly, for "conventionally financed," etc.), an approach which might be basically sound for most large projects but one which has absolutely no place on Welfare Island.
Prices eased along a broad front yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
Several changes in major executive posts at the Upjohn Company were announced yesterday in Kalamazoo, Mich., following the regular meeting of the company's board.
The Metropolitan Opera Association continued negotiations yesterday with stagehands and its orchestra, following a settlement Monday with solo artists.

WASHINGTON, OCT. 21 -The Pentagon ordered today annual independent civilian audits of all officers' and noncommissioned officers' clubs as the first step in creating uniform controls for all nonappropriated funds.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- American League club owners have urged the owners of the Seattle Pilots and Seattle city officials to make another try at settling their differences before considering any move to another city by the one-year-old expansion team.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Several hundred leftist art students occupied the Ecole des Beaux Arts today as a protest against the Pompidou Government's centrist policies. Several policemen were injured, eyewitnesses said, when the students began throwing stones and pots of red and white paint.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Jon Lindbergh, son of Charles A. Lindbergh, and Dr. Wendell Phillips, an archeologist and oil millionaire, plan to search the remote Arabian harbor of Muscat for sunken antiquities, it was disclosed today.

City agencies have asked for $3-billion in capital budget funds, a record, for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1970. This is about $1-billion more than they requested last year and $2-billion more than they are likely to receive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Defense Department sources said today that most military men, including the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the commander of U.S. troops in Vietnam, were strongly opposed to a unilateral cease-fire.
Somewhere on the windswept streets of Chicago, a piece of paper may be floating around that holds the key to solving the Bobby Hull-Chicago Black Hawks mystery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -The arguments for and against Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr.'s elevation to the Supreme Court are now fading from concern here as the politics and tactics that surround every major issue become paramount.

John A. Hines, a 38-year-old Negro who runs a two-year-old schoolbook publishing company from two small rooms at 1123 Broadway, says he doesn't put much stock in white men who bear promises of help for black capitalists.

IN "The Marker," Jason sits with a book in his lap and watches his wife across the room as she undresses enticingly and climbs into bed. He turns out the light and crosses the room confidently. But the bed is not where it is supposed to be Jason feels his way through increasingly unfamiliar space, lost and confused.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to tax more heavily than the Nixon Administration wanted the capital gains received by many upper-bracket taxpayers. The tax would not be as large as the one the House of Representatives voted, however.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Gloria Swanson was partly responsible, a Congressman said today, for an amendment that made possible the barring of the artificial sweetener cyclamate from diet foods and drinks.

Many in the crowd of 15,116 at Madison Square Garden last night turned out to watch the New York debut of Connie Hawkins in the National Basketball Association. The unbeaten Knicks chose the occasion, however, to steal the show by producing their finest offensive game of the young season, thumping the Phoenix Suns, 140-116, for their fifth victory.
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company attained the highest sales and earnings in its history for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.

Pete Rozelle, commissioner of pro football, reaffirmed yesterday that Joe Namath, the New York Jets' quarterback, had agreed to sell his interest in Bachelors III, the East Side bar and restaurant, although a spokesman for the State Liquor Authority was quoted as having said that the agency had received no application for a transfer of ownership in the license.
Municipal bonds, which last week made their largest advance in a year and a half, ran into some roadblocks yesterday.

The State Public Service Commission will hold public hearings here next month on the request by the Consolidated Edison Company for a $117-milliona-year rate increase for electricity, Commissioner John T. Ryan said yesterday.

BONN, Oct. 21 -- Willy Brandt is moving into Bonn's Schaumburg Palace this week, with hundreds of aides and secretaries, as the new Chancellor of the German Federal Republic. But the person closest to him, his wife, Rut, is staying home.
Fourteen police horses will be named by schoolchildren in a citywide contest that started yesterday and ends Nov. 21.

Mayor Lindsay has not been the perfect Mayor we would have liked. His greatest weakness has been as an administrator, which is too bad in view of the increased knowledge of effective administration that we have today.

THE annual experts invitation game organized by Bill Root at the Harmonie Club Monday night attracted 30 top-ranked players and more than 120 club members, making it the biggest such event ever played in New York City.
Board of Education security guards assigned to trouble-prone schools are scheduled to meet today to discuss a possible strike.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- Jerry West's superb shooting in the final minute and Keith Erickson's two key free throws with 40 seconds remaining enabled the Los Angeles Lakers to gain a 142-137 overtime victory tonight over the Baltimore Bullets.
The Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park will become "the Brookfield School" for the evening of Nov. 5 when a supper dance will take place there for the benefit of Project Hope.

Not all receptionists in agency media departments are overly attentive, it would seem, and many times when Anthony Johnson shows up to sell space for his magazine they don't listen and just assume he's from Ebony.
The move by major United States banks into the foreign mutual fund field appears to be spreading rapidly.

TRENTON, Oct. 21 -- President Nixon will go on the campaign trail next week for the first time since his election, to support Representative William T. Cahill, the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Eldridge Cleaver, the Black Panther leader who is now in Algeria, was reported today to have begun discussions with the enemy in Vietnam about an exchange of United States military prisoners for Panthers in custody in this country.

MIAMI, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- Hurricane Laurie drifted toward the west coast of Florida tonight with 110-mile-an-hour winds after veering away from Louisiana and Mississippi. Floridians braced to see where the storm would strike.

HONG KONG, Oct. 21 -- Evidence has reached here from Communist China suggesting that Peking's border negotiations with Moscow are causing concern and possibly opposition among some sections of China's leadership.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- A multimillionaire industrialist, Frank M. McMahon, announced today his retirement as chairman and chief executive officer of the Westcoast Transmission Company, Ltd., effective Oct. 31.

Chile has been one of the most durable democracies in Latin America despite staggering social and economic problems. For more than three decades its army not only kept aloof from politics but demonstrated its devotion to constitutional government and peaceful change. President Frei's "Revolution in Liberty" was exactly what the Alliance for Progress was all about and, for all its setbacks, became a model for other Latin countries.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 21 -- South African sporting organizations have decided to augment a fund for sending delegates overseas to defend South Africa in international sporting congresses.

Representatives of the theatrical, artistic, social and diplomatic worlds got together last night to celebrate the appointment of the American Ballet Theater as the official ballet company of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, and, incidentally, to raise money for special ballet performances for disadvantaged children across the country.
The initial findings in the mayoral poll being conducted by The Daily News showed last night that Mayor Lindsay was leading by a large margin.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- The first snowflakes of the season disappeared on the wet pavement outside, but Ed Marinaro's thoughts were of warmer days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Phillip S. Hughes, who has long been considered one of the most powerful and widely knowledgeable career bureaucrats in the Federal Government, resigned today as Deputy Director of the Budget.
The three major candidates for Mayor campaigned in a number of areas yesterday, with these developments:
New Yorkers too old to cope for themselves urgently need a broad program of government help, the Community Service Society said yesterday.
A retired couple in the New York City area needs to spend 11 per cent more than retired couples in other major cities to maintain a moderate standard of living.

Without a coherent, broadly accepted policy for ending the war in Vietnam, the Administration will be buffeted between the rising demands for immediate withdrawal and continuing pressures for staying in, and even escalating, the war. The domestic consequences of such a polarization could be disastrous.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff asserted today that perjury had been committed during Senate hearings on retired Maj. Gen. Carl C. Turner's activities while he was Provost Marshal General of the Army.

BONN, Oct. 22 -- Willy Brandt, the new West German Chancellor, presented a trimmed and streamlined Cabinet today, with a strong suggestion that his Government would treat East Germany as a separate, independent state.

Twelve hundred women are expected at the Americana on Saturday when the Ruth Kirzon Group for Hanicapped Children holds its 23d annual donor luncheon and fashion show to raise money for the organization's wide-ranging activities on behalf of handicapped children.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Spiro Agnew, the Administration's man in charge of colorful talking, was unleashed in New Orleans the other night and took the opportunity to identify the groups who are ruining America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- House backers of the Oct. 15 Vietnam Moratorium, apparently skeptical about some of the sponsors of the upcoming November demonstrations, met today with W. Averell Harriman, who reportedly expressed similar concerns.

In case Bobby Hull is interested, the Chicago Black Hawks ended their five-game losing streak last night, helped by the New York Rangers' erratic play as the clubs played to a 1-all tie at Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Richard Wagner's "Der fliegende Hollander" was given a new production by the Lyric Opera of Chicago last night, and the sets and costumes were designed by none other than the composer's great-grandson, Wolf Siegfried Wagner, who was making his American debut.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 -- A Protestant minister and teacher urged today that Protestant churches, collectively and individually, revise their religious teaching material to give a "more balanced picture of Jews, Judaism and Jewish-Christian relations."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- A bill that would allow everyone who wishes to check the accuracy of files kept by credit rating bureaus won the Senate Banking Committee's unanimous approval today.

The Board of Education, in requesting a two-month delay in the election of local school boards, is protecting the orderly process of decentralization. Under the present timetable, imposed by patchwork legislation in Albany, the entirely new procedures of local registration, filing nominating petitions and holding the elections themselves would be compressed into a period of just over three weeks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- The Government sought a Federal court order to desegregate every public school in Georgia by next September.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- Pope Paul VI endorsed strongly today the general aims of the Synod of Bishops to "decentralize" the ruling power in the Roman Catholic church and "concentrate" it at the local and regional level.
Trading volume increased sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and prices continued to advance.

Time Inc. has bought the Book Find Club and the Seven Arts Book Society from George Braziller, Inc., the publisher who founded and operated the clubs. Both will be operated as independent subsidiaries of Time Inc.

A joint legislative committee investigating drug use among children was told yesterday that the Federal Government's recent Operation Intercept -- aimed at stopping the flow of drugs into the United States across the Mexican border -- has caused heroin sales to jump among children here.
Everybody that is anybody, it seems, is lending his name to a new issue of stock.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Oct. 20 -- A dispute involving the United States and Congolese Governments and American religious welfare agencies has all but halted the flow of relief supplies into the former Belgian Congo.
JOE Namath has won almost every conceivable honor in football, with one notable exception. The Jet quarterback has never led the American Football League as the statistical passing champion.

The associate director of a Government-financed vocational training center in New Jersey and former New York City antipoverty agency official was arrested here yesterday and charged with criminal possession of stock certificates, bonds and forged checks totaling more than $1-million.
HOW far can you go? Or, if you think it more pertinent, how far are we going? In the theater, that is. And in the business of breaking old taboos, and all that nonsense.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Under Secretary of State for political affairs, U. Alexis Johnson, warned a group of Japanese prefectural governors last night that Japan's removal of restrictions against American exports and investments "has not been quick enough to lay to rest the feeling here that elements of economic reciprocity are lacking in our relationship."

NICHOLAS PATTERSON, a 22 - year - old Cambridge University undergraduate, won the recent Irish championship at Trinity College, Dublin. Patterson won 5 and drew 4 for a score of 7-2 in the nine - round, 32 - man Swiss system.
Five young women, debutante daughters of members of the Society of Mayflower Descendants, will make their debuts at the society's annual ball Nov. 7 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 -- Minor effects have been observed from the Oct. 2 hydrogen bomb test underground at Amchitka Island in the Aleutian chain, the Atomic Energy Commission said today.

BONN, Oct. 22 -- West Germany's new Social Democratic-led Government began its four-year term today amidst mounting expectation that revaluation of the West German mark would be its first major step in the economic sphere.

AS any sidewalk superintendent knows, there is nothing like watching work in Progress, and one of the most fascinating works in progress in Manhattan these days is a book on Chinese cooking that is currently being prepared by Florence Lin and Margaret Spader.

Premier Golda Meir's meeting with a group of "Jewish intellectuals" (news story Oct. 7) would have been more revealing had The Times been able to report some of the searching questions such a distinguished group should have addressed to the Premier of Israel.
The Association of American Universities yesterday endorsed President Nixon's proposal for a draft-lottery system to replace the current "oldest first" method.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 22 -- Frank Chapot captured the blue ribbon tonight for the United States in the International Fault-and-Out Class at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- Hubert H. Humphrey declared today that the United States had achieved its objectives in Vietnam and had fulfilled its obligations to the South Vietnamese people.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland Oct. 22 -- Airline representatives remained deadlocked today in their efforts to end a dispute over trans-Atlantic airline fares.

HOUSTON, Oct., 22 (AP) -- A Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor has been named chief scientist at the Manned Spacecraft Center, a new position designed to form a bridge between the science community and the manned spaceflight program.
VIENNA, Oct. 22 -- The Slovak Communist party newspaper Pravda of Bratislava praised Soviet occupation troops today for "helping with work" in labor-starved Czechoslovakia.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, appeared to have underestimated the cost of a private satellite system for coast-to-coast relay of television programs.

There is little anyone can do to redeem a ballet as meretricious as is "The Poppet" in its fevered pursuit of the theatrically fashionable at the expense of the substantive. What was possible was accomplished by Lili Cockerille at the City Center Joffrey Ballet last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Senate voted, 49 to 24, today to liberalize trade with the Soviet Union and its Eastern European allies. The chamber approved, over the Nixon Administration's firm objections, reversal of a 20-year policy.

When a biography of Controller Mario A. Procaccino was criticized in The New York Post last week for stating that he had been graduated from City College "with honors," when actually he had received more C's than any other mark, his staff quickly prepared copies of his Fordham Law School transcript. The transcript showed a fine scholastic record consisting mainly of A's and A pluses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- House Speaker John W. McCormack kept Dr. Martin Sweig as his administrative assistant for several weeks after the Justice Department is reported to have informed the Speaker that his aide was under investigation.

Brooklyn, which hasn't had a major league team of its own to cheer about since the Dodgers left for Los Angeles following the 1957 season, officially adopted the Mets yesterday. Brooklyn's 74-year-old Borough president Abe Stark, issued the proclamation on the steps of Borough Hall.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 22 -- The series of clashes in Lebanon between regular troops and Arab guerrillas was seen tonight by Israeli experts as a temporary disruption with no long-term impact.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A special study commission on tax-exempt foundations proposed to Congress today that these organizations be required to pay out a large proportion of their annual earnings for the public purposes for which they were organized.

The stock market roared along recovery road yesterday, with the Dow-Jones industrial average accelerating to its best single day's gain in nearly six months. The blue-chip average boomed 13.47 points to finish at 860.35. It marked the best gain since a rise of 16.08 points on April 30. For the second day in a row, the market closed at its best levels as the stock tape ran three minutes late.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Pentagon plans to test-fire Minuteman missiles across the northwest United States next year if it can get approval from Congress.
A bill requiring companies supplying the city to pay their employes at least $2.50 an hour was signed into law yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
Borrowing costs for the Bell System, the nation's biggest borrower of long-term capital, came down moderately yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay has one great advantage over his rivals for the mayoralty when the debate turns to fiscal matters. Despite the steadily rising cost of government, he has substantially improved the city's fiscal position since he took office by balancing the budget without deficit financing -- an achievement that borders on the miraculous.

HONG KONG, Oct. 22 -- Communist China announced today that Trutz von Xylander, a West German, had been arrested in the northwestern city of Lanchow and sentenced to 10 years in prison as a "U.S. imperialist spy."
Dr. Christiaan Barneard, the heart transplant surgeon, says he once made a mistake in a University of Minnesota operating room that cost the life of a 7-year-old boy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- New orders for durable goods in September increased $1.8-billion, to $32.3-billion, after seasonal adjustments, the Commerce Department's Bureau of the Census reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- President Nixon told a group of Congressmen today that "there are times when we need help beyond ourselves, to make the right decisions" on national policy.
An agreement in principle has been reached for the sale of Midland-Ross Corporation's I.R.C. fibers division to the American Cyanamid Company for more than $20-million, it was announced yesterday.

Third-quarter income of the Olin Corporation dropped to $11,480,000, or 50 cents a share, from $13,831,000, or 57 cents a share, a year earlier, when a larger average number of shares was outstanding, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A consumer affairs message that promises to disappoint advocates of strong legislative and administrative action will be sent to Congress, possibly next week, by President Nixon.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 22 -- The old-line Hudson County Democratic organization appeared today to be lining up behind Representative William T. Cahill, the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey.

WITH all those riotous colors in spring collections screaming "look at me," it's amazing what a lasting effect the quiet ones have. After an hour or so of tropical foliage adapted to fabric in truer-than-life colors or wild abstractions in tones that grate in the modern manner, the fashion show viewer is apt to remember the cool number in beige or gray.

Federal Reserve bank examiners have found it "desirable" for the Central Trust Company of Rochester to increase its capital by about $3.5-million, according to documents on file at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 22 -- Twenty-six students have been identified by Dartmouth College as having participated in last week's demonstration preventing William Shockley, a Nobel laureate, from delivering a paper on racial genetic differences to the fall meeting here of the National Academy of Sciences.

The superliner United States has canceled a 21-day cruise to the Eastern Atlantic, highlighting uncertainty about its future and the future of other passenger carriers of the merchant marine. The cruise was to have started Nov. 9.
SUNDAY will be toy day at the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn. The Progressive Dog Club will hold its 37th annual show and, as most aficionados know, Progressive limits its entries to toy breeds.
The Nissan Motor Company, Ltd., which has built its reputation on economy cars, is making a determined bid for the middle-priced sports car market.

Representatives of police organizations drawn from 11 American cities -- including New York, Chicago and Los Angeles -- are scheduled to meet in Omaha next month to adopt a constitution for a national police union.
Gregory Sons, a brokerage house with headquarters at 40 Wall Street, was suspended yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange, which appointed a liquidator to take over the business.
MOSCOW, Oct. 22 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist party, said today that the "main road" to space exploration lay in Soviet plans to build orbital space stations.
Rohm Haas, Inc., a large chemical producer, has entered the fiber field with a stretch yarn that has earned a new generic designation from the Federal Trade Commission.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 22 (Reuters) -- Somalia's army-backed Supreme Revolutionary Council, which seized power yesterday, banned all political parties tonight and renamed the African republic. "The Somali Democratic Republic."

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 22 (UPI) -- District Attorney Edmund S. Dinis said today that he had no intention of appealing to any ruling on his petition to allow the exhumation of the body of Mary Jo Kopechne.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- House investigators delved into corporate defense strategy against conglomerate take-overs today, unearthing a story of Wall Street "battle plans," "task forces" and "rescue parties" using everything from Government pressure to the stock market as weapons.
PRINCETON, Oct. 22 -- Eighty-four of every 100 adults in the United States are opposed to the proposal that the use of marijuana be made legal, the Gallup Poll reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Justice Department made available without comment today court documents that included letters and telegrams written by Hubert H. Humphrey, when he was a Senator from Minnesota, on behalf of Napco Industries, Inc., of Minneapolis.
Joe Namath said yesterday he had "fulfilled" his agreement with Pete Rozelle, pro football commissioner, regarding the sale of his part-ownership of the Bachelors III restaurant.

The presidents of the nation's three commercial television networks told a Senate subcommittee yesterday that they favored discounts for commercials by political candidates. Their unanimity was seen as an attempt to head off legislation to make such rate reductions mandatory.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 22 -- Premier Rashid Karami resigned today in the aftermath of clashes between Lebanese forces and Palestinian groups in southern Lebanon and protests from other Arab countries against Beirut's policies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The effects of weightlessness killed the space monkey Bonny after his eight-day orbital flight last summer, a space agency official said today. The official said that something similar could happen to a human attempting an ambitious space flight.

WERE one to construct, from the glass bricks in these diaries, an architectural idea of John Kenneth Galbraith's ego, it would be a cathedral the size of a subcontinent. Beneath each icon would lie a mirror and one of his books. Above each arch would be nailed the stuffed head of a State Department mountebank.
ALBANY, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Public Health will recommend that DDT and certain other pesticides be prohibited from general use in the state within a year.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 22 (AP) -- The suspension of 27 black and Puerto Rican students who barricaded themselves inside a Central Connecticut State College administration building yesterday morning will be lifted nest Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Justice Department filed two briefs today upholding the Government's authority to crack down on young men who return their draft cards. Neither brief bore the signature of Solictor General Erwin N. Griswold, who had taken a different position in the privious Administration.
The Xerox Corporation had increases of 26 per cent in profits and 20 per cent in revenues in both the third quarter and first nine months of this year, again setting records for the periods.

ALTAMONT, N.Y. -- In each region of the country a special sign confirms the beginning of a new season. In the south it is the first whiff of wood smoke that drifts across a burning blue sky; in the Midwest it is the rustling ranks of dry cornstalks.

Plans for a movie "theater-party" in tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., expected to be attended simultaneously by more than one million people in more than 300 cities, were announced here yesterday.

THOSE people-shaped sculptures standing on the main floor of Sachs Quality Store, Eighth Avenue at 35th Street, are actually functional furnishings. Mike Nevelson, the sculptor-son of artist Louise Nevelson, has fashioned chests and cabi nets that sprout heads, arms and feet and have trunks that incorporate either drawers or one-door cabinets.

The widespread violence that marked antiwar demonstrations in Japan this week will do nothing to advance the cause of Japan's post-World War II pacifism. Rather, the violent acts that temporarily converted Tokyo and other Japanese cities into daylong battlegrounds exposed the immaturity and irresponsibility of the youthful "pacifist" demonstrators.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 22 -- A University of Texas coed wept today and an art professor shouted, "You have no feeling for human environment" as a yellow bulldozer tore into a huge cypress on a campus construction site.
Kirk Kerkorian, the Las Vegas hotel, movie and airline investor, succeeded yesterday in having Western Air Lines reorganize its senior management.
CAZZIE RUSSELL stole the ball Tuesday night in the Knicks' rout of the Phoenix Suns, threw a long pass downcourt to Walt Frazier, who passed off behind his back to Dick Barnett in the left corner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Food and Drug Administration is restudying saccharin, monosodium glutamate and two components of baby food in the aftermath of the decision to halt general use of the cyclamates, widely used artificial sweeteners.

SUFFOLK, Va., Oct. 22 -- A Negro civil rights leader and six other persons were arrested here today during a "solidarity" rally, a march in support of striking nonprofessional workers at Louise Obici Memorial Hospital.
The latest national and local figures on the upsweep in the cost of living contribute nothing to the persuasiveness of President Nixon's plea for voluntary wage-price restraint.
JERUSALEM, Thursday, Oct. 23 -- Two Israelis were killed and 16 injured when five bombs, apparently planted by Arab terrorists, exploded yesterday and early today under apartment houses in Haifa.

FILMS of last Saturday's Penn State-Syracuse football game "show no evidence of a laxity in officiating," according to Asa Bushnell, commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference and the man who assigned the five officials to the game.

Mayor Lindsay and Controller Mario A. Procaccino demanded yesterday that any new policy to admit more Negroes and Puerto Ricans to City University guarantee places in its four-year senior colleges for high school graduates whose grades would qualify them now.

NEW YORK enthusiasts this weekend will have their last opportunity in the sixties to win red points and gold points -- the hard currency of life master qualification -- in the metropolitan area. The Long Island Regional Championships begin today at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I., a setting not unaccustomed to tense concentration and furious argument.
An antipoverty clash involving a competition for power between Puerto Ricans and Negroes in the Bronx will be taken up tonight by the city's Council Against Poverty.
PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Massive shifts are taking place in the flows of hot money as the West German Government prepares to peg the mark to a new, higher parity.

Those little coupons you get in the mail or newspapers or magazines that promise so much money off on the price of some product or other must be a great stimulus to sales or there wouldn't be so many of them.

Silver futures were still caught yesterday in the turmoil of uncertainty over whether the joint Senate-House committee will approve a silver Eisenhower dollar or a copper-nickel coin. Prices recovered from Tuesday's weakness.

Leading tennis nations and the International Lawn Tennis Federation are studying a proposal by Jack Kramer that he says will help resolve the complex situation the sport is now in and stimulate its growth throughout the world.
Bargaining talks are continuing in the Metropolitan Opera dispute, but no progress was reported in the key negotiations involving the orchestra.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- A threatened nationwide railroad walkout was canceled today, giving Italians a significant but expensive respite from an onslaught of fall strikes that shows few other immediate signs of slackening.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- More than 100 scientists from 30 countries, including the United States, attended the opening today in Sochi of the 19th International Pugwash Conference to discuss the problem of disarmament.
Federal Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon denounced yesterday members of a Mount Vernon, N.Y., draft board for their "blatantly lawless" refusal to grant a deferment to a University of Bridgeport student.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Vice President Agnew accused Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine today of suggesting that the President "play Russian roulette with U.S. security."
The cost of living in the New York City area rose a sharp 0.8 per cent in September as higher prices for everything except transportation here kept the city an inflationary step ahead of the nation.

Union Theological Seminary and the rest of the Columbia University community joined yesterday in an ecumenical service welcoming 60 scholastics and 10 priests of the Jesuit Woodstock College to Morningside Heights.

Current legislation in Congress sponsored by Representative Patsy Mink of Hawaii to require inclusion of a substance to prevent glue-sniffing by youngsters is a positive step toward ending a growing evil.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 21 -- As the parade to celebrate the nationalization of the Bolivia Gulf Oil Company formed Monday, militant union members struggled with their parrade marshals to get ahead of the military leaders in dress uniform leading the march.
A Lower East Side grocer, held up by three men, pursued them out of his store, the police said, and stabbed one to death and wounded the others.

Controller Mario A. Procaccino on pornography (in a statement read in Washington) -- Unbridled pornography is a disease that can ravage a nation, rob it of its strength, dissipate its talent and lay waste its national heritage. History itself proves that either we must destroy it or it will destroy us.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 22 -- The pro-Communist Pathet Lao movement has accused the United States of intensifying its "special war" in Laos.

The Cloisters has acquired a second major manuscript painted by Jean Pucelle, the 14th-century court artist and illuminator.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- Japan's New Left, composed of radical, extremist students, stole much of the thunder from the established and organized "Old Left" of Socialists, Communists and trade unionists in yesterday's nationwide demonstrations marking "international antiwar day," observers here agreed.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- A birthday cake was ruled out of order today in the trial of the Chicago Eight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee approved today a bill designed to make available an additional $3-billion in Federal funds for home mortgages. The measure has been opposed by the Nixon Administration.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 22 -- President Eduardo Frei Montalva asserted today that Chile weathered an attempted coup yesterday by army officers. But the officers insisted that their 24-hour revolt had been nothing more than a strike for higher wages and better working conditions.

The last of a great library of Americana was auctioned yesterday, bringing $3,104,982 for a collection assembled during a lifetime by the late Thomas Winthrop Streeter, a banker who lived for many years in Morristown, N. J.

Fruit and fruit cocktail packers, hit hard by the ban on cyclamates, are urging a slowdown in its enforcement.

YONKERS, Oct. 22 -- Neither the filly nor her driver enjoyed the best of health, but Nancy Lynne and Stanley Dancer enjoyed their easiest race together this season at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Neither a skin infection on two legs nor a virus attack that affected Dancer prevented Nancy Lynne from winning the $71,250 New York Sire Stakes for 3-year-old trotting fillies.

Four weeks after he feared his football career had ended, Jim Hudson will return to the New York Jets Sunday for their Shea Stadium game with the Boston Patriots.

At a hearing called for consumer complaints against moving companies, Commissioner of Consumer Affairs Bess Myerson Grant yesterday made four proposals to bring the industry under tighter city regulation.

Bailar found the wind and the weight much to his liking at Aqueduct yesterday. Stephen Clark's 4-year-old gelding toted top poundage of 123 pounds in the 1 1-16-mile turf contest that served as the feature on the card, and he won the event by a length over Chance Hill Farm's Big Shot II.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 22 -- The possibility of resumpion of Red Cross relief flights into Biafra seemed to recede today as Biafra put forth new proposals on how the food shipments should be handled.

WILLIAM STEINBERG started last evening on the podium of the Philharmonic Hall stage, and ended it in Roosevelt Hospital. At the end of the intermission Thomas D. Perry Jr., manager of the Boston Symphony, told the audience that Mr. Steinberg had been taken ill, and that the assistant conductor Michael Tilson Thomas, would complete the concert.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Leading officials of the Nixon Administration have left some conflicting impressions about orders to the troops in Vietnam, but Defense Secretary Laird today defined those orders with remarks similar to those made by field commanders in the war zone.
Reynolds Co., a major New York brokerage house, and Courts Co., a large regional securities house based in Atlanta, announced yesterday plans to merge.

Procaccino used the opportunity to begin develop-loyalty to the Democratic partying a new campaign theme: For 59 minutes on radio station WINS, the Controller, Mayor Lindsay and State Senator John J. Marchi recited familiar campaign rhetoric and charges, occasionally spicing them with stronger language than they had used in the past.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 -- Today was Canadian Day in the international jumping competition of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show. Vermont is enjoying a record early start for its ski season. A storm that began on Wednesday and deposited as many as 25 inches on the Green Mountain State's central elevations had snow runners cavorting yesterday.

Paul F. Cowie has been elected group vice president-administration of the Standard Poor's Corporation. He also was elected a director of Standard Poor's, a member of the executive committee and chairman of the personnel management committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- By accusing Senator Edmund S. Muskie of playing "Russian roulette with United States security," Vice President Agnew may have provoked Senate consideration of a proposed moratorium on testing of multiple warheads for missiles.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 23 -- Samuel Beckett, the avant-garde writer acclaimed for his plays and novels of loneliness, despair and human degradation, was announced today as the winner of the 1969 Nobel Prize in Literature.
As a result of a complaint by a Government secretary, Federal agents yesterday seized $5-million in securities held here for the account of a Hong Kong brokerage company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Art Linkletter, the television entertainer -- an old friend of President Nixon -- came to the White House today and recited the personal tragedy of his daughter's suicide after her use of hallucinatory drugs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Treasury auctioned $3-blion of 236-daytax-anticipation bills today at an average discount rate of 7.205 per cent, the lowestlevel since a tax bill offering on July 11 when the rate was 7.201 per cent, it announced tonight.

This autobiography by the English scholar and teacher goes over very familiar ground: a comfortable childhood in the late Victorian era, adolescence in Edwardian times, maturity and growth during the years of the First World War, a time that shattered forever the age and values into which he had been born.

MONTREAL, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press) -- The city administration reached agreement today with its police and firemen on the terms of new contracts, bringing an end to a dispute that resulted in a 16-hour walkout by the two forces Oct. 7.
The Federal Communications Commission is expected to announce today that two opposing license applications to operate WPIX-TV, Channel 11, here have been designated for a comparative hearing.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 23 -- Officials of Local 1066 of the Uniformed Firefighters Association met today with Francis X. Hayes, first assistant corporation counsel of Jersey City, to draw up a new contract providing a pay increase of $1,900 for city firemen.
ATLANTA, Oct. 23 (AP -- Atlanta paid tribute today to a member of the New York Mets, the team that kept this city's Braves from participating in the 1969 World Series.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Industry spokesmen told Federal officials today that they were all for the abatement of water pollution but that it should not be carried to the point of trying to make waterways too clean too soon or causing too great an impact on company profits.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court voted unanimously today to bar the name of Ambrose T. Lane, a Negro Independent candidate for Mayor of Buffalo, from the Nov. 4 ballot.

The Purex Corporation, Ltd., a major producer of bleach, soap and cleaning products, announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire three industrial and chemical companies for an undisclosed amount of stock.
GENEVA, Oct. 23 -- The United States and the Soviet Union decided today to make five concessions to critics of their joint proposal to ban nuclear weapons from the ocean floor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- President Nixon and Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi of Iran exchanged pledges of continuing cordiality at the conclusion of a three-day state visit spent largely discussing the military implications of Britain's scheduled withdrawal from the Persian Gulf area in 1971.
Mayor Lindsay inspected new snow-removal equipment yesterday, announced a revised strategy for coping with blizzards and assured Queens housewives they would never be snowbound again.

He played two dozen harpsichord works by Couperin, Rameau and Scarlatti, but instead of grouping them in historical order, or according to composer, he arranged "A Program of Musical Images," offering categories called "The City," "The Dance," "The Theater" and "The Country."
LISBON, Oct. 23 -- The campaign for the Portuguese parliamentary elections Sunday has a style all its own.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The first Sergeant Major of the Army and three other former custodians of enlisted men's clubs invoked the Fifth Amendment today as Senate investigators sought to link them to a "pattern of systematic pilfering" that allegedly took hundreds of thousands of dollars from the service facilities.

Soybeans, soybean oil and soybean meal provided the most activity in the commodities market yesterday. Most contracts closed higher than on the previous day in continued heavy trading. Many months registered new life-of-contract highs.

Pick your candidate for good reasons, not for negative ones. Make your vote an affirmative vote, rather than a vote against a man you may not like.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission has agreed to lift the secrecy that has long cloaked its decisions on many issues ranging from merger approvals to deceptive advertising.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Europe's currency dealings turned brisk today as West Germany's Socialist-led coalition fixed a Cabinet meeting for tomorrow to determine a new parity for the four-week-old "floating" mark.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Rick Barry, star of the Washington Caps of American Basketball Association, will undergo surgery tomorrow to remove a cartilage in his left knee, the second time within a year he has had to have such an operation.
