THOSE who lack tickets for sold-out Shea Stadium have two pro football games to watch on television tomorrow afternoon: St. Louis at Cleveland at 1 o'clock, Channel 2, and Oakland at San Diego at 4 o'clock, Channel 4.

After re-examining motion pictures of last Saturday's Syracuse-Penn State game at the Orange's Archbold Stadium, officials of the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association issued a statement yesterday in which they again maintained they could see "no evidence of laxity or inefficiency in the officiating performances."

NEW DELHI, Oct. 24 -- The government in Kerala -- one of India's two Communist-led state governments -- collapsed today. While the immediate cause was a vote on investigating charges of corruption, the collapse was the climax of months of bitter feuding between the Left Communists, who dominated the coalition, and the Right Communists, who were losing ground to them.
LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Two elderly Britons who have lived much of their life in China have been arrested in Shanghai on unspecified charges, the British Foreign Office was informed today.
Temperatures in the city fell to a record low for the second day in a row yesterday as premature wintry blasts from Canada forced the mercury below the freezing point.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The United States exported $270.9-million more in merchandise than it imported during September, resulting in the year's largest monthly trade balance, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Stock prices surged upward yesterday along a broad front after a one-day spate of profit taking as they closed at the best levels since early July.

Aetna Life Casualty announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Urban Investment and Development Company, a Chicago-based real estate development and management firm, for stock valued at about $58-million.
Mayor Lindsay increased his lead over his two opponents for Mayor in the second run of The New York Daily News straw vote.

This fall across the nation more parents than ever before will notice the absence of any letter grades, such as 'U' for unsatisfactory, on their elementary school child's report card. This continues a trend, according to education experts, toward more individualized education and more specific progress reports.

The United Nations celebrated its 24th birthday yesterday sitting idly on a powder keg largely of its own making -- the outbreak of open warfare between the Lebanese Government and Palestine refugees.

At any rate, color TV will be transmitted from the command module.

BRASILIA, Oct. 25 -- The Brazilian Congress this afternoon officially ratified the designation by the armed forces high command of Gen. Emilio Garrastazu Medici as President of Brazil. Adm. Augusto Rademaker Grunewald was elected Vice President.

BENNINGTON, N. H. -- So many times in the recent past, ski enthusiasts have become so enamored of the sport that they have decided to buy mountains for use as ski centers. It has happened again here in the Monadnock region of the Granite State. The Onset ski area, which is being created on the south side of Crotched Mountain, is scheduled to welcome its first customers in mid-December.

Louis I. Kahn, who designed the Yale Art Gallery 15 years ago, yesterday was named architect for Yale's new Paul Mellon Center for British Art and British Studies, to be built on the other side of Chapel Street in New Haven.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Paul W. Kayser and Darrell Grisham are successful businessmen and officials of the National Alliance of Businessmen. There the comparison ends.
SOCHI, U.S.S.R. Oct. 25 -Scientists attending the 12th annual Pugwash Conference have heard that Argentina appears to be developing the ability to produce nuclear weapons.
The Seven Sisters -- Barnard, Bryn Mawr, Mount Holyoke, Radcliffe, Smith, Vassar and Wellesley -- have decided not to break up the family.
The Times has been lavish in its praise of Mayor Lindsay in recommending him to the electorate. I trust a dissenting opinion may be permitted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A Republican member of the House from Ohio, John M. Ashbrook, has raised "substantial" campaign contributions from conservatives around the country to try to defeat Mayor Lindsay for re-election in New York City.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 26 (UPI) -- Denis Hulme, leading from the start, lapped the field today as he drove his McLaren Chevrolet to victory in the $100,000 Times Grand Prix, the next-to-last event of the Canadian - American Challenge Cup series for sports cars.
DETROIT, Oct. 26 -- Improved bumpers that will reduce collision damage and repair costs are being designed and may be on cars in two years, according to an official of the Ford Motor Company.

William Kunstler a lawyer for two American pacifists, returned last night from a meeting with the North Vietnamese delegation to the Paris peace talks, and said the North Vietnamese had agreed to release "extremely important" information about American prisoners of war that would relieve the anxiety of the prisoners' relatives.
DALLAS, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- A Federal narcotics agent charged with the shooting death of his girl friend surrendered to Dallas County Sheriff's officers tonight after a day-long statewide search.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 26 -- The board of governors of the American Trial Lawyers Association asserted in a resolution today that the confirmation of Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. as a Justice of the Supreme Court would "undermine" public confidence in the Court.

A wildcat with glaring eyes and bared fangs greets readers of the Kansas State University football guide this year. Outlined against a background of grass and greenery, four prophetic words are printed on the cover: "Out of the Woods."

Representative William T. Cahill, the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, and the Democratic rival, former Gov. Robert B. Meyner, engaged in a bitter argument after a television debate yesterday until Mr. Cahill stalked away in anger.
Last summer, even before the Jets began their training camp, Bill Rademacher and John Dockery worked out together at Hofstra University. Yesterday, they worked against each other at Shea Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Twenty years after television began to have an impact on national politics, Congress has finally begun to grapple with the complex problems raised by this very expensive, very effective medium.
APHI Beta Kappa from Vassar College, Mrs. Alan Jay Lerner was a reporter for Life and Newsweek magazines before her marriage to the lyricist and producer in 1966.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Two days of intensive discussion by a panel of environmental specialists on Capitol Hill this weekend failed to throw much light on their assigned subject: "priorities" for national action.

Orders for machine tools, which indicate how business views the economy and specifically the need for production equipment a year or more in advance, continue in the doldrums, according to an analysis of figures released in Washington yesterday by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.
The Navy has carried the idea of midair refueling to incredible lengths.

MOSCOW, Oct. 26 -- Ranking Western diplomats said today that while they believed Soviet political leaders sincerely wished to reach accords with the United States on strategic arms limitations, Soviet military leaders appeared less than enthusiastic about this policy.

AVON, Conn., Oct. 26 -- With Doug Armbruster handling the reins, Sport captured one class and finished third in another to compile 8 points and win the junior jumper championship today at the River Farms horse show.
ITEM: A girl, 18, trips in the crack between the concrete blocks on a roller skating rink at Jones Beach. She breaks her leg.
ALBANY, Oct. 26 -- A year in advance of the 1970 election, in which Governor Rockefeller has said he will seek a fourth term, the Governor is campaigning as though the election were next week.

The Canadiens have Jean Beliveau only part-time these days, J. C. Tremblay's wrist hurts, Yvan Cournoyer's nose is broken, Dick Duff is having delicate surgery and Gilles Tremblay is out for the season.

Automation Industries, Inc., announced yesterday it had agreed to acquire Southwest Steel Rolling Mills of Los Angeles, a privately held concern. The purchase price was not disclosed. Automation said the acquisition would be effective July 1, bringing it half of Southwest's expected $18-million in 1969 sales.

The University of Pennsylvania's football team went to Princeton on Saturday and received a 42-to-0 drubbing. But Jane Grant,a willowly blond senior who majors in French, decided to come to New York to canvass for votes for Mayor Lindsay.
Mayor Lindsay announced interim appointments yesterday for three new Civil Court judgeships -- two Democrats and a Republican -- to serve until Dec. 31.

Richard Nixon's speech to the Inter-American Press Association in Washington Friday will be one of the most important ever delivered on Latin America by a President of the United States. A galloping crisis in the hemisphere and the accident of timing have combined to make the occasion a kind of political watershed.

The Sunday afternoon jazz concerts presented by Jazz Interactions began their fifth year this month in one of the most pleasant and appropriate settings the series has found in its peripatetic career. The concerts are now held at Danny's Restaurant, 345 West 46th Street, a small room with a warm, subdued and gracious atmosphere.
The grandest kind of Brahms, big, warm and completely uneccentric, was provided by John Ogdon yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.
Little political activity has been displayed in recent days in Central Harlem's 72d Assembly District, but most of that activity has been on behalf of John V. Lindsay.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 26 -There was a lull today in the struggle between the Palestinian commandos and the Lebanese Army as word spread that President Nasser was leading mediation efforts.

ABBAYE DE BOQUEN, France, Oct. 26 -- Thousands of Roman Catholics prayed today in solidarity with Dom Bernard Besret, who has been dismissed as Abbot, or head, of this Cistercian monastery under conservative pressure.

DALLAS, Oct. 26 -- The Giants made their longest trip of the season today, 1,375 miles as the chartered airplane flies. They will not have to travel this far again unless they should happen to win their division championship.

SAN DIEGO, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- Daryle Lamonica threw three touchdown passes as the undefeated Oakland Raiders beat the San Diego Chargers, 24-12, today. The victory was Oakland's sixth and the Raiders have been tied once.

BEFORE a distinguished audience, amid speeches and television cameras, events set in motion 10 years ago came to fruition yesterday. It was 10 years ago that President Eisenhower broke ground for Lincoln Center. It was only last Oct. 2 that students and faculty filed into the Juilliard School to set things going in the last of the Lincoln Center buildings and constituents.

Whitney M. Young, the director of the National Urban League, told a Harlem audience yesterday that charges of "Uncle Tom" and "sell-out" against Negroes who accepted positions of leadership were harming the cause of equality.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Bruce Gossett kicked three field goals, two set up by breaks, to rally the undefeated Los Angeles Rams to a 9-7 victory over the Chicago Bears today in a National Football League game.

The Washington Darts won the American Soccer League championship for the second year in a row yesterday, while the New York Greek-Americans were defeated for the first time in 13 months in the German-American League.

The state chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People demanded yesterday that Governor Rockefeller call a special session of the Legislature next month to restore cuts in welfare payments, endorse the concept of a negative income tax and develop "bold new welfare programs" aimed at the rehabilitation of the poor.

SYDNEY Australia, Oct. 26 -- Prime Minister John G. Gorton's conservative Government appeared to be only one seat away from retaining a majority in the House of Representatives when the counting of votes in yesterday's election stopped tonight.

Just One Break, Inc., a nonprofit placement agency for the permanently physically disabled, has planned its second annual card party for Nov. 9 and its 17th annual Feather Ball for May 5. Both benefits will be held at the Pierre.

PRAGUE, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Jail terms ranging from five months to two years have been given a group of Czechoslovak youths accused of having ransacked a regional Soviet occupation headquarters in the "ice hockey riots" last March, the Prague press reported today.
Five winners of this year's Howard W. Blakeslee Award for distinguished reporting on diseases of the heart and blood vessels were announced yesterday by the American Heart Association.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- Richard Cardinal Cushing, Archbishop of Boston, defended today his decision to negotiate the sale of a Roman Catholic high school to the city of Gloucester because of financial problems.

Substantially larger sales and earnings were achieved by Texas Instruments, Inc., in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, it was reported from Dallas over the weekend.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26 -- Government troops have clashed twice with North Vietnamese soldiers on a highway outside Benhet, the Special Forces camp that was under heavy siege earlier this year, South Vietnamese sources said today.
VIENNA, Oct. 26 -- A 10-day congress of the World Federation of Trade Unions in Budapest, Hungary, ended today with signs of division in the Communist-dominated organization.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown said yesterday that a man identifying himself as being from House Speaker John W. McCormack's office had once arranged for a friend of the Speaker to see him and ask for the parole of a California convict.

WOMBWELL, England Oct. 26 -- Fifty-five-year-old Alf Catling, one of the 125,000 miners in Britain prolonging an unofficial coal strike, says that he never wanted to work in the mines but that a man like himself had no choice.

As if startled out of their lethargy by the incongruous sight of Joe Namath hobbling upfield for a 16-yard gain in a critical third-down situation early in the final quarter, the New York Jets rallied yesterday for a 23-17 victory over the Boston Patriots.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 26 -- Gene Tunney, the former heavyweight boxing champion, announced last night that his 30-year-old daughter, Mrs. Joan Tunney Wilkinson, had been found alive after having been missing in Europe for nearly two months.

JOE ORTON must have been one of the most anarchic playwrights who ever lived. And one of the bitterest. His bitterness spews out like bile, and yet there is also a wary, observant sweetness to give a zany contrast to all this blackness.

The credit markets, which faltered a bit late last week, still are dominated by the belief that interest rates are headed downward.

Two Federal grants will make the city's new ambulance-station techniques available in other urban areas and will allow them to be expanded elsewhere in the city according to Joseph V. Terenzio, the Hospitals Commissioner.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 26 -- Although the official results of the fifth annual Head-of-theCharles regatta will not be tabulated until tomorrow, Harvard University was considered today to be a certain over-all point winner for the second straight year.

The recent television debate between the three candidates in the mayoralty race has shown that Mayor Lindsay is the least of the three evils that will be placed before the New York City voters on Nov. 4. CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- This month marks the 300th anniversary of the death of Rembrandt van Rijn, who died in Amsterdam on Oct. 4, 1669. Rembrandt is still the most universally admired of all the great masters, and it was inevitable that some of our leading museums would want to mark this anniversary with an exhibition more or less in keeping with the size and quality of the artist's achievement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- There is both hope and trepidation among knowledgeable officials here as they prepare for talks with the Russians next month on the life-and-death issues of how to control the nuclear arms race.

The Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory has a Department of Transportation contract to study new braking systems for future trains running at 250 to 300 miles an hour. A coalition of 13 unions representing 147,000 General Electric workers began a nationwide strike at 12:01 A.M. today against the country's fourth largest industrial corporation.

Now that the Sanitation Men's Union has let bygones be bygones and endorsed Mayor Lindsay for re-election, New York City teachers who still want to punish the Mayor for his role in teachers' strikes should reconsider. The heated campaign in New Jersey is leaving many voters cool. The two candidates spend much time and energy belaboring each other with charges of conflict of interest but neither has put forward a really progressive program for dealing with the urgent social and political problems that afflict the Garden State. However, former Gov. Robert B. Meyner, the Democratic nominee, is clearly preferable to his Republican rival, Representative William T. Cahill.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Drawing a mixed balance sheet on a decade of student exchanges with the Soviet Union, Robert F. Byrnes, retired academic coordinator of the program, called today for advance planning for a similar, but better, exchange program with Communist China.

" MARRIAGE is enough for me," Mrs. David Susskind said. The room, facing the East River and the United Nations buildings, was flooded with sunshine. It shone on a face that for almost a decade was seen frequently on television screens in the United States and Canada.

CHINESE CAMP, Calif. -Back in the Gold Rush era of the 1850's, Chinese Camp was a brawling, squalling town of 5,000 miners, scratching their fortunes out of the undulant foothills of the Sierra Nevada. But the last working gold mines closed here in 1948, when rising labor costs made it uneconomical to recover the remaining low-grade ore.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 24 -- The people of Minneapolis during Moratorium Day on Oct. 15 had the unusual experience of seeing their new Mayor personally directing a police riot squad as it broke up a small crowd of demonstrators at the entrance to this city's new shopping mall.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The African countries succeeded today in their campaign to win a third place on the 15-seat World Court. The place was won at the expense of the Asian candidates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -The three-month Treasury bill rate advanced a bit at today's auction from last week's levels, but the six-month bill showed little change, the Government reported late this afternoon.

Young Concert Artists, a nonprofit organization for the promotion thereof, began its activities some years ago in a Greenwich Village restaurant. It gradually moved uptown, and last night it opened its ninth season in the elegance of the new Alice Tully Hall.

New York City has the largest park system -- 37,262 acres -- and potentially the best of any large city in the country. When Mayor Lindsay took office four years ago that system was in deplorable shape. Many of the parks were unsafe for visitors at any hour; much of the equipment was horribly dilapidated; vandalism and neglect left their marks almost everywhere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The Commerce Department predicted today that home construction would continue to slump for the next few months at least.

Walter Kennedy, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, canceled a recent transaction that sent Sam Williams from the Milwaukee Bucks to the Los Angeles Lakers and directed yesterday that the player be returned immediately to the Bucks' active roster.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the constitutionality of the Federal law that gives individuals the power to stop companies from mailing advertisements for erotic wares to their homes.

CAIRO, Oct. 27 -- The commander of the Lebanese Army, Gen. Emile Bustani, will come to Cairo within the next 24 hours to try to negotiate a solution of the crisis with Palestinian commandos, it was reported here tonight.

HIGH POINT, N. C. -- No one seems sure who the crown prince is, but a new king appears ready to be crowned in the furniture market.

In Room 702 at the Hospital for Special Surgery yesterday, Jim Hudson reached down to scratch his right thigh, and suddenly he realized that he couldn't. Only his toes protruded from the white cast that covered the leg.
A 17-year-old boy was suspended from school yesterday for refusing either to stand up or leave the room when his class pledged allegiance to the flag.

The J. C. Penney Company, Inc., one of the largest department -store and catalogue chains, will open 180 of its 1,650 stores on Sundays, starting Nov. 9. Penney's announcement of its plan here yesterday follows a recent decision by Sears, Roebuck Co. to open 150 of its stores on Sunday during November and December.

The stock market felt the mild pinch of profit taking yesterday, following its rapid advance of the last two weeks. Some popular stock averages closed with losses, but advances ran ahead of declines on the New York Stock Exchange by 740 to 639.

SUVA, Fiji Islands -- A leisurely stroll and a whim helped put Mrs. Cherie Whiteside in the dress business in this polyglot South Seas capital about nine years ago.

Norman Cousins, editor of The Saturday Review, has been elected chairman of the board of directors of National Educational Television, it was announced yesterday by James Day, N.E.T. president. Mr. Cousins succeeds Everett N. Case, who recently retired.

One of the most effective programs in the Office of Economic Opportunity is legal services, under which 1,800 attorneys in 800 neighborhood offices in forty-nine states represent impoverished clients. Federal funds administered through the O.E.O. enable hundreds of thousands of indigent persons every year to obtain equal justice under law.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 28 -- The National Product Safety Commission agreed today that the number of fires in television sets was high enough to warrant a full report to the public.

Gains in earnings were reported yesterday by the Gulf Oil Corporation, the Cities Service Company and the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company for the nine months ended Sept. 30. Only Gulf showed a decline for the third quarter.
Prices closed mostly lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in moderate trading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, asserted today that the United States was engaged in a clandestine war in Laos without the knowledge or authority of Congress.
John Reaves, the flashy Florida quarterback, could become college football's most proficient scoring passer if he continues his current touchdown trend.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- High-ranking diplomats of the United States and Soviet Union conferred today on ways to reduce tensions in Lebanon, the State Department disclosed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Vice President Agnew, whose quotes recently have become conversation pieces, fluffed a punch line today in an awards ceremony at the Pentagon.

The Bronx District Attorney announced yesterday the indictment of 16 welfare recipients who allegedly received more than $30,000 in illegal payments, and two welfare caseworkers accused of falsifying records to obtain extra relief.

SAIGON, Oct. 28 -- Fighting has increased slightly in the last three days and military analysts here are accumulating evidence that North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces are planning still further Intensification in mid-November.
School officials, physicians and social agencies estimate that one area of Brooklyn has the highest proportion of defective and educationally retarded individuals in the city.

IN its original New York run "Lend an Ear" was something of a freakish success. Charles Gaynor had written the book, music and lyrics in the early '40s, had staged the intimate revue in Pittsburgh and Cohasset, Mass., and then shelved it during World War II.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- A bitter and persistent outburst by Bobby G. Seale forced an early recess today in the conspiracy trial of the "Chicago Eight."

The Hazeltine Corporation announced yesterday that a court judgment of $18,892,173 entered against a subsidiary in 1965 in an antitrust case had been vacated by the United States Court of Appeals in Chicago.

IS IT possible that the tax-reform bill could tip the balance and push the economy into a full-scale recession in 1970? There can be no question but that the tax-reform legislation is the most earth-shaking since the Revenue Act of 1954 and it has reportedly caused even greater division within the tax fraternity than the earlier bill.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Jim Harding, the University of Detroit's recently named basketball coach, took a hard line today in quelling a brief revolt by players apparently critical of long practice sessions.

The Philadelphia Orchestra's concert last night at Philharmonic Hall concentrated on 20th-century music, though in so determinedly antique a manner that one wondered why Eugene Ormandy, who conducted, thought it worth the trouble.
Stars of the stage and screen who will perform in a concert of the music of Kurt Weill on Nov. 9 at Philharmonic Hall will be guests of honor at a supper dance at the Plaza after the concert.
Stock prices drifted lower yesterday in the absence of either selling pressure or compelling news.
ALBANY, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals ordered today that the name of third-party candidate Ambrose I. Lane be restored to the Nov. 4 election ballot for mayor of Buffalo.

A former neighborhood youth counselor in Queens was sentenced to 30 days in prison and fined $250 yesterday for having refused to testify before a Queens grand jury investigating charges that the Lindsay administration had put "hardened criminals" on the city's payroll.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 28 -- Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, called upon the Lebanese populace today for support against elements in the Beirut Government that oppose the activities of Palestinian forces in Lebanon.

Laughter and tears are the fundamental business of the theater and Choreoconcerts and Critiques blends the twin humors easily. Last night at the New School, in the final program of its fall dance-and-talk series, the mixture of elements was split evenly between the somber and the smiling.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller announced the appointment today of a 16-member state commission of leaders in business, labor, education and the Legislature to make "a pentrating analysis" of education. The study will emphasize the financing of public and private elementary and secondary schools.
The Times on Oct. 24 reported that an F.B.I. paid informant "had become a member of the steering committee . . . of the Crazies, a group noted for disrupting gatherings of liberals."

CAIRO, Oct. 28 -- Abubakr Awadallah, the left-wing Premier of the Sudan, was deposed today by the country's Revolutionary Command Council following a dispute that the Premier had touched off about the role of Communists in the regime.

THE least you can say about Eliot Feld is that he is irrepressible. Last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where his troupe, the American Ballet Company, is giving its American debut season, he danced in the world premiere of his ballet, "Pagan Spring."
VIENNA, Oct. 28 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist party chief, Dr. Gustav Husak, and other party and Government leaders returned today from Moscow with soviet promises of increased economic help.
According to a survey by the American Association of Advertising Agencies, most of its members that have tried outside media-buying services do not intend to do it again.

LISBON, Oct. 28 -- Complete return today for the National Assembly elections Sunday gave 88 per cent of the votes and all of the seats to the Government's National Union and 12 per cent to the opposition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Administration officials assured Congress repeatedly today that the controversial Philadelphia plan did not require an employer to increase minority employment on Federal construction projects but only called on the employer to make a "good faith effort" to do so.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Sixty-five square miles of inland bays lying between Atlantic City and the mainland have been condemned as being too polluted for shellfishing, swimming or even water-skiing.

Governor Rockefeller and two other high state officials were directed yesterday to show cause why they should not be held in contempt of court for failing to appeal a court ruling that the state's $6.9-billion budget is unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today its earnings in the third quarter of this year fell to $3-million, the smallest figure since the association became a private corporation at the beginning of this year.

PERHAPS the earth shook the day Annie Mae Bank-head first set foot on the dusty roads of College Station, Ark. For since Jan. 16, 1926 -- the day she arrived -- the small, slender woman has been putting a powerful will to work changing an impoverished and deteriorating all-black community into a healthy, growing integrated town.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- The Commerce Department reported today that its index of leading business indicators rose 1.3 per cent last month, a sharp setback for inflation fighters in the Nixon Administration.

Theodore W. Kheel, chairman of the Mayor's Committee to Save the 20-Cent Fare, contended yesterday that the Port of New York Authority had a surplus of nearly $80-million in 1967 and complained that it had remained silent when "misinformation" was publicized that the amount was $6.4-million.
The city's Board of Elections has printed 400,000 paper ballots to be held in reserve for Election Day in case of breakdowns in voting machines.

Joseph Monserrat, president of the Board of Education, told a group of about 50 school principals yesterday that the New York public school system was "behind the times" and that there was a "new ball game" in education today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board was urged by its own staff today to let Pan American World Airways take further financial control of New York Airways, which operates helicopter service between the three major New York airports and Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- John W. Gardner, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that much of the $53-billion the nation spends on health each year is wasted.

JERUSALEM, Wednesday, Oct. 29 -- Premier Golda Meir's ruling Labor party was returned to power yesterday in the Israeli general election. Incomplete returns showed that a shift toward the right appeared to have deprived the governing political alignment of an absolute majority in the seventh parliament, the Knesset.

IT had been too long since I heard a live performance of Beethoven's Op. 131, so I attended the Juilliard String Quartet concert last night at Alice Tully Hall. It was a fine program all around, the Beethoven C sharp minor Quartet balanced by Mozart's "Dissonant" Quartet and the world premiere of Stefan Wolpe's two-movement, 16-minute-long String Quartet.
The Giants did not get Donny Anderson of the Packers yesterday but, on the other hand, they did not give up Homer Jones.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 28 -- An authority on intergroup relations accused American Jewish organizations today of failing to respond with effective programs to alleviate "the pain of the black community."

Carnegie Recital Hall was filled to overflowing with trumpeters and their friends last night as Martin Berinbaum presented concert of Baroque music featuring a miniature trumpet that plays in a range an octave higher than the instrument we hear most often nowadays. To play such music on such an instrument all evening is not easy, but Mr. Berinbaum got through his assignment, and was still sounding pretty good at the end.
There was a blur of silks and another winner ridden by Rudy L. Turcotte surged to the front in the closing strides at Aqueduct yesterday.

BONN -- Revaluation of the German mark is but the latest step in a profound financial revolution that has reshaped the Bretton Woods agreement establishing an international currency system after World War II.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The prize for the jumping competition at the Washington International Horse Show tonight was the Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Perpetual Trophy, in competition for the first time, and it went to an American youth and a young mare affectionately called Mule.

Soybean futures prices continued to drop yesterday, probably under the influence of some hedge selling. Earlier in the week the prospect of the large carryover from the preceding crop inspired some selling.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 26 -- Just below the surface of many political tensions and social ills in the Domincan Republic lies the problem of almost unbridled childbirth among the poor.
Sanford D. Garelik, the Republican-Liberal candidate for City Council President, won the endorsement yesterday of Democratic State Assemblyman Guy R. Brewer of the 26th District in Queens.

LIKE the citizens of Pompeii, the New York Giants were perched at the base of the volcano the night before last. They were tilling their fields and going about their business with unexpected skill against the Cowboys in Dallas before a nationwide television audience. But a sense of impending disaster could never have left them because subterranean seethings or ungovernable force signaled an eventual breakthrough of the crust.

Your Oct. 20 news article noting apparent voter apathy to Amendment No. 2 to the State Constitution is very disquieting. Amendment No. 2 on the ballot in November will increase the state-guaranteed borrowing power of the State Job Development Authority as well as permit its loan funds to revolve.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 28 -- The General Electric Company expects sales outside of the United States to approach $2-billion this year, J. Stanford Smith, vice president and group executive-international group, said here today.

HONG KONG, Oct. 28 -- Peking today hailed the downfall of the Communist-dominated Kerala state government in India as proving the Chinese Communist thesis that there is no "revisionist," parliamentary road to Communism.

The narcotics-conspiracy conviction of two former city detectives was reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals because the prosecution had failed, before trial, to disclose that the seized cocaine had undergone a new, revolutionary test to identify it as evidence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- As the time approaches for his report to the nation on Vietnam, President Nixon is said to be trying to write a speech that will convince the country of his determination to withdraw systematically from the war, but preferably without a commitment to a fixed timetable or a deadline.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Ohio Highway Patrol reported today that it had found no evidence that money had been offered or paid in connection with the commutation of the life sentence of Thomas (Yonnie) Licavoli, a former Toledo mob figure.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. announced yesterday the election of Louis H. Roddis Jr. as president, effective Saturday.

The United States Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday that General Electric's widely publicized "take-it-or-leave-it" bargaining approach was a violation of the National Labor Relations Act's mandate to bargain "in good faith."

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia, in a document issued today, called on West Germany to grant "international legal recognition" to East Germany as one of the "just demands" before Bonn could improve relations with Eastern Europe.

Controller Mario A. Procaccino on his campaign's progress (in an interview) -- I have been in many campaigns and you can tell in contacts with the voters whether you are losing support. I have truly found warm response everywhere and feel that the people are for me.

Both John S. Knight and Walter H. Annenberg, the principals in the sale yesterday of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Daily News, built their publishing empires on solid bases provided by their fathers.

The Greyhound Corporation announced yesterday it had signed a definitive agreement with the General Host Corporation which will allow the transportation company to increase its interest to almost 90 per cent in Armour Co., one of the nation's largest meat packers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The State Department said today that the United States would welcome any information on United States prisoners of war held by North Vietnam through whatever channel it might come.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Veterans Administration agreed today to release all data on the ratings it assigns to hearing aids.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The list of military base reductions announced today by Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird included the following for New York and New Jersey. None were announced for Connecticut.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The United States and Japan were reported today to be close to an agreement to return the strategic island of Okinawa to Japan in 1972.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 -- Auto shows have certain common denominators -- the miniskirted girls singsonging a sales pitch that no one can hear, visitors loading pounds of colorful brochures in advertising shopping bags provided by the exhibitors, display cars that come apart to show their innards and an incessant assault by the public-address system blaring everything from rock 'n' roll to "Ramona" and Herb Alpert.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--The House of Representatives approved overwhelmingly today a tough measure to protect coal miners by requiring mine owners to adopt safety practices many of which have been recommended for 100 years.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- President Joaquin Balaguer disclosed last night that he had ordered the Secretary of state for the Interior and Police to deny permission in the future to the Dominican Revolutionary party to hold open meetings.

YONKERS, Oct. 29 -- Louis Sauve, 35-year-old Frenchman, who will drive the Prex d' Amerique champion, Upsalin in the $50,000 Gotham Trot at Yonkers Raceway Friday night, made his American debut in the third race tonight and scored a victory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Federal Government is taking action to restrict the use of the weed killer 2,4,5-T as a result of laboratory tests that show it results in "a higher than expected number of deformities" in the offspring of mice and rats given relatively large oral doses of the chemical.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Federal Government invoked for the first time today its power to set water quality standards for a state and told Iowa to clean up the raw sewage that it pumps into the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers.

The office of Borough President has lost much of its former political power -- and glamour. No longer does the Borough President have administrative control over certain municipal services. The recent Charter change consolidated this function in the office of the Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers disputed Senator J. W. Fulbright today on his allegation that the State Department had not kept the Senate Foreign Relations Committee fully informed on American military operations in Laos.

The New York State Banking Board, acting on the recommendation of Superintendent of Banks Frank Wille, denied yesterday the application of Lincoln First Banks, Inc., a big upstate bank holding company, to acquire the First National Bank of Olean, N. Y.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 29 -- A two-year truce between the teamsters union and rebel steel haulers may be ending after a gun fight here yesterday that left one dead and five wounded.
A five-mile-stretch of Metropolitan Avenue in Queens, from Hillside Avenue in Kew Gardens to Flushing Avenue in Maspeth, will be joined today to the computerized traffic signal system.

A former city appraiser testified yesterday that the Federal Government had reneged on a promise not to indict him at the same time it indicted Roy M. Cohn, the lawyer, on bribery and conspiracy charges.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits rejected today suggestions that the withholding of food stamps be used as "a club" to force hungry strikers back to work or hungry students to cease rioting.

Interest rates, pushed upward by signs that the economy is not slowing down as much as expected, continued yesterday to move back toward the record levels reached at the end of September. The upward move, however, was less pronounced than earlier in the week. And prices of some bond issues, especially in the corporate sector of the capital markets, rebounded during the afternoon.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 29 -- Israel's right-wing Gahal party indicated today that it would seek to apply its gains in yesterday's general election toward a stronger position in the next Government headed by Premier Golda Meir.
CHARLES H. MELLON 3d stepped off the runway where, nodding and waving like British royalty, he had modeled a rust-colored cheviot country suit "with bi-swing shoulder pleats."
DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 29 -- This Arab capital, only 40 miles from the Israeli-held Golan heights, cuccumbed this week to what one Palestinian here termed "fedayeen fever."

Senator John J. Marchi's campaign manager accused Mayor Lindsay yesterday of spending more than $20,000 of city funds for stamps and stationery "to circulate a document outlining one of his campaign promises."

The design of a new domestic satellite system which for the first time makes no provision for the transmission of telephone calls was outlined yesterday by offficials of the Communications Satellite Corporation to the heads of the television networks.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 29 -- The Lebanese Army and the Palestinian guerrilla forces have agreed to a 24-hour cease-fire, which began at noon today. The object of the agreement appears to be to give the negotiations in Cairo a chance to make progress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Government reported today widespread increases this month in wholesale prices of industrial raw materials and manufactured goods, often a harbinger of further rising living costs.

PETER RAND'S "Firestorm" is an ambiguous picaresque. William Harrison's "In a Wild Sanctuary" is an encyclopedia of motives, flashbacks and desperate acts. Bailar, the 4-year-old campaigner owned by Stephen Clark, again demonstrated his liking for the grass by winning the feature race at Aqueduct yeesterday. Ron Turcotte, riding the gelding for the first time, had no trouble guiding him to a three-length triumph over Hand to Hand in the 1 1-16-mile event on the main turf course.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 -- In a tiny upstairs study crammed with books, a young Japanese editor offered tea to a visitor and talked of plans to make a worldwide best-seller out of a biography of Marshal Kim Il Sung, North Korea's ruler.

Major television equipment manufacturers in Japan, West Germany and the Netherlands announced yesterday plans to introduce video tape players for use in the home well in advance of units being developed in this country.

ROME, Oct. 29 -- The two-week meeting of the extraordinary Synod of Bishops that ended here yesterday took the first tentative practical steps toward converting the Roman Catholic church from an absolute monarchy to a constitutional one.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A brief statement of United States policy toward Lebanon, uttered at a private academic meeting here nearly three weeks ago and prominently published in Beirut, remains a point of controversy in the Lebane crisis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to reduce the taxes of single persons, regardless of age, so that none would have to pay more than 20 per cent more in Federal income taxes than a married couple with the same income. Single persons now can pay as much as 40 per cent more.

On the outside, the Hilton Hotel in Tarrytown, N. Y., looks like a very hospitable, modern, suburban high school. On the inside, the Hendrick Hudson Ballroom has been decorated to accommodate a banquet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended Roland F. Burns, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, from associating with any broker, dealer or investment adviser for 11 months.

LIMA, Peru, Oct., 29 -- The military government, which marked its first year with nationalizations, has entered its second year with negotiated efforts to attract foreign investment and perhaps encourage Peruvian capital.

Japanese arts -- both martial and cultural -- are on daily display at the Japan Exposition at the New York Coliseum through Sunday. Voters have an opportunity at this election to embody in the State Constitution a declaration of enlightened policy on conservation known as the Conservation Bill of Rights. It was originally offered by the Constitutional Convention of 1967 and is now presented as Amendment No. 3. It should be overwhelmingly approved.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- Buses and trucks will begin paying an average increase of 18.5 per cent in tolls on the New York State Thruway beginning Jan. 1.

THE Giants' persistence in trading future draft choices to fill immediate personnel needs continues to defy current practices in pro football. The Giants are the outstanding exception to the theory held by general managers and coaches that the way to build a winner is through extensive scouting and careful selection in the annual draft.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 29 -- United States and North Korean officers conferred secretly today at the armistice village of Panmunjom about the three crewmen of a United States Army helicopter shot down in North Korea Aug. 17.

Sales of chain stores and catalogue houses in September rose 10.2 per cent from the level of sales in September, 1968. Last month's gain was moderately above the 8.3 per cent increase registered in August.

Cardinal Cooke, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, announced yesterday that the Most Rev. Joseph F. Flannelly had retired as administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral and been replaced by Msgr. James F. Rigney.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Nixon was said today to have "reaffirmed" to labor leaders that it was in their best interest to be restrained in their demands for higher wages.
Hornblower Weeks-Hemphill, Noyes said yesterday that it had developed an automated system that almost eliminated errors in securities orders.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 29 -- Lending some of the luster of his office to the gubernatorial campaign of Representative William T. Cahill, President Nixon called tonight for a Republican victory before a cheering audience of nearly 4,000 jammed into the Hackensack High School gymnaisum.

PARKERSBURG, W. Va., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The assets of the Endicott-Johnson Corporation might actually be worth millions of dollars less than the value carried on the company's balance sheet, Donald E. Martin, president of the McDonough Company, said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 29 -- The Big Four powers will resume their talks here on the Middle East in the near future, perhaps next week, according to informed sources.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- When a simulated brick wall rose to 6 feet 11 inches in a puissance event at the Washington International Horse Show close to midnight tonight, all three horses that had survived into a third jumpoff failed to clear, but Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gill's Ile Dice became the winner.

SOCHI, U.S.S.R., Oct. 27 -- In a broad range of agreements, scientists from East and West, including some high in the Soviet hierarchy and former leaders of American defense research, have recommended measures to avert nuclear war.

ONLY the Disney organization could come up with a genteel, sweet-natured and appealingly frail little exercise like "Rascal," the story of a pre-adolescent boy and his pet raccoon in a small Wisconsin town about 50 years ago.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 29 -- The jury began its deliberations today in the trial of Julius F. Klein in the slaying of Irene Brandt, a part-time go-go dancer who was found dead in a sump in Suffolk County on Sept. 29, 1966.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Senate is almost certain to rebuff the Nixon Administration by postponing until next year consideration of reforms in the military draft, including the establishment of a lottery system for selecting draftees.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller wielded a gold-painted shovel today to break ground for the first construction project of the state's Urban Development Corporation.

THERE are butterflies floating and flowers growing on top of the gold jewelry countersatTiffany's this week. These diamond-paved, gem-encrusted pieces, along with a few dozen, others are being exhibited through Nov. 7 as the new crop from the store's gold jewelry department.

LUCILLE LORTEL'S admirable ANTA Matinee Series at the Theater de Lys is once more up, away and flying high. Tuesday afternoon is always a dull time, and I for one will always be grateful to Miss Lortel for filling a few of them during the year with a new play and some excellent players.

MADISON, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Robert B. Meyner, the Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, chose President Nixon's appearance in the state today as the occasion to attack Administration policy for what he called its "perversion of our national purpose."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29 -- The race for leadership of the Democratic party shapes up now as a tight three-way contest, with former Vice President Hubert H. PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 -- Hanging on desperately, hoping for a tie, the Penguins failed tonight to check the Rangers enough and did what they usually do to the New Yorkers -- lost.
Junior Coffey stood in front of his new locker yesterday, his bright blue slacks a good match for the Giants' bright blue jerseys.

Cassius Clay, better known as Muhammad Ali, began rehearsing yesterday for his Broadway debut in "Buck White," Oscar Brown's musical version of "Big Time Buck White," which opens on Dec. 2 at the George Abbott Theater.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- High Government officials said tonight that the Supreme Court's order tody on the desegregation of Mississippi schools could result in almost immediate integration of most of the schools in the South.

Ralph Kirkpatrick, harpsichordist, writing in the program notes to his Couperin recital at Alice Tully Hall last night, described his chosen composer as "deliberately modest and restrained, yet intense and concentrated."

Silver futures trading set a volume record yesterday with 9,252 contracts changing hands. Prices showed a sharp rise.
PARIS, Oct. 29 -- France announced today that the most powerful microscope in the world had gone into service and promised to open a new phase in the exploration of the "infinitely small."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to provide unemployment benefits to four million more nonagricutural workers and to charge employers higher taxes to foot the bill.

A MATCH beginning in Phoenix, Ariz., tonight will decide the American team for the 1970 world championship. The winners will be strong candidates to return the world title to the United States for the first time since 1954, because the invincible Italian Blue Team has retired.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Ernie was the only man in the neighborhood who had not put a decal of the American flag on his car window. The neighborhood was a little uneasy about that, so a committee was appointed to go around and talk to Ernie.

Declines outpaced advances on the American Stock Exchange yesterday by a wide margin as the list finished lower in moderate trading. At the final bell, the exchange's index of stock prices was down 22 cents at $28.18. Its low for the day was $28.02 and its high $28.55.

City Council President Francis X. Smith, Democratic candidate for election, proposing state legislation that would place domestic workers under the state minimum wage regulations (in a statement) -- Under the present law a domestic is not considered an employe under the minimum wage law.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- The manager of the American Express Company here said tonight that he had been ordered to leave the Soviet union "as soon as possible." He is Michael S. Jelisavcic, a United States citizen who was born in Yugoslavia and who has been in Moscow for nine years.
