Nassikas, new chairman of the Federal Power Commission, announced today the formation of five regional councils to improve the reliability of interconnected electric systems. The plan is designed to allow private utilities to build needed power plants with a minimum effect on their environment.

Black and white society, whose separate worlds rarely meet outside the gavel-like atmosphere of civic meetings and awards banquets, got a chance to look each other over on the more intimate terms of soft candlelight last night.

The general counsel for the National Council on Crime and Delinquency said yesterday that minimum recommended standards would prohibit keeping a prisoner in solitary confinement for more than 15 days.

The three Nobel Prize winners yesterday have a common way of viewing the world. Each has telescoped his intelligence in an effort to make order out of chaos and then to translate that order into pristine principles of scientific understanding.

Like the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911 in this city, the mine explosion that killed 78 men in Farmington, W. Va., a year ago will go down as a turning point in the nation's progress toward industrial safety. That place in history was assured with the passage by the House of Representatives this week of a mine health and safety bill even stronger than the far-reaching one already approved by the Senate.

The Federal Reserve has not altered significantly -- if at all -- its policy of severe monetary restraint, the weekly data from the central bank released yesterday disclosed. However, the principal indicators of credit availability presented a mixed picture. Some pointed to tighter conditions, while others might be interpreted as showing signs of ease.
The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the September quarter and the first nine months.

To make room for nine young prospects on their 40-man roster, the New York Yankees have assigned Bobby Cox and five other players to their Syracuse farm club in the International League. Cox had been a semi-regular third baseman for the Yankees for the past two seasons.

An experiment in which householders used paper or plastic containers instead of metal garbage cans has proved so successful that the city hopes the containers can be used throughout the five boroughs, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 30 -- A messenger boy employed by a dozen or so business concerns in Saigon left the following note at each this afternoon:

To Jay W. Forrester, whose specialty is grappling with complexity, the modern city is a diabolically complicated system that not only hides its real nature but even sets up decoys for those who want to learn how it functions.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- A frantic dive by Arnie Brown took him inches away from hitting Bob Clarke tonight, and Clarke got off his shot to score and lift the Flyers to a 3-3 tie with the Rangers.

The poetry of Hermann Hesse, the self-soaked Romantic and mystic whose visions have been rediscovered by America's collegians in recent years, helped illuminate last night's concert by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.
The stock market staged a brisk afternoon rally yesterday as glamour issues recouped substantial losses, and popular averages posted their first gain of the week.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The embattled Labor party hung on to four of five Parliamentary seats tonight in elections hailed by party leaders as a turn in their political fortunes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Ringmaster Challenge Trophy that had been in competition at the Washington International Horse Show since 1958 went into permanent keeping of the United States Equestrian Team tonight when 23-year-old Jared Brinsmade and Golden Gavel came through handsomely in the featured jumping competition. American horses also had won the prize last year (The Senator) and 1966 (Untouchable).
VIENNA, Oct. 30 -- The foreign ministers of the nations in the Warsaw Pact alliance held consultations on joint diplomatic strategy at Lany Castle near Prague today.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 30 -- The Kenyan Government today proscribed the country's only opposition party, the Kenya People's Union. The action comes three days after the opposition party leader, Oginga Odinga, and all seven opposition members of Parliament were arrested on charges that the party organized anti-Government demonstrations last Saturday in which 11 persons were killed.

A woman who called the police Wednesday night to say she had been mugged panicked a few moments later when two detectives knocked at her door. She rushed to the window, apparently to call for help, but lost her balance and fell through the window to her death.
BERLIN, Oct. 30--East Grmany protested today Chancellor Willy Brandt's plan to visit Berlin tomorrow, asserting he had no right to come to the city, which is 110 miles within the East German border.
IN the light of irrefutable, unemotional statistics undefeated Dartmouth should make Yale its sixth successive football victim tomorrow in the Bowl.
SOME time ago, a Manhattan woman wrote asking for the names and addresses of worthwhile organizations dedicated to the preservation of wildlife.

A strike by an Episcopal priest left 13 church owned apartment buildings without service yesterday as the clergyman's assistant and the buildings' maintenance men walked off their jobs in support of the priest's demand for higher wages as the manager of the apartments.

Dance is "the imminent creative art" in the nation, a panel of figures in the arts agreed Wednesday night. But the panel members differed on how this expanding activity should be related to the community.

Silver futures volume continued heavy yesterday, but well below the record level set on Wednesday -- 5,063 contracts compared with 9,252. Prices drifted lower by more than 2 cents an ounce for most contracts on no particular news.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Southern Regional Council strongly protested today a Senate committee action that, it said, would cut off all funds for the organization's voter registration activity.

A pall of absolute hopelessness hangs over the wage "negotiations" at the Metropolitan Opera. The season was supposed to have opened some seven weeks ago. The indications now are that it never will open.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- In a dispute that involved vital legal issues and had touches of comic opera, the House Commerce Committee voted today to cite Rosel H. Hyde, retiring chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, for contempt.

A well-rested Walt Frazier played the best basketball game of his life last night at Madison Square Garden and led the Knicks to a 123-110 victory over the San Diego Rockets. A crowd of 13,888 gave the talented guard a standing ovation when he left the court three minutes before the end of the game.
The state filed motions in two courts yesterday in an attempt to nullify a hearing this morning at which three Assemblymen will seek to have Governor Rockefeller cited for contempt of court.
BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 30 -- Scientists reported progress today in developing an experimental vaccine against bacteria meningitis, a serious and often fatal infectious disease.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- although gagged and strapped hand and foot to his chair, Bobby G. Seale still kept the trial of the Chicago eight in turmoil today.
State Senator John J. Marchi characterized himself yesterday as the only real alternative to Mayor Lindsay, contending that Mario A. Procaccino was no longer a creditable candidate for Mayor.

DETROIT, Oct 30 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Bucks outscored the Detroit Pistons, 20-0, over a 7 1/2-minute stretch in the second period tonight and went on to an easy 102-81 National Basketball Association victory.
Patrolman Earl Anderson, who is assigned to guard Morris High School, arrested a 17-year-old student there yesterdar for possession of a deck of heroin and a "dike," an altered eye dropper.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Scientists said today that a reinterpretation of the data collected from the Apollo lunar landing showed that geologically the moon is more dead than alive.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- The United States proposed today that delegates to the peace conference here meet in a closed session on Tuesday to escape the present "sterile" confrontation and begin "serious negotiations." North Vietnam and the Vietcong rejected the proposal.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The killing of hundreds of animals and birds -- including foxes, badgers, squirrels and small rodents and owls, magpies, jays and crows -- started today in Surrey on orders from the Ministry of Agriculture to prevent an infestation of rabies.

PARIS -- Slowly and perhaps not consciously the two halves of partitioned Germany seem to be moving toward the kind of loose confederation created by Metternich for the hodgepodge of German states after the Napoleonic Wars.
The city's first low-income, community-sponsored furniture cooperative left its old quarters in a barn-like, onetime sausage factory yesterday to compete on Third Avenue's "Furniture Row."

IT wasn't William Service's fault that Owl died. The Services took him in because he'd been abandoned as a fledgling. And they were gracious hosts: They gave him the flight and hop and pounce of their roomy Connecticut home, as well as a Maxwell House coffee tin to retire into when the children and pets got too much for him.
McDonnell Co., the financially troubled brokerage firm, disclosed yesterday that it was virtually withdrawing from the retail stock brokerage business.

President Thieu's decision to release 310 political prisoners in honor of South Vietnam's National Day tomorrow, will give a modest boost to President Nixon's scheduled effort Monday to rally the nation behind his Vietnam policy. Political repression in Saigon has been a major source of embarrassment to the President of the United States because it so blatantly conflicts with his pronounced goal of free choice for the South Vietnamese people.
When Fred Dryer was growing up in southern California, his teachers used to tell him all about geography and climate and cold weather.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The Senate Commerce Committee decided tentatively today to outlaw television and radio cigarette commercials.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30 -- The United States and Mexico agreed today to form a joint working group that will seek "to identify possible bases" for a more effective cooperative drive against traffic in dangerous drugs across the Mexican border.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 30 -- Two 13-year-old girls on their way to school were killed at 7:35 A.M. today by a Penn Central commuter train just east of the Rowayton Railroad Station.
David Nadien, concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic, appeared as soloist with the orchestra at Philharmonic Hall last night, playing Beethoven's Violin Concerto.
Paramount Pictures will make another effort to change the classification of its $20-million musical, "Paint Your Wagon," from "M" to "G."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Federal judge in New York approved today a permanent injunction against the Parvin-Dohrmann Company, its president and its chairman forbidding them to violate antifraud provisions of the securities laws.

American apparel manufacturers must be prepared to establish production facilities overseas, if necessary, go compete with imported products, according to John W. Field, president of Warnaco, Inc., a leading domestic manufacturer and fledgling retailer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Senate Finance Committee agreed today to give some tax relief to every income group by means of a low-income allowance for the poor, an increase in the standard deduction and cuts in the tax rates.

The seasonally adjusted Dodge index of construction-contract value dropped to 173 in September, its lowest point of the year, the F. W. Dodge Company, construction research division of the McGraw Hill Company, reported yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Vice President Agnew raised the possibility tonight of official repression as the result of antiwar protests he said have been exploited by politicians and perverted by subversives into "something sick and rancid."

The Cartier diamond, 1 1/2 inches long, an inch wide and nearly an inch thick, has been drawing crowds of over 6,000 a day to the Cartier store at 52d Street and Fifth Avenue since it was put on display there last Saturday.
Eli Timoner, chairman of Giffen Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that litigation between Giffen and holders of a large block of stock of Keller Industries, Inc., had been settled.
Two men were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of attempting to extort $250,000 from the Chase Manhattan Bank as ransom for $1.6-million in stolen securities.

" GLORY! HALLELUJAH!," which National Educational Television is presenting tonight at 8:30 on Channel 13, is an often compelling, sometimes brilliant antiwar drama that ultimately fails because it is unsuccessful in transmuting propaganda into dramatic passion.

NEITHER of the items in the new double bill of the New York City Opera, unveiled last night at the State Theater, can be called new. Ravel's one-act "L'Heure Espagnole" was restored to the repertory after a 17-year absence, and Carl Orff's "Songs of Catullus" had its premiere at the Caramoor Festival in 1964.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- President Nixon asked Congress today for a variety of weapons to protect consumers against deceptive sales practices and shoddy products.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Oct. 30 -- An attempt here by 44 airlines to agree on a new set of North Atlantic passenger fares that would fill the jumbo jets has failed, airline officials said tonight.
Mrs. Robert. F. Kennedy came to a renovated slum in Brooklyn yesterday to watch its residents take a step toward the fulfillment of one of her husband's goals.

Aides of Mario A. Procaccino spent 90 minutes at The Daily News yesterday reviewing the methods used in the newspaper's straw polls, which have shown the Democratic and Non-Partisan candidate trailing Mayor Lindsay by a wide margin.
The other day Jack Ryan spent his first day behind a Trans World Airlines ticket counter checking in passengers at Kennedy International Airport.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 30 -- The Lebanese Government and the guerrilla chief, Yasir Arafat, today accused each other of aggression.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The State Department revealed today that the United States had asked the Soviet Union to use its influence with North Vietnam to ease the tense situation in Laos.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The ballet of the Teatro San Martin. Buenos Aires, gave Londoners a pleasant surprise tonight when it opened a week's season at the Place, a new theater specializing in modern music and dance. Formed only 19 months ago, and unheard of in Europe until the current tour, the company of 26 dancers proves to be a resiliently homogeneous team, intense but not solemn, disciplined without loss of individuality.
The Episcopal Diocese of New York released yesterday the names of four candidates to succeed the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan as Bishop of New York.

CARRYING two bags of groceries from the supermarket, Jack Greenberg, the civil rights lawyer, quickened his pace Wednesday evening as he strode toward the door of his new apartment at 146 East 54th Street. Inside, the phone was ringing.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 30 -- Both Nigeria and Biafra have agreed in principle to unconditional negotiations to end the Nigerian civil war, an African diplomat said yesterday.
" Stomp" is living-in at Joseph Papp's Public Theater.

The threat of overpopulation in this country by the end of the century is so strong, an informal education progarm should be started to urge American families to have fewer children, Dr. Roger O. Egeberg, Assistant Secretary for Health and Scientific Affairs, said yesterday.
The Lindsay campaign is built around a selling point unique in American politics. In effect the Mayor is saying, "I made mistakes but forgive me, I will do better next time."

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Mrs. William R. Loweth of Wykagyl was elected president of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association today at the annual meeting at The Apawamis Club. She succeeded Mrs. William M. Tingue of New Canaan, who retired after serving three terms.

An ancient atlas, assembled from 81 maps that were published separately in Venice between 1553 and 1570, won the high price of $42,000 in an auction of Americana that ended Wedesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 30 -- Denis Michael Rohan, the Australian farm worker who has admitted that he set fire to Al Aksa Mosque Aug. 21, took the stand today in his own defense as his trial resumed after a 17-day recess. He testified that he had been chosen by God to become King of Jerusalem and Judea.
Don Maynard is receiving double coverage and George Sauer is receiving double coverage, but that doesn't automatically mean that somebody else on the Jets is open for the long pass, either.
Negotiations were at a halt yesterday in the nationwide strike of 13 unions against the General Electric Company.
Penny Pitou, the effervescent blonde who won two silver medals for the United States at the 1960 Winter Olympics at Squaw Valley, Calif., is making a comeback. But she isn't doing it as a racer.
SYOSSET, L. I., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Ron Swoboda is still making the big hit.

Rabbi Herbert Weiner's subjective exploration into contemporary Jewish mysticism turns into a survey of the field and an investigation of its strength and weaknesses. He sought out and, in some cases, studied with a wide range of mystics: scholars and historians of the movement, translators and transmitters of the texts, embodiments of the mystical ideal.

In a resumption of last week's board meeting of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc. -- the first since Las Vegas millionaire Kirk Kerkorian assumed control of the giant movie maker -- the slate of directors proposed for the forthcoming annual meeting was reduced to 11 from 19.
Mayor Lindsay has received all of the city's television and radio endorsements -- but not without a minor protest before the Federal Communications Commission.
BOSTON, Oct. 30 -- The Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts granted Senator Edward M. Kennedy today the right to a closed inquest in the death last July 18 of Mary Jo Kopechne.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 30 -- A 40 - year - old American was awarded the 1969 Nobel Prize for Physics today for his discoveries, first published when he was 24, concerning subatomic particles, the basic units of energy.

Jean and Kenneth Wentworth present music written for two people playing at one piano. Since the worthwhile literature in this form is relatively small they have asked several contemporary composers to supply them with material.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are listed on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -The television manufacturing industry, prodded by the National Product Safety Commission, agreed today to develop strong new fire-prevention standards for television sets.
DETROIT, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Despite a strike at American Motors Corporation, auto production in the nation increased slightly this week, compared with the week before.

Frito-Lay, Inc., has agreed to sell nine of its potato-chip plants to Nefco, of Little Rock, Ark., for about $10-million, it was announced yesterday by Harold R. Lilley, Frito-Lay president and chief executive officer. The sale is in compliance with an agreement consent order reached with the Federal Trade Commission in July of 1968 and is subject to F.T.C. approval.

The Travelers Corporation reported yesterday improvements in earnings and premium and investment income and a reduction in its statutory underwriting losses for its casualty-property insurance lines over the first nine months of 1969.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino held a news conference yesterday to accuse New York's daily newspapers of damaging his mayoral campaign by biased or mistaken reporting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A citizens' committee on Vietnam policy said in a policy statement it sent to President Nixon this week and made public today that abrupt or pre mature withdrawal of troops could have disastrous consequences for world peace and domestic tranquility.
SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The University of Washington football team flew to Los Angeles today without its 13 black members.

The E. F. MacDonald Company, better known to the public as the Plaid Stamp entrepreneur, reported yesterday that it was negotiating with the holders of its 6 3/4 per cent promissory notes for the required waivers on dividend restrictions that would enable the company to pay its regular quarterly dividend for the fourth quarter of the fiscal year ending next Jan. 31.
THURMONT, Md., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Fog kept President Nixon from landing at Camp David tonight and his helicopter landed instead on a school grounds at Thurmont.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The White House turned into the Great Pumpkin today, and why not?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- A Cabinet-level study group reported to President Nixon early this year that the supersonic transport plane, which he approved last month, would be a dangerous, noisy "white elephant," it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Oil companies planning an 800-mile trans-Alaska pipeline have agreed to stringent conditions for the protection of fish and wildlife, Congress was told today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Pentagon today identified 19 servicemen as having been killed in Vietnam. They included Pfc. John K. Goett of Monroe, Conn., of the Army.
LARAMIE, Wyo. -- The crisis in black and white has made a gentle entry into the affairs of the startled University of Wyoming.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -Four conservation groups petitioned the Department of Agriculture today to ban the use of DDT on the ground that it is hazardous to human beings and wildlife.

" Well, they talk about hijacking," Donald J. Cook Sr. said of pilots. "I think all of them are of one mind: they just go along with it, because if the gun goes off in the plane it can ruin the pressurization, if nothing else."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -Youthful Elizabeth Ashton, the only woman involved in the international jumping at the Washington International Horse Show, hustled a horse named Darwen over the course with a fine burst of speed tonight and scored for Canada.
Richie Havens, who has become one of the most important figures in folk music, performed at Philharmonic Hall last night.
MADRID, Oct. 31 -- "We are now in the post-Franco period," was the way one Spanish publisher put it.
The State Department of Motor Vehicles had a word of reassurance yesterday for drivers whose operator's license is about to expire but who have not yet received punch cards for renewal.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- The average rate of discount at today's auction of British Treasury 91-day bills fell to 7.743 per cent from 7.763 per cent last week. This week's u100-million offers met applications of u204,115,000.
For the third time in two months, the price of coffee is heading upward.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Benjamin R. McElveen, 36 years old, a reporter of less than two weeks for The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, was arrested in Wednesday's robberyslaying of a bank guard in northeast Philadelphia, the police announced today. Still being sought is Wesley Leon Harper, 24, of Baltimore.
HONOLULU, Oct. 31 -- An offbeat industry for which the University of Hawaii is preparing to share in the research is making a modest start in the 50th state.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -Clutch shooting by Tom Sanders offset a second-half rally sparked by Don Kojis of San Diego and helped the Boston Celtics to a 118-113 victory over the Rockets tonight at the Boston Garden.
A future Queen rapid transit line has been added to the long-negotiated plan to construct a high-speed rail line linking midtown and Kennedy International Airport.

MANILA, Oct. 31 (UPI) -Charles A. Lindbergh said through a spokesman today that he was amused at reports that his plane crashed yesterday in a remote section of the Philippines. Mr. Lindbergh said his small plane had made only an emergency landing in a rice paddy as a precaution against bad weather.
VIENNA, Oct. 31 -- The Foreign Ministers of the Warsaw Pact alliance declared in a joint statement in Prague today that an all-European conference could be held in Helsinki in the first half of 1970.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission granted permission for the Pacifica Foundation today to operate a new FM radio station in Houston despite continued complaints about the use of obscene language on its station in Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York.
Van Sahakian has been appointed vice president and chief financial officer of the Consolidated National Shoe Corporation.
Columbia University has raised over $140-million in its three-year fund drive, it was announced last night by Andrew W. Cordier, president of the university.

CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Parochial and private education may be supported by public tax money if enough constitutional safeguards are provided, the New Hampshire Supreme Court said today in an advisory opinion.
CONROE, Tex., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Sandra Palmer of Fort Worth took a three-stroke lead today in the $17,500 second annual River Plantation women's open golf tourney.

Philip J. Zichello, who failed to win the approval of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York as a candidate for a Civil Court judgeship, said yesterday that three legal associations had found him qualified.
For a while there, it looked as if New York wasn't going to have a spectacular charity ball all season, and then along came Halloween with trick or treat for the kiddies and the April in Paris Ball.
Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., once the corporate vehicle of Roy M. Cohn, Victor Muscat and their associates, may be returned to public control as a result of a court petition.

The Technicon Corporation, a privately held company engaged in design, production and sale of automated chemical analytical systems, filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of one million shares.

ONEIDA, N. Y., Oct. 31 -Someone in this upstate city of 11,000 last night gave three children Halloween trick-ortreat apples with sewing needles in them and a quantity of candied popcorn balls containing camphor.

Two Manhattan Republican district leaders obtained a court order yesterday directing the county chairman, Vincent F. Albano Jr., to show cause why he should not be held in contempt of court for displaying signs implying Mayor Lindsay was a Republican candidate. A hearing was set for Monday morning.
The Consolidated Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a decline in net income for the first nine months of this year despite a 5.9 per cent increase in operating revenues.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 31 -- Guerrillas at the headquarters of Al Fatah and As Saiqa here denounced Lebanese peace feelers today and said the guerrilla forces' show of strength in Lebanon had led King Hussein of Jordan to call off moves to halt commando activities along Israel's long and vulnerable Jordanian front.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 31 -- Connecticut state authorities have shown "a good deal of interest" in the idea of helping the New Haven Division of the Penn Central renovate some of its self-propelled diesel passenger cars for better service in the state, a railroad spokesman said today.

Several Brooklyn Democratic leaders, taken aback by the Brooklyn Democratic organization's decision not to pay its precinct captains for the first mayoral campaign within memory, said yesterday that they would pick up the bill for their own districts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -Representative Wilbur D. Mills conveyed indirectly to a high-level Japanese parliamentary delegation today the warning that Congress could well begin action in January on legislation restricting textile imports unless a voluntary agreement were reached before then.

Mayor Lindsay urged voters yesterday to approve all four proposed amendments to the State Constitution in Tuesday's election.
The rate of expansion in consumer credit--a key leading indicator of business activity-increased during September, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday in Washington.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 31 -- Stock market prices in South Africa have slumped by $12.18-billion since May and the collapse has now become an issue in the campaign for the general election next April.
A new network of 113 automobile dealerships throughout the country will open for business today to specialize in the sale of German - built Porsche and Audi cars.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Oct. 31 -- This New Jersey coastal town was forced today to cancel its annual Halloween Mardi Gras for the first time in 27 years following an outbreak last night of attacks by juveniles on policemen.

ATHENS, Oct. 31 -- A special military tribunal tonight sentenced eight opponents of Greece's army-backed Government to prison terms ranging from 6 to 25 years in jail. They were charged with having placed 17 time-bombs in the Athens area. Two other defendants were acquitted.
Owners of American tramp ships were considering some concerted action yesterday to protest the interim use of the icebreaking tanker Manhattan as a grain carrier.
Labor contract talks between the New York City Ballet and its orchestra remained stalled after the two sides met yesterday.

WASHINGTON Oct 31 -Governor Rockefeller, praising President Nixon's welfare plan as "a workable first step," urged Congress today to strengthen "significantly" the proposal to aid the hardpressed urban states.

Programs that contrast musical periods and unusual instrumental vocal combinations -such is the avowed aim of Lincoln Center's new Chamber Music Society. While efforts to resolve the Middle East crisis were pressed in Cairo and Washington, Arab guerrillas asserted yesterday that they had repulsed a major threat by the Lebanese Army in eastern Lebanon.

The Alleghany Corporation, the large holding company, had net assets of $15.78 a common share as of Sept. 30 compared with $19.93 a share at the same date last year. WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Despite an intensive political campaign, President Nixon appears to be losing his fight to place Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. on the Supreme Court.

PORT READING, N. J., Oct. 31 -- The rupture of an eight million-gallon storage tank here yesterday afternoon sent an undetermined amount of crude oil spilling into Arthur Kill, the channel that separates Staten Island from New Jersey, and spread a slick south as far as Raritan Bay.

The retirement of Grant Keehn as vice chairman of the board of the Equitable Life Assurance Society was announced yesterday. Mr. Keehn will continue as a director and as chairman of the board's finance and real-estate committees. He will serve as consultant to Equitable on financial and investment matters. Thomas F. Murray, vice president-investments, has assumed direct responsibility for investment and banking operations.

SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Marijuna, LSD and hashish seized from Dr. Timothy Leary and his family may be used as evidence at their trial, a judge ruled today.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest retailing organization, announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire a majority interest in the Computer Usage Company, which provides analysis and programming services for computer users.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 31 -- Palestinian guerrillas said today that they repulsed a Lebanese Army attack on Kfar Kouk in a five-and-a-half-hour battle that began at 2:30 A.M. They claimed a major victory.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Small clouds of radiation escaped from an underground nuclear explosion near Las Vegas Wednesday and drifted across a major highway, the Atomic Energy Commission has disclosed. Three clouds of gaseous radioactivity passed over U.S. 95, near Lathrop Wells and Mercury. The Atomic Energy Commission said the clouds posed no health hazard.

Miss Heldman will meet Virginia Wade of Britain in the final tomorrow. Miss Wade won, 6-3, 7-5, from Annette du Plooy of South Africa.

Now he invokes the shades of Upton Sinclair and Rachel Carson to stress his identification with the concept that "consumerism" is here to stay.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- President Chiang Kaishek went into seclusion today as his countrymen celebrated his 82d birthday with colorful parades, parties, Chinese operas and fireworks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Apparently bitter and unsure of his future, the former Green Beret commander in Vietnam who was once charged in the bizarre murder of a South Vietnamese retired from the Army today after 23 years of service.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- Precautions were taken by international authorities today to help prevent American gold reserves from plummeting next year when Western countries deposit fresh quantities of gold with the International Monetary Fund.

TOMORROW morning at Christmas, Florida, the United States will release its 1969 Christmas stamp bearing a miniaturization of "Winter Sunday in Norway, Maine," an oil painting from about 1870 by an unknown artist. The 6c stamp will be multicolored and depicts a typical New England winter morning with people on their way to a church which forms part of the background.

IF there is any shortage of airplane seats to Caribbean, European or Far Eastern points this winter, one can hardly say that the airlines did not give it the full try. There will be a total of 2,177 flights each week, and collectively they will provide a total of 307,870 seats.

MOBILE, Ala. -- Mobile has never been renowned for pressing its historic charms energetically, but the restoration of several blocks of old buildings and the establishment of historic tours have helped generate a new spirit. Alabama's sesquicentennial celebration of statehood this year has encouraged the city to think more of its assets, which include tangible marks of early Spanish and French occupancy as well as many fine antebellum homes.

ITEMS of political Americana such as posters, tokens, buttons and pictures of candidates for office -- whether they be winners or losers -- have always had great appeal for many collectors, and their popularity seems to be increasing.

After viewing such a kaleidoscopic diatribe of unmitigated cinematic junk as "Alice's Restaurant," I am amazed that this type of movie is even allowed to be shown to the public.

An illuminatus, an old fight manager or baseball scout, can still find it expressed in the technique itself: in minute variations of stance or swing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Nathan M. Voloshen's alleged web of influence peddling activities, already under scrutiny by two Federal grand juries, extended to the national banking field, according to a confidential investigative statement.

Predominant were the bright jingle of "sleigh" bells on the harnesses of ponies pulling two-wheeled "taxis," the clop-clop of hoofs on the pavement and the barking of innumerable dogs.

MEXICO CITY -- A visitor to Mexico City who enjoys hiking, but for one reason or another is not up to tackling one of the nearby snowcapped volcanoes, need not be idle. There are at least a hundred possibilities for hikes and walks tailored to every taste and requiring no equipment more complicated than a sturdy and comfortable pair of shoes.

SYDNEY -- Vietnam and the related Australian involvement in Southeast Asia were an important issue in the election last weekend that saw the conservative Government of Prime Minister John Grey Gorton retain power by a narrow margin over the opposition Labor party.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence today urged drastic and far-reaching revision in the American machinery of justice, which it said was fragmented, inadequate and archaic.

Gary Callahan scored 26 points as unbeaten and untied Far Rockaway buried Flushing, 43-0, yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League Division I game on the winners' field. NEWARK, Nov. 1 -- A lack of enthusiasm for the pace, content and leading figures in the campaign for Governor between Robert B. Meyner, the Democrat, and Representative William T. Cahill, the Republican, appears commonplace among New Jersey voters as the race nears an end.

An item on the first page of The Times of Oct. 26 tells of the large tax savings available to doctors and other professional practitioners through the incorporation of their practices. This in turn leads to greatly increased pensions upon retirement.

MAKATI, the Philippines -- Any old Philippine hand who has been away for at least 12 years is in for an exhilarating surprise on returning to Manila. Southeast of the city, on reclaimed swampland near dusty, desolate Highway 54 -- an area where cogan grass grew 10 feet high undisturbed and the Nichols Field landing strip was the only sight for miles -- a sparkling, landscaped, streamlined skyscraper city has sprouted.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- In the late nineteen-twenties, King Amanullah of Afghanistan returned from a tour of Europe fired with the desire to modernize his backward Central Asian nation. JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Twenty-three Port Gibson, Miss., businessmen have filed a $3 1/2-million damage suit against the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and numerous individuals because of an economic boycott in force against white merchants for 2 1/2 years.

ROME, Nov. 2 -- Italian justice took the first steps today toward a trial and punishment in Italy of Raffaele Minichiello, the Los Angeles-to-Rome aircraft hijacker, possibly blocking indefinitely his extradition to the United States.

The captain of the airliner hijacked from California to Rome was accused yesterday of having acted "irresponsibly" in criticizing an attempt by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to stop the plane here and in portraying himself as "the sole hero of the escapade."
Henry W. Proffitt, counsel for Columbia University and a specialist in banking and real estate law, died Saturday in the Presbyterian Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 142 East 71st Street.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 2 -- A ball is a ball is a ball. There is only so much you can do to make one interesting. That is, unless you go along with the recent thinking that the only way to draw potential ballgoers away from their television sets is to hold the soiree in some out-of-the-ordinary place.

Probably few musicians or regular music followers here had heard of the Prague Symphony and Vaclav Smetacek, its conductor, before the orchestra's American tour began recently. For most of us, the Czech Philharmonic and its conductor, Karel Ancerl, have been the familiar names in the Czechoslovak symphonic world up to now.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Tax Reform Act of 1969 is a product of the most intense public resentment against tax abuses that this country has known for many years. Somehow, in the last year, the fact that some rich people escape paying their fair share, or paying anything at all, got through to the public consciousness and evoked an irresistible demand for reform.
VIENNA, Nov. 2 -- The newspaper of the Rumanian Communist party advocated today "the withdrawal of foreign troops and the elimination of military bases on the territory of other states" in Europe.

The initiative for the return of the six hijackers from Cuba came from the men themselves, and in no way resulted from negotiations involving the United States Government, State Department officials said yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 2 -- Travelers reported seeing dozens of Syrian Army vehicles streaming northward and westward today along Syrian highways toward the Lebanese border.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Christian Bonington, the British mountaineer, announced here today that next spring he would attempt to climb the south face of Annapurna, perhaps the world's most formidable mountain wall.

" Hair" is still growing healthily, as evidenced by an open-call audition that drew over 250 aspiring young performers on Saturday and will continue today at Theater 80, St. Mark's Place. The selected hopefuls will join companies of the tribal rock musical in Toronto, Boston, Chicago and on the West Coast.

KFAR KOUK, Lebanon, Nov. 2 -- A Sunday calm that at least lightly blanketed the rest of troubled Lebanon stretched even into this pocket of tension along the country's hilly, southeastern border with Syria.

If his recital yesterday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall was not merely one of those freakishly great days that good pianists sometimes enjoy, Seymour Bernstein is ready to break out into a wider circle of attention.

With marginal exceptions, the Senate Finance Committee's decisions on tax treatment for foundations betray the same punitive spirit that dominated and disfigured these provisions of the House-approved tax reform bill. Those who know and admire the major philanthropic contributions made by the great foundations and many of their smaller counterparts can only be appalled at the suspicion and hatred of these agencies implicit in the decisions on Capitol Hill.
The Columbia Broadcasting System is expected to announce this week several major program changes, including the cancellation of "The Leslie Uggams Show."
As the weather begins to turn cold it is natural for one's thoughts to turn to sunny Shrike Island, the beach at its Loggerhead Bight and the gang at the bar at the Piranha Club.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The gag and shackles that bound Bobby G. Seale for three days during his trial here were removed today without explanation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The United States would support a system of general tariff preferences for all developing countries at a Nov. 15 meeting of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, but there would be some exceptions.
OTTAWA, Nov. 3 -- Canada announced measures today to reduce the use of the pesticide DDT by 90 per cent next year.

At least 15,000 BMT and IND subway riders were delayed up to 75 minutes at the height of the rush hour last night. A fire and mechanical trouble affected trains carrying passengers from Manhattan to Brooklyn and Queens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Clarke L. Fauver, director of operations of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, was shot to death today in his ninth-floor office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The proposal to substitute direct popular election for Electorial College choice of the President appears to be Stalled in the Senate Judiciary Committee until at least early 1970.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- It was 1:20 in the morning and Miss Rose Mary Woods, President Nixon's personal secretary, was preparing to leave the White House for her apartment in the nearby Watergate Hotel. The door opened to admit Manolo Sanchez, Mr. Nixon's valet.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Nov. 3 (Reuters) -- More than 70 black immigrants from the United States who came here two years ago saying "we never had real freedom in America" have been given seven days to leave Liberia as undesirable aliens.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon canceled a planned four - day cross-country tour of college students' volunteer projects today only five hours after the trip had been announced by the White House.
THE legal system is black-robed judges and solemn-faced jurors, busy lawyers and confused defendants. It is crowded courtrooms and somber law offices, century-old precedents and new statutes.

Navy rescue vessels with deep-sea divers aboard churned toward the last reported position of a missing tugboat off the Carolinas early today on the possibility that the tug might be on the bottom of the Atlantic with its six crewmen still alive inside.
Trading declined and prices eased yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Nov 3 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra's opening concert in a heavily subscribed season in Constitution Hall here was called off tonight. Eugene Ormandy was to have conducted.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 3 -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology obtained a court order today banning members of the November Action Coalition from violence or the threat of violence during planned demonstrations tomorrow against defense research at the institute.

IN THIS town, the capital of the wrecking ball, it is like pouring water on a parched throat to rediscover a small and going concern that has resisted change for more than 70 years. But M. Rohrs, whose specialty is coffee beans and plain and fancy teas, is just such an establishment.

WEEKLY rankings of college football teams can lead to a situation "inconsistent with good sportsmanship," according to Joe Paterno of Penn State. The Nittany Lions' head coach has never liked the system of weekly voting for the top 10 teams in the nation and he once again made his point during a visit to the New York football writers' luncheon at the New York University Club yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Four drugs ruled ineffective or unsafe by a Government panel are still being stocked in some Federal hospitals, a Senate subcommittee was told today.

BUPRANG, South Vietnam, Nov. 3 (AP) -- When the order came to abandon the allied fire base known as Kate, the handful of American artillerymen raced from their bunkers, clawed through their own barbed wire and ran down the steep slopes.
President Nixon's speech was met with skepticism, disbelief and sarcasm in one Columbia University dormitory las night.
The Union Pacific Railroad's land division announced yesterday a $98-million real estate development program.

TRENTON, Nov. 3 -- New Jersey's election for Governor, a bitter campaign that was dominated by repeated conflict - of - interest charges, concluded tonight in more controversy as a result of former Gov. Robert B. Meyner's charges of religious bigotry.
Swift Co., the big meat packer, announced yesterday it was acquiring for an undisclosed amount of cash a major portion of the assets of the farm fertilizer business of the Mobil Chemical Company.
The credit markets bet yesterday that President Nixon's address last night would push bond prices higher and interest rates lower, but the wagers weren't heavy.
FRED W. LANGE has been around Wall Street for a long time as a director of research, but he's just gotten into the business of managing mutual funds. He seems to be doing rather well at it.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 3 -- Willis Reed and the New York Knickerbockers took a giant step forward tonight in their quest for the Eastern Division championship of the National Basketball Association.
Thee National Horse Show begins its annual eight-day run in Madison Square Garden today with Bill Steinkraus rejoining the United States Equestrian Team.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Productivity, or output per manhour, rose slightly in the United States economy in the third quarter but remained below the peak reached in the last quarter of 1968, the Labor Department reported today.
STAND aside, Pocahontas, and put away your disintegrator gun, Wilma Deering. A new girl has come to town and she doesn't dress as if she just left the tepee or is off for a joust with Martians.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The Defense Department took another tentative step today toward development of a new strategic bomber, without actually committing the Administration to production of a fleet of planes to succeed the aging B-52.

YONKERS, Nov. 3 -- A pacer has no place in the scheme of harness racing in the Soviet Union (or in most of Europe) where the trotter reigns supreme among standardbreds. On the rare occasion when a pacer has bobbed up it has had to compete against trotters.

The recommendations of The Times to the voters of New York City, Westchester and New Jersey concerning candidates and issues in today's election are recapitulated below. Candidates whose names are followed by an asterisk are incumbents.

ANDAKET, Lebanon, Nov. 3 -- Lebanese authority ends at a crude roadblock of jumbled stones outside this Christian hill village six miles south of the tense Syrian border.

An oil exploration venture in Indonesia has been announced by Gulf Western Industries, Inc., whose previous diversification moves have taken it into such varied businesses as motion pictures, insurance, cigars, metal products and paper.
New York City's population has resumed a downward trend again after reaching a peak of 8,019,100 as of July 1, 1966, estimates obtained from the United States Census Bureau indicated yesterday.

Another chapter was inscribed yesterday in the stormy saga involving London's Pergamon Press and New York's Leasco Data Processing Equipment Corporation, when Leasco sued Pergamon's former chairman for $22-million.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark urged Congress today to repeal Selective Service rules calling for swift induction of antiwar protesters and those who violate Selective Service orders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Treasury bill rates moved in opposite directions at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor of The New York Times, announced additional responsibilities yesterday for Lewis Jordan, news editor, and the promotion of Lawrence G. Hauck to associate news editor.

To thousands of college students of American history since 1930, an assignment to "read about it in Morison and Commager" has been handily translated into "read 'The Growth of the American Republic:'" But now for the sixth edition of that classic, professors are adding a third time -- Leuchtenburg.
Union repairmen for the New York Telephone Company walked off the job here last night, on the eve of Election Day, charging the company with "locking out" union members in an overtime dispute.
Exactly 10 years after he had made his debut here as a winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation award, Howard Aibel returned for his second New York recital -- last night in Carnegie Hall.

The complicated domestic legal procedures to extradite the young hijacker of a Trans World Airlines jetliner from Italy began yesterday despite the possibility that the extradition may not take place for as long as 30 years.

They make a perfect duo, one would think, for aficionados, Carr to rack your brain, MacLean to chill your spine. Alas, only MacLean lives up to his billing, but he does so in spades. "Puppet on a Chain" is one of the best in the Greene-Ambler-MacIness tradition that this operative has come across.

John Lill, a 25-year-old pianist from Great Britain, played last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. His concert was the first in an International Artist Series sponsored by a grant from the Steinway Foundation and a contribution from the Carnegie Hall Club.

ATHENS, Nov. 3 -- Greece's military backed regime announced tonight that in an effort to stop allegations of police torture of Greek political prisoners, it would give the International Red Cross free access to all Greek jails.

Your Nov. 1 editorial showed little understanding about what has been happening in Westchester during the past twelve years. Edwin G. Michaelian has served as County Executive for three terms and has provided, as you admit, thoroughly honest government.

Tommie Agee, one of the half-dozen indispensables of New York Met success, has agreed to terms for next season, the club announced yesterday. His salary, which was not announced, will be in the $35,000-$40,000 range.
SAIGON South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 4 -- Enemy troops staged three ground attacks early today, killing at least three Americans and wounding 43 others.

President Nixon disappointed the nation's hope for a reordering of American priorities with a "plan for peace" that looks more like a formula for continued war. He proposed no new American initiative at Paris or in South Vietnam, preferring instead to reiterate the American position in terms reminiscent of those used by President Johnson and Secretary Rusk.

PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Robert Lee Sandlin, one of the six accused aircraft pirates who returned to the United States yesterday, told a lawyer today that he had been in detention ever since he arrived in Havana last March.

In record trading of more than 2,700 contracts, platinum prices rose yesterday as much as $4.50 an ounce. On Friday, prices were about $10 an ounce. The reason for yesterday's gain was an increase of $10 an ounce in platinum prices by the major refiners.

NAPA, Calif., Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Jack Nicklaus rolled in a 12-foot birdie putt in a dramatic playoff today with Billy Casper and George Archer and won the $140,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament. The first prize of $28,000 moved him into second place on the career money winning list with a total of $978,974.
Joe Namath's passing arm is sore.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- In an addendum to President Nixon's speech tonight, the White House press office made public the text of the exchange of letters between Mr. Nixon and Ho Chi Minh, the late President of North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Creation of a national development bank able to make direct loans of nearly $20-billion at interest rates no higher than 6 per cent was proposed today by Chairman Wright Patman of the House Banking Committee.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 3 -- The losses suffered by Premier Golda Meir's ruling alignment in last week's general election appeared tonight to have been greater than at first realized.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 3 -- Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, the pioneer in heart transplant surgery, has fallen out of favor with many South Africans because of his calls for greater racial tolerance.

Despite wide price swings in some glamour issues, the stock market reflected a generally cautious tone yesterday as the investment community awaited President Nixon's address to the nation last night. The Dow-Jones industrial average dipped 1.45 points to 854.54.

Cabaret theater, in two completely different modes, is thriving at two clubs in New York City -- that established bastion of topical humor, the Upstairs at the Downstairs, and at a new, intimate club called The 12 Steps.

WHILE it is not certain that Al Pacino is getting typecast, I personally am positive that I would not wish to meet him on a dimly lit side street. Mr. Pacino, one of our most charismatic and violent actors, opened at the Actors Playhouse last night in a British play by Heathcote Williams, "The Local Stigmatic." He was ice-cold and savage.

Hardly anyone recognized Byron Dyce at Van Cortlandt Park Sunday as he jogged five miles in the rain. The New York University senior worked lightly over the course again yesterday, but he was just another cross-country runner preparing for today's Metropolitan Intercollegiate championships there.

The bankrupt New Haven Railroad Company -- the corporate shell that holds bonds and stocks of the Penn Central, which that carrier issued when it took over the New Haven's transportation plant -- isn't going to be out of reorganization "earlier than the end of 1971," according to its trustee, Richard Joyce Smith.

DOVER, N. J., Nov. 3 -- This community began to respond today to a call from its Mayor, Edward R. Horan, for aid to a family that lost seven of its nine children in a fire early yesterday.

Current press reports on the mutilation of the House tax reform bill at the hands of the Senate Finance Committee are distressing. The House bill, which offers the most important step towards constructive tax reform in many years, deserves a better fate.

A state judge ordered the city yesterday to release the completed parts of a master plan that reportedly outlines a vast series of proposed changes for the city for decades to come.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, who has criticized the Small Business Administration for not lending enough money to minority-run enterprises, yesterday took steps that he said would make it easier for minority-group businessmen here to get bank loans guaranteed by the Federal agency.

A State Supreme Court justice rejected yesterday a motion by Controller Mario A. Procaccino for the right to quesion personnel of The Daily News about the newspaper's method of conducting its mayorality poll.
The city has leased 20 acres of the Brooklyn Army Terminal from the Department of the Army, it was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay. The property includes two piers.
Tim Buckley, now more a jazz singer with a guitar than a folk singer, performed at Carnegie Hall on Sunday.

Tonight's "opening night" will not be the social pinnacle of the National Horse Show. Tomorrow's matinee will be the "in" time, when Prince Philip of Britain will attend.

Cautious consumer buying in New York City during October kept sales to a relatively small gain compared with last year in seven of the city's largest stores.

Edward Krock, a Massachusetts financier, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he filed false reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission when he was an official of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company.
SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 3 -- South Korea virtually devalued its "won" currency by 4.5 per cent today in a move to stimulate exports.

The annual North Shore Hospital Ball, to be held Saturday at the Americana Hotel here, will mark the recent affiliation between the Cornell University Medical College and the North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The president of the Air Line Pilots Association said today that if Italian authorities refused to return Raffaele Minichiello for trial on hijacking charges in this country, the United States Government should "go get him" in Italy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Following is a transcript of President Nixon's broadcast to the nation last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A spokesman for the American Medical Association told a House committee today that "greed and avarice are least obvious in the medical profession than any other, possibly excluding the ministry."

Nicholas (Big Nose) Tolentino a 60-year-old former convict reputed to be a Mafia lieutenant, was arrested yesterday in the Bronx and charged with evasion of the state income tax for allegedly failing to report a payment from a reputed gambler.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The chief of the National Guard Bureau is asking the nation's 500,000 guardsmen to stage what amounts to a counterdemonstration against war protest activities planned for next week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Sixteen Republican Congressmen asked President Nixon today to consider scrapping all chemical and biological weapons, contending that they undermine rather than strengthen the nation's security.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The organizers of the antiwar protests scheduled for next week said tonight that President Nixon's speech had given added impetus to their movement.
OTTAWA, Nov. 3 -- The Canadian Government announced today that it would close seven diplomatic missions abroad over the next five months in the interest of economy.

DETROIT, Nov. 3 -- Sales of new American-made cars in the final third of October trailed last year, as did deliveries for the four months, resuming the industry decline that began in July. Through June, sales of United States-made cars were slightly ahead of the 1968 level, but in July and August they trailed the level a year before, then spurted ahead in September, probably because of the earlier new-model introduction date.

Lung cancer, which has been linked mostly to smoking, will kill more than 51,000 men in the United States in the coming year, the American Cancer Society said yesterday. This represents an increase of 4,000 deaths from the level in 1969.

THE victory of the Dallas Aces in the playoff match that ended in Phoenix, Ariz., Sunday was not unexpected. The world's first professional bridge team displays a dedicated toughness few teams can match, and it may bring the Aces a world title in Stockholm next June.

The Northern Illinois Gas Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first 9 months. The report placed operating revenues at $212,078,760 against $194,491,076 for the corresponding 1968 period.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The Cunard Line announced today that it had solicited bids for the construction of one and possibly two new cruise ships for delivery in 1972.

ROME, Nov. 3 -- A United States diplomat pressed "at a high level" today for custody of the American marine who hijacked a Trans World Airlines plane last week. But at the same time sections of the Italian press, public and Government claimed him for Italy.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- "Le Jardin des Delices," a play by the Spanish-born Arrabal that opened here tonight, is perhaps the most important play on the French stage since Jean Genet's "The Screens."
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday a price reduction on electric resistance weld project line pipe and an increase on another pipe product.
Construction of the largest floating drydock in the United States was nearing the halfway mark yesterday at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's San Francisco shipyard.

Throughout the city yesterday, 6,871 tall gray voting machines, many of them unwelcome guests in stores, apartment houses and school lunchrooms, stood idle, attended only by the Board of Elections' 70 mechanics, who checked to see that the machines were in the right places.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- President Nixon pleaded tonight for domestic support as he persisted in his effort to find peace in Vietnam and as he unfolded what he said was a plan to bring home all United States ground combat forces on an orderly but secret timetable.

RECENTLY, researchers for the United States Department of Interior persuaded an 18-inch skipjack tuna to swallow a tiny transmitter powered by a potent Mallory battery the size of an aspirin. Returned to the sea, the fish sent out signals enabling scientists to track his peregrinations.

Plans for the establishment of the New York Times Archives and a related program of oral history were announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the publisher of The Times.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -The Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill today to permit joint operations of two competing newspapers in the same city if one of the papers is failing.

District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn, a prominent defense lawyer who switched to the prosecutor's side only last January, coasted to reelection yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- The Air Force abolished today the job of the civilian financial expert who had first called Congress's attention to skyrocketing costs for construction of the huge C-5A transport planes.
