CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- It was sort of quiet early in the evening at Chicago Stadium tonight. The Rangers were taking control of the puck. The Hawks, bewildered and diffused, went nowhere.

President Kenyatta has taken a bold gamble for Kenya's future by putting Oginga Odinga and his lieutenants under house arrest in Nyanza and banning Mr. Odinga's Kenya People's Union, the only opposition party. The provocation was undoubtedly great and Mr. Kenyatta evidently decided that a crackdown now against his former Vice President in the latter's Luo homeland was the lesser risk for the country.
Debate within the legal profession over tactics of young activist lawyers who view their role as that of vigorous advocate for the poor came into focus in Federal Court here yesterday.

The Student Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam announced yesterday a wide range of activities here for Nov. 13 and 14 and challenged President Nixon's "silent majority" to try to equal them.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The Royal Mail Lines was fined today because its liner Andes discharged oil at sea in a banned zone.

May I with all due respect disagree with The Times's analysis of the Metropolitan Opera's labor dispute with its unions, as set forth in a recent news article: "At Center of Met Feud: Bing and Gray" and as expressed in an editorial in your issue of Oct. 31 headed: "Death of the Met?" Both seemed to me only to have scratched the surface of the problem.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Federal District Judge Julius J. Hoffman convicted Bobby G. Seale on 16 counts of contempt of court today and sentenced him to four years in prison.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber, one of France's best-known editors and commentators. has caused a stir in the French political world by undertaking to breathe some life into the Radical party, an organization commonly considered moribund.

YANTA, Lebanon, Nov. 5 -- Lebanese soldiers handed back 90 prisoners near here today to the Palestinian Liberation Organization, from whose ranks the men were captured during the two weeks of fighting in this area. The guerrillas returned a captured jeep to the Lebanese.
The "loss" of more than $13-million in Treasury bills from the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company last month is now being listed as a "theft," the police disclosed yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay and his advisers began considering his second administration and his political future yesterday and concluded that the future might include his backing a Democratic candidate against Governor Rockefeller and eventually becoming a Democrat himself.

THE Los Angeles Rams, the only unbeaten team in pro football, were hit with a pair of injuries of significance this week. Myron Pottios, the middle linebacker, was in an automobile accident on Tuesday night and has facial lacerations plus internal bleeding in one eye.
A cocktail dansant for the benefit of the Brazilian Institute of New York University will take place next Thursday at the Tavern-on-the-Green.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 5 -- Cassius Clay, the former heavyweight boxing champion, filed legal arguments today in connection with his conviction and sentence of five years and a $10,000 fine for refusing to be inducted into the armed forces.
Following are the results of some of Tuesday's municipal elections around the country.
An East Village resident pleaded guilty yesterday to the slaying of 18-year-old Linda Fitzpatrick of Greenwich, Conn., in a slum tenement basement here more than two years ago.
The chairman of the State Senate Committee on Housing and Urban Development said yesterday that "New York City faces the worst housing crisis since the London blitz."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Consumers can do little to prevent fires from breaking out in their television sets, safety experts agree, but they suggest that the hazard may be reduced and the damage limited by observing some "do's" and "dont's."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The opening of Senate debate on the nomination of Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. to the Supreme Court has been scheduled for next week by Senator Mike Mansfield, the majority leader.
A long fought-over community proposal for an old-fashioned, walk - up housing project in the midst of a ware-house area of Greenwich Village was approved by the City Planning Commission last night.
Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld yesterday ordered that a three-judge court hear a challenge to the constitutionality of the state's abortion laws.
OTTAWA, Nov. 5 -- Canada will again abstain this year on the question of admitting Communist China to the United Nations, informed sources here said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- After a coalition led by Democrats rammed through several major toughening amendments, the House of Representatives passed tonight legislation regulating one - bank holding companies for the first time.
Striking members of the Communications Workers of America refused last night to heed their leaders' instructions to return to their jobs with the New York Telephone Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, after negotiations with the Government, has agreed to the largest reduction ever in its long-distance rates, it was announced today.
The London Stock Exchange moved ahead yesterday after recent dullness.

DALAT, South Vietnam, Nov. 5 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that South Vietnam intended to take over the war at a pace that would permit withdrawal of all American combat troops by the end of 1970 and support troops possibly a year later.

CONTROL DATA'S Harold Harlan Hammer is none too happy with his erstwhile colleagues on Wall Street. Control Data's financial vice president used to be a market analyst and still retains his "non-resident membership."
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday a two-step program designed to provide immediate financial aid for hospitals throughout the state and particularly in slum areas.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- North Vietnam charged today that President Nixon had been guilty of a breach of faith in disclosing in his address Monday that secret peace talks had taken place. The disclosure, North Vietnam said, showed the duplicity of the Administration's approach to a Vietnam settlement.
LAKE FOREST, Ill., Nov. 6 -- Robert E. Wood, who built Sears, Roebuck Co. into the world's largest merchandising concern, died today at his home in this Chicago suburb. He was 90 years of age.
A former president of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company testified yesterday that Roy M. Cohn told him he had information to compel a reluctant official to yield control of the bus line.

As a union negotiator with General Electric, I do not plead impartiality in discussing the issues of the present strike. I do, however, think it is necessary to take the discussion out of the realm of your Oct. 28 editorial speculation about "power" plays, that assumes the everyday needs of General Electric workers had nothing to do with their decision to walk off their jobs.

Negotiators for the Metropolitan Opera and the orchestra union, after rejecting a call for arbitration, have agreed to resume negotiations next Tuesday at 11 A.M. in the Roosevelt Hotel, a spokesman for Harry Van Arsdale, president of the New York City Central Labor Council said yesterday.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 6 -- The harvest season is just about over.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a $20.7-billion military authorization bill, over muted protests by some of its Pentagon critics. The vote was 59 to 9.
After each Oklahoma home game during the football season, Steve Owens and his wife, Barbara, pile into their old Falcon and drive 18 miles to Oklahoma City for a steak at Glenn's Hickory Inn.
HONG KONG, Nov. 6 (AP) -- North Vietnam renewed demands today that the United States withdraw all troops from Vietnam and abandon all support of the South Vietnamese government.
Youthful policemen and women are now posing as students at five or six city high schools in an effort to detect student lawbreakers, sources at the Board of Education said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- The Senate approved by voice vote today the $610-million food stamp program authorization that was accepted yesterday by the House.

HONOLULU, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus posted a course record of 63, nine under par, and established a four-stroke lead in the first round of the $125,000 Hawaiian international open golf tournament today.
The Department of Consumer Affairs issued yesterday a free 32-page handbook entitled "How to Sue Someone in New York City Small Claims Court."

ROME, Nov. 6 -- Thirty-one persons, including 24 policemen, were injured in strike violence in Milan and Bari today, and three of Italy's largest labor confederations called a nationwide general strike for Nov. 19.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Navy divers turned up nothing but an old wreck today and the Coast Guard indicated hope of finding the missing tugboat Marjorie McAllister and her six-man crew was fast fading.

" Salute to Black Women," a concert underscoring 300 years' contributions to American history by Negro women, will be presented twice tomorrow evening, from 6 to 8 o'clock and from 9 to 11 o'clock, at Philharmonic Hall at Lincoln Center.

BANMETHUOT, South Vietnam, Nov. 6 -- United States military officials said today they had decided not to commit any ground troops to the fighting now taking place southwest of here between South Vietnamese and enemy forces.

GENEVA, Nov. 6 -- Ministers of the eight-nation European Free Trade Association, meeting in Geneva today, quickly showed concern over the Nixon Administration's slowness in formulating trade policy and over the forthcoming Common Market meeting in The Hague.

Because 10 voters each preferred Denny McLain of Detroit and Mike Cuellar of Baltimore, while the remaining four preferred neither, there are co-winners of the Cy Young Award in the American League this year, the first time such a tie has developed in any of the categories the Baseball Writers' Association of America votes on annually.

Kemperco, Inc., the holding company for the Kemper Insurance Group with assets of $321-million, announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Supervised Investors Services, Inc., a mutual fund management company managing four funds with total assets of about $900-million.
A high Conservative party spokesman declared yesterday that Governor Rockefeller had "drawn the lines" for the 1970 state campaign by "throwing in again" with his party's liberal wing.

Some politicians appear to be upset because a variety of education groups have joined forces in Washington to create an education lobby. There is nothing new about the existence of lobbies for everything from oil depletion benefits to the defense establishment. Only education was supposed to be above such grubby practices which seek only money.

The legal battle involving Robert Maxwell, Pergamon Press, Ltd., Pergamon Press, Inc., and the Leasco Data Processing Equipment Corporation took yet another turn here yesterday with the disclosure of a new set of lawsuits.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Negro community leaders and representatives of Chicago's construction industry and its building trades unions agreed today on the general outline of a plan to take more Negroes into skilled construction jobs.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 -- A confidential staff memorandum prepared for the command at Fort Carson, Colo., described proposals for preventing five soldiers, known for their antiwar sentiments, from participating in Moratorium Day activities in Colorado Springs.

In a demonstration that called for plenty of power from their mounts, two riders from the Argentine topped the field last night in the demanding international jumping Puissance class at the National Horse Show.
HONG KONG, Nov. 6 -- As border talks continue between Communist China and the Soviet Union, China is believed to be preparing for the possibility of a Soviet attack if the talks break down.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Breaking a five-month deadlock, the House Education and Labor Committee approved today a $2.3-billion extension of the antipoverty program, $295-million over President Nixon's request for the fiscal year 1970.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Vietcong units, trying to infiltrate into Saigon for the first time since May, 1968, clashed with national policemen in the southwestern section of the capital early today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 6 -- A band of from 150 to 200 young people staged a 2 1/2-hour sit-in in front of the office of Massachusetts Institute of Technology today as demonstrations against military research here entered their third day.

THREE wartime incidents, two Vietnamese, one American Civil -- three novels (which proves once again that though war may be ugly, it is a potent producer of fiction). In "Masque of Honor," by Edward Linn and Jack Pearl, the ambush and escape of a group of American soldiers near Khesanh is puffed into an act of heroism by an unscrupulous Broadway columnist turned war correspondent.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- Five years ago, after Nikita S. Khrushchev's fall from power, one of his most ardent supporters, Nikolai V. Podgorny, was widely rumored in diplomatic circles as a strong pretender to the throne of Soviet power.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Justice Department said today that militant organizations were planning to stage violent confrontations during the antiwar demonstration here Nov. 15.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 6 -- Gov. James A. Rhodes, Ohio's best vote-getter, announced today his candidacy for the United States Senate next year.

BONN, Nov. 6 -- The West German central bank rescinded the bank's obligation to maintain full-reserve coverage on foreign deposits today in a first step to offset the money pinch that followed last month's revaluation of the West German mark.

A majority of American teen-agers oppose smoking, but environmental magnets like advertisements and the imitation of parents and peers still draw about 40 per cent to the habit, according to a study sponsored by the American Cancer Society.
The Dean of Students at City College has asked a special five-man student-faculty committee to investigate reports of an organized traffic in narcotics on the campus.

DR. JOAN SHALACK is a pretty California divorcee who leads something of a double life. In the mornings she practices Freudian psychiatry in Beverly Hills. In the afternoons she works at being president of her own perfume company.

Sam Katzman had been waiting for this moment for a solid year -- well, really two years, since the rumors started -- and when Meyer Slifkin, an assistant corporation counsel, reached across a table covered with legal papers the other afternoon and handed him a check for $25,402.51 Mr. Katzman's blue eyes twinkled and he could not suppress a grin.

IT'S axiomatic that a person's home tells a lot about the person. Now a sociologist at the University of Michigan has come up with guidelines that purport to relate decor not only to a life style but also the owner's background and beliefs.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Oct. 29 -- In a series of 20 or more flights during the coming months, British scientists hope that, figuratively, they can peel back a large part of Antarctica's ice covering, disclosing the continent that lies beneath.

American business appears to be determined to expand and improve its manufacturing and distribution capacity next year despite higher costs and interest rates, according to the latest survey on capital spending by the McGraw-Hill Publications Company.

Governor Rockefeller and the state administration were accused yesterday of pursuing a "conscious and deliberate policy" of discrimination against Negroes and Puerto Ricans seeking construction industry jobs.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Jeff Mullins reeled off six straight field goals in the third quarter to help the San Francisco Warriors open an insurmountable lead and defeat the Cincinnati Royals, 130-109, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

An airline executive forecast yesterday that the city's proposed Manhattan "STOLport" would never be built because it would create impossible highway congestion and be unpalatable to the community on grounds of aesthetics, noise and air pollution.

Edward J. Logue, who heads the state's Urban Development Corporation, said yesterday that the city would need $1-billion a year in Federal funds for five years to reverse the spiral of housing decay in the slums.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Air Force has hired as a $107-a-day consultant a partner in the accounting firm employed by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, the holder of one of the service's biggest and most controversial contracts.

RARELY at a loss for a formula, if occasionally short of a policy, the Lincoln Center Repertory Company has devoted this season, to what its director, Jules Irving, calls "four views of American life from different decades and from different vantage points."
Ease of delivery, suavity of manner and concentrated vocal control were the very undebutish characteristics of Philip Cho's New York recital debut last night at Alice Tully Hall.
Joe Namath's arm is ready for Buffalo and George Sauer's hands and legs are ready for the Bills' George Byrd.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Nixon Administration's drive to win Supreme Court confirmation for Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. suffered a serious psychological setback today when Senator Jack Miller of Iowa announced his opposition to the nominee.
CAPE KENEDY, Fla., Nov. 6 (UPI) -- The launching director took advantage of trouble-free work today and ordered the Apollo 12 countdown started at noon tomorrow, a day early.

If you have not yet observed Barnett Frummer's frantic but bankrupt pursuit of his ladylove Rosalie Mondle, you can do so now. And on the way you can pick up a few useful tips on how to make it with the crowd on the Upper West Side. Frummer once came within a doorman's nod of getting a rent-controlled apartment on the East Side, but the gods were only kidding.

A major breakthrough has been achieved in the conservationist campaign to preserve unspoiled the beautiful Lake Minnewaska resort area in the Shawungunk Mountains, only a two-hour drive from New York. But it is still uncertain that the dream of making it the nucleus of a woodlands park can be realized.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
Sanford D. Garelik, the newly elected President of the City Council, asserted his independence yesterday of all political parties and his right to disagree with Mayor Lindsay, his sponsor.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, Nov. 6 -- President Abdul Rahman al-Iryani of neighboring Yemen has agreed to continue in office as chairman of the three-man presidential council for another eight-month term at the request of the National Assembly, Yemen's first parliament in 1,100 years.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6 -- The top American commanders here believe that the United States can successfully withdraw all its ground combat forces over the next 18 months.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- President Nikolai V. Podgorny combined criticism of the Nixon Administration today with the hope that the forthcoming Soviet-American talks on limiting strategic arms would prove fruitful.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., Nov. 6 -- Widespread municipal zoning laws that exclude decent low- income housing were attacked today by civil rights leaders and spokesmen for the home- building industry at a conference here on Housing for the 70's.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 6 -- Fighting along the Suez Canal increased sharply today with two Egyptian commando raids, several artillery and mortar exchanges and an Israeli air strike.

Mayor Lindsay began fashioning his new administration yesterday by obtaining pledges of help from his recent opponents, Mario A. Procaccino and John J. Marchi, and holding his first official meeting with a group of supporters, the Fusion Advisory Council.

The Appellate Division reversed yesterday the convictions of a suspended official of the City Housing Authority and of three painting contractors and their companies on charges of bribery and conspiring to rig bids on $42-million in city contracts.
CAIRO, Nov. 6 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser said tonight that a path of "fire and blood," not political "half-solutions" was the only way for the Arabs to recover their occupied lands from Israel.

GENEVA, Nov. 6 -- Armand Hammer, chairman of the board of the Occidental Petroleum Company, paid $313,953 tonight for "Bonjour Monsieur Gauguin," a self-portrait painted in 1889 to decorate the dining room of an inn where he was staying in Britanny.
DICKSON, Tenn., Nov. 6 -- The old man stood at the corner of Main and College Streets watching the black and silver hearse move quietly by.
A wildcat strike by telephone repairmen and installers continued to spread across the state yesterday in defiance of court-ordered appeals by the union leadership.
The sloppy footing at Aqueduct yesterday was more suitable for the favorites than it was the day before, when the public choices failed in all nine attempts.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- North Vietnamese troops assaulting an American artillery base north of Saigon were met with a hail of arrows as well as bullets. The arrows came from a longbow wielded by a cook who found himself short of rifle ammunition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Nixon Administration announced today a plan to make up to $500-million available by next June to finance Negro business opportunities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- The Penn Central Railroad, after one and one-half years as a merged company, has failed to regain its competitiveness and continues financially shaky, a railroad attorney told the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

WHEN Cy Young was a wrinkled old man of 85, he was approached by a boy with a total ignorance of baseball history. Because there was a gathering of Hall of Famers and other diamond celebrities, the kid had to assume the white-haired old gaffer once had some connection with the sport.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Nixon will go to Cape Kennedy to watch the launching of the Apollo 12 moon shot next Friday, the White House announced today. He will be the first President to see the launching of a manned space shot while in office.

" Money and power are desirable if they can be obtained without the sacrifice of principle. The greatest success comes not from money, power or fame, but from a happy marriage, a happy family and a happy home."
The Federal Reserve System has shown no sign of relenting in its policy of extremely tight credit in the last two weeks, banking figures published yesterday showed.
New York University obtained an injunction yesterday barring two militant student groups from any violence on university grounds pending a court hearing Nov. 17.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has taken initial steps to take over the operation of two bases in the metropolitan area that are being closed by the Air Force.

TRENTON, Nov. 6 -- Representative William T. Cahill, the Republican Governor-elect, modified some of his campaign pledges today and refused to be drawn out on others at his first news conference since becoming the biggest gubernatorial winner in New Jersey's history.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Two ballets by Frederick Ashton were revived by the Royal Ballet at Covent Garden last night, and it is no exaggeration to call both of them masterpieces. Although the Royal Ballet has a large potential repertory, comparatively few works are given in any one season, and this leads to curious neglect of some fine ballets.

EXPATRIATE American bridge enthusiasts often contribute substantially to the development of the game in other parts of the world. Roberts Chapin, a famiilar figure in New York bridge circles before World War II who died this week in Florida, played a major role in Venezuelan bridge in recent years.

TOKYO, Nov. 6 -- The Japanese Government said today that it did not expect the forthcoming talks on Okinawa to be directly affected by the United States Senate's resolution calling on President Nixon to seek its advice and consent on the return of the island to Japan.

Peter Yarrow, Paul Stookey and Mary Travers -- Peter, Paul and Mary -- made one of their infrequent concert appearances last night at Philharmonic Hall in a benefit for the United Nations International School.

The next to the last of Mayor Lindsay's proposed "superagencies," the Transportation Administration, will come up for a vote before the present City Council expires at the end of the year, according to Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 6 -- State Senator Edward J. Speno called today for an impartial panel to review the questions raised when the Long Island newspaper Newsday published a series of articles that were critical of him.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 6 (UPI) -- A Federal judge today approved balloting procedures to be followed by the United Mine Workers when its members vote for a president next month.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 6 -- A harness horse yearling sold for a record sum of $125,000 today at the conclusion of the 31st annual auction of the Standardbred Horse Sales Company in the State arena.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The World Federation for Mental Health has been made the victim of what it calls a "destructive hoax" that threatens the success of its annual conference. The conference is scheduled to bring 2,000 delegates from the United States and abroad to Washington on Nov. 17.

Alex Rose, the Liberal party's chief political strategist, said yesterday that "a lot of people assume the new Lindsay administration will be a Liberal party one," but that the Liberals did not want a one-party administration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- The House approved today a 10-year, $5-billion airport and airways development program that includes new user taxes to help cover the costs.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 6 (UPI) -- Emile Francis, coach and general manager of the New York Rangers, said today that "for the good of the game" he "might" agree to have his team play the Los Angeles Kings Saturday afternoon instead of Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Nixon Administration is focusing on two alternate plans for the next American troop withdrawal from Vietnam.

Papert, Koenig, Lois Advertising, which recently took in a new three-man creative team from Jack Tinker Partners, has saved the Piel's beer account. The $3-million in beer billings now represents a major part of the business.

MAYAN BARUKH, Israel, Nov. 6 -- A Lebanese peasant, plowing his tiny tobacco field with a pair of oxen today, did not bother to look up as an Israeli border patrol drove slowly by, 70 yards away along a frontier road.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The most interesting reaction to the recent state and city elections in the United Sates was the President's. For the pundits and new Governors and Mayors can be wrong and even silly without doing too much harm, but the President's conclusions influence all the policies and priorities at home and abroad.

YONKERS, Nov. 6 -- Fresh Yankee, a $900 yearling who has grown into an affluent 6-year-old with earnings of $420,476, is listed as the 4-to-5 favorite in tomorrow night's $50,000 United Nations trot at Yonkers Raceway.
Judah Gribetz, who was dismissed nearly four years ago as Buildings Commissioner by Mayor Lindsay, has been asked by the Mayor to accept the post of City Housing and Development Administrator.
The bond market, still struggling to regain its equilibrium after President Nixon's address Monday night, was unable to absorb yesterday a huge volume of new financings.

PARIS -- The new Soviet ploy in Europe is in fact an old ploy, revived for changed circumstances. This ploy is quite simply to try and negotiate a deal with West Germany that would in the long run tend to neutralize its role in and value to NATO.
In moderately heavy trading, prices advanced slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, although the stocks showing declines outnumbered those advancing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The State Department declined comment on President Nasser's speech today, saying that the full text would have to be studied.
An educator who quit the administration of Columbia University a year ago because of "deep differences" said last night that "a bleak outlook" there had changed to "a healthy, exciting panorama."

WENDING their merry way westward, the New York Knickerbockers have now won 12 of their 13 games and have held the opposition under 100 points more than half the time. In the process, they have made their fans defense-conscious as never before.

Meredith Monk, a 25-year-old Sarah Lawrence graduate and avant-garde choreographer who grew up in a radio control room while her mother sang "D-U-Z does everything," will have her mother join her today on the Guggenheim Museum's ramp for the first installment of "Juice."

IF Francesco Consentino doesn't know whether he is coming or going these days, it is understandable. As one of Italy's two leading offshore ocean powerboat racers, he has been chasing world champions over most of the globe for six years trying to wrest the title.

Talk of demand abroad raised prices for soybean oil on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Once again, as they have recently, soybean oil contracts set a new round of life-of-contract highs yesterday on heavy volume.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- New York City's Commissioner of Hospitals called the state's Medicaid program a failure today, and said the city had been able to do as much with less trouble under the old system of voluntary clinics.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

Governor Rockefeller, who sharply criticized Senator Charles E. Goodell's call last month for a Vietnam pullout yesterday called the Senator "the brightest, ablest man that I know on the political scene."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered a 45-day suspension today of the Brimingham, Ala., office of Andresen Co., a New York Stock Exchange firm.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6 -- American combat deaths in October fell to their lowest monthly level in more than three years, according to United States military statistics. Enemy attacks this week, however, were expected to result in substantially higher losses for November.

Less than one year ago the Security Council was called into emergency session by both Lebanon and Israel. Lebanon complained about the Israeli raid on the Beirut airport and Israel protested the attack on an El Al airliner in Athens by Lebanon-based members of the National Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

AIHA, Lebanon, Nov. 6 -- Escorted by a small Lebanese Army contingent, four Palestinian commandos drove into this quiet hill town today to reclaim a munitions truck they had been forced to abandon in their unsuccessful fight to capture Aiha and nearby Rasheiya five days ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A labor agreement was announced today that could lead to increasing mass production and distribution of prefabricated homes. Officials of the Nixon Administration say the homes represent a key to solving the nation's housing crisis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The White House Consumer Office, designed to protect the public, would be advised by business under legislation being drafted by the Nixon Administration, Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Pentagon announced today that "research breakthroughs" had eliminated the need to gird a large part of Northern Wisconsin as part of a controversial billion-dollar Navy submarine communication system.
THE worst fears of a number of Ivy League alumni have been realized this fall.

VIEWERS who feel strongly that public television should be experimental are invited to tune in tonight at 8:30 to Channel 13 for National Educational Television's production of Paul Foster's mythic drama, "!Heimskringla! Or the Stoned Angels."

Gen. Omar N. Bradley, says that "in World War II, we in Europe were an ocean away from home. "Today in Korea, in Vietnam, our servicemen and women are an ocean away from home. And in Europe, they are still an ocean away from home.

FORT DIX, N.J., Nov. 6 -- Army Pvt. Jeffrey Russell, the defendant in a general court-martial here, was found not guilty of the charge of solicitation to riot, but he is still defending himself on charges of riot and arson stemming from a stockade disturbance last June 5.

Milton Friedman, the University of Chicago economist whose views on the importance of money to economic activity have found widened acceptance in recent years, said yesterday that the Federal Reserve already may have begun to ease its tight money policy.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- The stormy North Atlantic began to lose some of its punch today and search operations were expanded for 36 crewmen aboard the stern section of a Liberian tanker split by vicious seas.
Nicholas Johnson, a consistent critic of commercial television as a member of the Federal Communications Commission, was at the top of his form yesterday.

The labor troubles that dogged Mayor Lindsay's first term started in the subways five hours after he was sworn in. The disastrous transit strike of 1966 was followed by a series of crises in virtually every major municipal service. Out of these conflicts has grown a pattern of purchasing labor peace at a very high price, even by inflationary standards.
FRED MATES is back in the mutual-fund derby -- refurbishing his image as a clever stock analyst -- and tooting his horn about his comeback.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- Montreal scored three goals in the third period to defeat Philadelphia, 4-1, in a National Hockey League game tonight and hand the Flyers their first loss in 14 home games.

OTTAWA, Nov. 6 -- Government officials said today that the prospect of making a major oil discovery in the Canadian Arctic had been strengthened by the evaluation, just received, of a gas reservoir on Drake Point, Melville Island.
The nation's bankers reacted yesterday with concern at the action of the House of Representatives in passing an unexpectedly rigid bill to control the activities of one-bank holding companies.

In what the Government described as "one of the most unusual tax-evasion cases," a husband and wife were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of evading income taxes for three years, starting 28 years ago.

SAN DIEGO, Nov. 6 -- "What we do in the next three games will be criteria for judgment," said Willis Reed this afternoon after the New York Knickerbockers had finished a practice scrimmage at San Diego State University.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 6 -- Richard S. Jackson, 61-year-old Mayor here for nearly three years, announced his resignation today. He will become executive director of the Atlantic City Expressway, 44-mile high-speed toll road between the Philadelphia-Camden area and Atlantic City.

HARVARD'S football team in the Rose Bowl? Don't snicker. Everyone knows the Ivies are not permitted to play postseason games. But 50 years ago, long before the formalization of the Ivy League in 1956, the Cantabs compiled an 8-0-1 won-lost-tied record, then hopped a train to Pasadena, Calif., to play in the Rose Bowl on New Year's Day, 1920.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- A financial authority who helped shape the monetary system at Bretton Woods 25 years ago predicted an American victory over inflation today, but he warned that this might halt the growth of trade and perhaps lead to a general world recession.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A top official of the Boeing Company defended today the mammoth Boeing 747 jet against recent industry criticisms.

Fritz Jahoda, who made his New York debut 25 years ago, celebrated the anniversary last night with a piano recital at Carnegie Recital Hall. The Vienna-born musician, for many years a leading teacher and chamber-music participant, played a program of Beethoven, Schumann, Bartok, Kurka and Chopin that amply indicated his experience in both those areas.
Detectives searched yesterday for a man who stabbed two women within the space of a few minutes in separate attacks in the Bronx Wednesday night.

Memorex, a producer of computer equipment, raced ahead 12 1/2 points as a market stand out yesterday, while the New York Stock Exchange list generally held to an even tenor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted $600.5-million today for the Model Cities program, restoring $100-million of a House cut.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- With White House encouragement, the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved today a resolution endorsing President Nixon's "efforts to negotiate a just peace in Vietnam."

Dancing will be rampant, a la mode, impromptu and also fun, the evening of Nov. 19, when balletomanes and the dancers they idolize take over the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at 111 Amsterdam Avenue at 65th Street.
The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of companies reported yesterday higher sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.

CHESTERTOWN, Md. -- A forthright assessment of the average waterfowl hunter's ability as a wing shot is implicit in a letter bearing the signature of R. H. Coleman, president and general manager of Remington Arms Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- The Commerce Department announced today it would begin allocating nickel for defense use from surplus Government stocks this month. A department spokesman said that up to 4,500 tons was being made available to meet the current shortage of the metal.
Across the crowded dressing room, one of Steve Wright's New York Giant teammates spotted the 6-foot-6-inch 250-pound offensive tackle talking to a stranger and yelled: "Hey Steve. whatcha doing?"

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Nov. 6 -- Judge James A. Boyle of the Dukes County District Court said today that he would not set a date for an inquest in the death of Mary Jo Kopechne until the question of an autopsy was settled in Pennsylvania.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Frankie DePaula, 182 pounds, Jersey City, knocked down Artie Miller, 190, of Youngstown, Ohio, with the first punch of the fight and later went on to score a 36-second knockout in the sixth round of a 10-rounder at the Philadelphia Arena tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 6 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit today gave 30 Mississippi school districts until Dec. 31 to implement effective desegrega tion plans and said it would issue orders tomorrow on just what those plans should be.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- A defense motion for a mistrial in regard to the seven remaining defendants in the trial of the Chicago eight was denied today by Judge Julius S. Hoffman.

ROME, Nov. 6 -- The mother, sister and lawyer of the youth who hijacked an airliner from the West Coast of the United States to Rome last weekend attributed his actions today to a "personality change" after combat as a United States marine in South Vietnam.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6 -- Rossini's "La Cenerentola" is a lovely opera, and an amusing opera, and a masterpiece of the buffo style, but it is very, very hard to sing. It needs a coloratura tenor and baritone as well as a coloratura soprano and mezzo-soprano.

THE Harkness Ballet, which last night opened its season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is one of those institutions perpetually poised on the brink of transition. In past years it always looked as though it was momentarily on the point of being far better than it was.

Scores of letter carriers applied yesterday for welfare assistance at the City Welfare Center at 260 West 30th Street in a demonstration by Branch 36 of the National Association of Letter Carriers.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- The Common Market Executive Commission today proposed that the community pay $180-million over four years toward offsetting the loss caused to West German farmers by the revaluation of the mark.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 6 -- The North Atlantic Alliance agreed today to broaden its activities to include the fight to protect man's environment against the effects of industrial civilization.

THE drawings of Saul Steinberg rank high among the few great comic achievements of our time. Mr. Steinberg is an extremely sharp observer, a hilarious visual punster, a mordant analyst of manners and a satirist of genius. His feats of draftsmanship are so dazzling and so various -- and yet so far removed from the kind of empty glitter usually associated with mere virtuosity -- that they all but defy critical analysis.

Further layoffs in airline personnel because of economy moves were announced yesterday by three air carriers.

MEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 7 -- More than 400 Tufts University students took a day off from classes today and milled peacefully through administration offices to dramatize demands for more minority workers on a dormitory construction project.

A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn handed down a three-count indictment yesterday against Lance Cpl. Raffaele Minichiello, the trans-Atlantic plane hijacker now in jail in Rome.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- The Soviet Union reminded the world of its nuclear power today as it marked the 52d anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution with a traditional military parade of men and missiles through Red Square. fense Minister Andrei A. THE Jets are a 14-point favorite to win their seventh game tomorrow, against troubled Buffalo at Shea Stadium, while the Giants will be a 6-point underdog in St. Louis.
